A.1. Project Company
The AES Corporation, USA is a leading global power company comprised of competitive generation,
distribution, and retail supply businesses in Argentina, Australia, Bangladesh, Brazil, Canada, China,
Dominican Republic, El Salvador, Georgia, Hungary, India, Kazakhstan, the Netherlands, Mexico,
Pakistan, Panama, the United Kingdom and the United States.
The company's generating assets include interests in one hundred and twenty-three plants totalling over
43,000 megawatts of capacity. The company's electricity distribution network has over 954,013 km of
conductor and associated rights of way. In addition, through its various retail electricity supply
businesses, the company sells over 115,869 giga-watt hours per year to around 15.7 million end-use
customers. The company employs over 40,000 people around the world and is dedicated to providing
electricity worldwide in a socially responsible way.
A.2. Project Sponsor
The AES Corporation formed AES Meghnaghat Limited (AES), based in Dhaka, Bangladesh, for the
purposes of managing the Meghnaghat Power Project. AES is the project sponsor and is supported with
technical and managerial staff from The AES Corporation. It is a wholly owned subsidiary of AES
Corporation and was incorporated on February 4, 1999 under the Government of Bangladesh's
Companies Act of 1994. The authorized capital of the company is Taka 10 million divided into 10,000
shares of Taka 1,000 each. Management of the company is comprised of a Board of Directors and a
number of recruited personnel.
AES is developing the 450 MW Meghnaghat Power Project, which is to be established on a Build, Own,
and Operated basis. The project was granted to AES through a competitive bidding process that has
resulted in the execution of four project agreements:
* Implementation Agreement with the Ministry of Energy and Mineral Resources;
*  Gas Supply Agreement with Titas Gas Transmission and Distribution Company Limited;
* Land Lease Agreement with Bangladesh Power Development Board; and
* Power Purchase Agreement with Bangladesh Power Development Board.
All project agreements were officially executed on July 29, 1999. AES expects to start commercial
operation of all power plants within thirty-seven and a half months of the execution of the project
agreements.
A.3. Study Team
The Canadian-based firm of ESG International was the lead consultant for preparation of the Initial
Environmental Examination and Environmental Impact Assessment. ESG International's personnel are
familiar with power project development as well as the environmental guidelines applied by multilateral
lending institutions, such as the International Finance Corporation. ESG Intemational also has experience
with the environmental assessment and approvals process administered by the Department of
Environment for Bangladesh.
To aid in the collection, interpretation, and analysis of data relevant to this project, ESG International has
coordinated input from specialist subconsultants in the areas of: air dispersion modeling and noise
assessment (RWDI Inc., Canada); public consultation and socio-economic assessment (Deodar Associates
Inc., USA); Bangladesh EIA process, data collection and surveys, and public consultation (Design
Planning Consultants, Bangladesh); and power plant design and operation (AES Meghnaghat Private
Limited, Hyundai Engineering and Construction Company Ltd., Korea and Ansaldo Energia s.p.a., Italy).

Introduction
The AES Corporation, founded in 1981, is the world's largest global power company. The Company is dedicated to
supplying safe, clean, reliable electricity to meet global energy needs. AES generates and distributes electricity and is
also a retail marketer of heat and electricity.
AES owns or has an interest in one hundred and thirty three plants totaling over 47,000 megawatts in 19 countries.
AES also distributes electricity in 9 countries through 19 distribution businesses. In addition to having assets in excess
of $29 billion, the Company has numerous projects in construction or late stages of development.
AES has placed more than $15 billion of financing with commercial banks, export credit agencies, multilateral
financial institutions and public markets. The Company employs roughly 56,000 people around the world.

EVALUATION OF PROJECT ALTERNATIVES AND COST-BENEFIT
ANALYSES
1. Project Alternatives
Several ministries within the Govemment of Bangladesh have previously evaluated project alternatives as
part of their individual planning and development activities. Following a sequential-step analyses, this
alternatives evaluation surnmarises the findings contained within these reports to formulate a set of
project-specific conclusions pertaining to the preferred:
*   project site location;
*   project fuel resource;
*   generation technology; and
*   mode of transportation for project materials.
This evaluation also includes an overview of the need for a modern electrical transmission system in
Bangladesh as well as the supply of natural gas fuel to the project site. All of the alternatives reviewed as
part of this project are summarised below
1.1 Site Locations
Due to its concentration of population and industry, Dhaka City has the greatest demand for electricity
within Bangladesh. As such, the Ministry of Energy and Mineral Resources (MEMR) has indicated that
new (private sector) power plant development should first occur in the vicinity of Dhaka City (Power
Cell, 1996).
To assist in the development of private sector power plants a consortium based group was formed,
consisting of members from Power Cell, the Bangladesh Power Development Board (BPDB),
Petrobangla, and Titas Gas Transmission and Distribution Company Limited (Titas), and conducted site
visits to seven altemative site locations near Dhaka City. The results of their studies are summarised in
Table 1.
Table 1: Consortium Evaluation of Altemative Power Plant Sites

In addition to the consortium's evaluation and ranking of the altemative sites, ESG also conducted a desk-
top review of the seven alternative sites as part of the AES Haripur Power Project (ESG, 1999). Based
upon available information, the desk-top review identified the consortium's evaluation and ranking as
acceptable.
Of the top four sites (i.e., Haripur-KA, Haripur-KHA, Haripur-GA, and Meghnaghat), three sites are no
longer available for developmnent activities. A summary of the current political and/or construction
activities occurring at these altemative sites is provided below.
Haripur - K4
The Smith Cogen Project was tendered in 1997 by the BPDB. This barge-mounted power plant is in
close proximity to alternative site 4 and as such, BPDB removed this site from its list due to the
possibility of cumulative environmental effects. As such, this site has been removed from further
evaluation.
J
ESG INTERNATIONAL INC.                                                                                               B- 2
SEPTEMBER, 2000



AES MEGHNAGHAT LTD.
MEGHNAGHAT POWER PROJECT
FINAL ENVIRONMENTAL IMPCAT ASSESSMENT
> Haripur - KHA
AES Haripur Pvt. Ltd. concluded the signing of the LLA, PPA, GSA, IA, and other agreements in the
winter of 1998 with the relevant GOB ministries. Site filling, grading, and general construction works
began following the signing of the agreements and submission of the EIA to the World Bank and DOE.
Consequently, this site is no longer available for development and has been removed from further
evaluation..
Haripur - GA
The BPDB also discarded alternative this alternative as a possible site for power plant development due to
problems with construction in the local area. Construction of the power plant on this site could adversely
impact the use of the Haripur Substation, making expansion or use of the substation impractical for future
use. ln addition, incoming transmission lines would significantly limit the layout of the power plant.
Consequently, this site has been eliminated from further evaluation.
Meghnaghat
Considering these development proposals and activities, in relation to the four preferred alternative sites,
alternative site 7 (i.e., Meghnaghat) is the only remaining site of those considered and has been selected
as the preferred site for this project. Selection of the Meghnaghat site for power plant developrent is
further supported by the findings of the 1985 and 1995 Power System Master Plans, produced by Acres
International, which identify this site as the next probable large site for development (Acres, 1995). The
Project Sponsor has subsequently signed the LLA, PPA, GSA, IA, among others with the relevant
ministries of the GOB in 1999.
1.2  Fuel Resources
Indigenous natural gas was identified as the preferred fuel for the MPSA by Acres in the 1995 Power
System Master Plan (PSMP) based in part upon:
* availability;
*  certainty of supply over a project's lifecycle;
*  transport distances and costs; and
*  spent fuel emissions.
Confirmation of the fuel selection for Phase I of the MPSA has since been provided by the Project
Sponsor. The following discussion provides an overview of the various fossil fuel sources currently
available in Bangladesh.
Natural Gas
Petrobangla is the responsible government agency for the production of all liquid and gas hydrocarbons.
Under the supervision of Petrobangla eleven onshore gas fields are operated by two of its subsidiary
companies. Occidental of Bangladesh Limited, a wholly owned subsidiary of Unocal, USA, also operates
an onshore gas field. Offshore, one gas field in the Bay of Bengal is operated by Shell Bangladesh
Exploration and Development B.V., Netherlands. Collectively, these gas fields are currently producing
natural gas with a current daily production capacity of over 1,300 rmillion standard cubic feet per day
(mmscfd). Titas is among one of the three subsidiary distribution and marketing companies owned by
Petrobangla and will supply natural gas to the Project Sponsor under the terms and conditions of their Gas
Supply Agreement.
ESG INTERNATIONAL INC.                                                                B- 3



AES MEGHNAGHAT LTD.
MEGHNAGHAT POWER PROJECr
FINAL ENVIRONMENtAL IMPCAT ASSESSMENT
At Meghnaghat, there is an existing gas connection 400 metres from the boundary of the MPSA. It is
anticipated that this connection can supply enough gas to support power generation facilities up to 1,200
MW (MEP, 1997).
In Bangladesh, the costs of extracting and delivering natural gas are significantly below the costs of using
coal, peat, or crude oil. As for emissions, a natural gas-fired boiler typically releases 56,100 g/GJ of
carbon dioxide (CO2), 17 g/GJ of carbon monoxide (CO), 1.4 g/GJ of methane (CH4), and 67 g/GJ of
nitrogen dioxide (NO2) (World Bank, 1998).
Using the most conservative estimates of the existing reserves, Petrobangla has identified proven,
recoverable reserves of natural gas totalling 10.2 trillion cubic foot (Tcf) with a current delivery rate of
1,100 million cubic feet per day (mmscfd). In the fiscal year ended June 1996 the consumption rate of
natural gas for power generation was 100.18 billion cubic feet (Bcf) or 40.2% of that year's production
rate. In the fiscal year ended June 1998, gas consumption for power generation was 137.5 Bcf against the
country's total consumption of 307.23 Bcf (44.75%). It shows that share of natural gas in power
generation is gradually increasing. With the continued exploration and development of new proven and
recoverable natural gas fields in Bangladesh, the country has no immediate or foreseeable supply
shortages. With the recent discovery of a new gas field by Occidental of Bangladesh Limited at Bibiyana
in the Sylhet area with a recoverable reserve of 3.0 Tcf, the country's proven gas reserve has increased to
around 13 Tcf and Unical is planning to develop this gas filed in the near future.
coal
The MEMR is responsible for the overall development and management of coal and other comrnercial
energy resources, while the Bureau of Mineral Development (BMD) is responsible for issuing leases for
coal exploration and development. As of 1995 no coal mines were in operation in Bangladesh, however,
economnically-viable areas have been identified and are currently undergoing development by private and
public sector organizations.
Coal development is a relatively recent phenomenon in Bangladesh. Until recently, deposits were only
known to exist at depths between 650 to almost 3000 metres. Most recently deposits have been
discovered at depths of 75 metres, thus making extraction much more feasible. It has been estimated that
there are 1,782 million tonnes of coal in Bangladesh. The coal mine at Barapukuria is presently under
exploration by Chinese Machinery Consortium (CMS). This mine is expected to produce I million tonnes
of coal beginning in 2001. The coal from this mine will mainly be used in a power plant to be located near
the mnine site.
Along with its limited availability, coal is one of the least environmentally preferred fossil fuels. Coal-
fired boilers release 94,000 g/GJ of carbon dioxide (CO2), 93 g/GJ of carbon monoxide (CO), 2.4 g/GJ of
methane (CH4), and 329 g/GJ of nitrogen dioxide (NO2) (World Bank, 1998). For these reasons, coal is
not considered to be a practical nor suitable fuel for the Meghnaghat power plant.
Peat
The 1985 PSMP identified peat as a possible resource fuel for power generation. Since 1985, however,
minimal work has been undertaken in regard to this fuel source as extraction of this resource is difficult
due to the low-lying nature of the Bengal terrain. Further, extraction of such a resource is very labour
intensive that is offset by the low-energy produced from peat. Consequently, this fuel source was
excluded from further evaluation
ESG INTERNATIONAL INC                                                                  B- 4
SEPTEMBER, 2000



AES MEGHNAGHAT LTD.
MEGHNAGHAT POWER PROJECT
FINAL ENVIRONMENTAL IMPCAT ASSESSMENT
Crude Oil
Traditional liquid fuels used for power generation in Bangladesh include superior kerosene oil (SKO),
high-speed diesel (HSD), light diesel oil (LDO), and grade one heavy fuel oil commonly referred to as
furnace oil (HFO). SKO, HSD, LDO, and HFO are typically imported directly or derived from imported
crude oil refined at Chittagong and distributed throughout the country. The majority of crude oil in
Bangladesh is supplied from the Arabian Gulf.
As a result, crude oil is an expensive source of fuel. In 1995, its estimated cost was US $17/barrel in
constant 1995 dollars (Asian Development Bank, 1995) against the current market price of approximately
US $29/barrel. Additionally, wastes from crude oil combustion include particulates (including heavy
metals), sulphur and nitrogen oxides, and in some cases volatile organic compounds (World Bank, 1998).
For these reasons, crude oil was excluded from further evaluation.
Summary
As noted by the World Bank (1998), the use of coal, peat, and HFO fuels for power generation typically
results in a greater potential for adverse environmental effects when compared to natural gas. Further, the
combustion products of natural gas are the least objectionable of the common fossil fuels. Throughout
most regions of the world, and indeed in Bangladesh, natural gas is the least-cost alternative fuel for
power generation. This makes natural gas the preferred fuel for the Meghnaghat Power Project.
1.3 Generation Technology
As part of the 1995 PSMP, Acres identified combined cycle engines as the preferred, least-cost generation
technology for large thermal power plants (Acres, 1995). Combined cycle technology provides the
mZ        highest thermal efficiency rating while having the lowest generating costs of all fossil fuel plants
operating above 40% load. Consequently, this technology has become the preferred power generation
method around the world, especially where natural gas is available for fuel. In comparison to a steam
turbine plant, a combined cycle plant can be built faster, constructed at a lower cost, and situated on a
smaller land area; all three factors are important for power generation development in Bangladesh.
When operating on natural gas, the environmental impacts of a combined cycle power plant are low in
comparison to oil-fired steam and coal-fired power plants (e.g., lower emissions are produced from
combined cycle technology). In addition, since quantities of sulphur dioxide and particulate matter are
typically negligible in the natural gas fuel, so too are the associated emissions. Oxides of nitrogen (NOx),
cooling water discharge, and noise are generally the main emissions of concern.
To reduce air emissions, several methods can be used to limit the formation of NOx in the turbine
combustors, and include: use of special combustors, keeping air-gas mixtures lean, injecting water or
steam in conjunction with the fuel into the combuster, and selective catalytic reduction devices which
apply an ammonia reactant which converts the NOx to nitrogen and water vapour. With such reduction
methods available, combined cycle technology is the preferred method for power generation.
1.4 Modes of Transportation
All heavy project equipment manufactured outside of Bangladesh (e.g., gas turbines and heat recovery
steam generators) will be shipped to the country's second largest port at Mongla via ocean going vessels.
The country's primary port at Chittagong will not be used for heavy equipment transfer due to congestion
and frequent labour slowdowns. Additionally, any heavy equipment unloaded at Chittagong Port would
need to be carried on shallow barges across the Bay of Bengal, which often experiences unfavorable
ESG INTERNATIONAL INC                                                                  B- 5



AES MEGHNAGHAT LTD.
MEGHNAGHAT POWER PROJECT
FINAL ENVIRONMENTAL IMPCAT ASSESSMENT
marine weather conditions during the monsoon season. Light cargo, consisting of minor construction
materials and spare parts, could efficiently be unloaded at Chittagong Port for transport via road to the
MPSA.
Consequently, the review of alternative modes of transportation is limited to the in-country infrastructures
of rail, river, and road networks. Each mode of transportation is discussed below.
Rail
Based upon desk-top and in-field surveys, there are no existing rail lines in the immediate vicinity of the
MPSA (e.g., within 35 kilometres), nor are there any plans to construct such facilities. As a result, this
transportation option was discarded from further analysis.
River
The Meghna River remains navigable throughout the year, with access to the Bay of Bengal and other
rivers extending up to Mongla Port. Heavy cargo can be shipped through this waterway system, from
Mongla Port to the MPSA, on shallow barges on a year round basis. The Project Sponsor is currently
seeking approval from the Bangladesh Inland Water Transportation Authority to construct a temporary
jetty at the MPSA to facilitate removal of the heavy equipment once it arrives at the project site. This
mode of transportation is the preferred mode of transportation for heavy equipment.
Road
The MPSA is located adjacent to the Dhaka-Chittagong Highway and the BPDB has constructed of a
small access road from the highway to the MPSA. The Dhaka-Chittagong Highway is one of the
Country's major transport arteries connecting the capital city with its primary port at Chittagong.
Consequently, road transport offers a practical mode of transportation for imported lightweight project
supplies with no additional or supporting infrastructure required from the Project Sponsor.
However, heavy loads cannot be carried on this highway route due to limited load bearing capacity of the
road, its associated bridges, and dimensions (e.g., width). For these reasons, the highway will only be
used to transport light cargo from Chittagong Port to the MPSA.
1.5 Electrical Transmission System
In Bangladesh, 132 kV and 230 kV transmnission lines are the standard high voltages. The 1995 PSMP
noted that in order to increase the efficiency of the existing transmission system, while expanding
delivery capabilities throughout Bangladesh, two key tasks required completion:
* a 230 kV nrng around the Dhaka; and
* a 230 kV transmission line from Chittagong to Cornilla and on to Meghnaghat and Haripur
(Acres, 1995).
These two recommendations are currently in various stages of construction by the Power Grid Company
of Bangladesh (PCGB). Environmental reviews and funding for these undertakings have been provided
by the Asian Development Bank (ADB).
Since the 1995 PSMP, the PGCB has been formed as an entity under the BPDB and charged with the
responsibility of constructing electrical lines. With funding from ADB, the PGCB has embarked upon
several projects throughout the Country; generally following the recommendations of the 1995 PSMP..

SEPTEMBER, 2000



AES MEGHNAGHAT LTD.

Power Supply in Bangladesh
As noted (Acres, 1995), Bangladesh is in need of a modern electrical transmission system capable of
___/     transporting ppwer throughout the country. Three principal electrical utilities are currently operating in
Bangladesh: the BPDB, Dhaka Electricity Supply Authority (DESA), Dhaka Electric Supply Company
(DESCO) and the Rural Electrification Boards (REB). Although each of these utilities has similar
mandates, to supply power, the market and function of each utility is different. All three utilities are
regulated by the MEMR.
BPDB, established in 1972, is the largest of the four electrical utilities and is responsible for planning,
construction, and operation of power generation and transmission facilities throughout the Country,
except for Dhaka. As such, they operate most of the high voltage grid with sales accounting for
approximately 49% of the total direct electricity sales in Bangladesh.
In 1990, BPDB transferred the responsibility of power supply to DESA for the urban area of greater
Dhaka, including the Dhaka Metropolitan City. DESA does, however, still purchases power from the
BPDB. Today, DESA supplies approximately 450,000 direct end users, accounting for approximately
38.5% of electricity sales in the Country. However, the differing market mandates of each agency has
partially attributed to an overloaded, inefficient power supply system in and around the Dhaka area.
The REB, established in 1977, is responsible for the distribution of electricity in rural areas through a
system of co-operatives known as Palli Biddyut Samities (PBSs). REB purchases power from both
BPDB and DESA and serves about 2 million customers. REB accounts for approximately 12.5% of the
Country's electricity sales.
Collectively, these utilities had an electrical generation capacity of 3,300 MW with an annual output
>         capacity of 2,000 MW in 1997; a meager increase of roughly 200 MW since 1995 (Huda, 1999; Canadian
High Commission, 1995). The actual power output is currently in the range of 2500 MW to 2,700 MW.
The difference between generation capacity and output capacity is partly attributable to the fact that most
existing power plants are approaching or have exceeded their useful life and to system loss through the
illegal acquisition of power.
1.6 Natural Gas Pipeline
Titas will supply natural gas to the project site via a NPS 20 steel pipeline as per the terms and conditions
of the GSA. Only a small, spur pipeline is required totalling 400 metres in length. Gas to the MPSA will
mainly be supplied by the Titas and other gas fields located in the northern region of Bangladesh. The
country is producing gas at the rate around 1,000 mmscfd, which exceeds that the present rate of
consumption. The gas supply situation in Bangladesh has recently improved after the Jalabad gas field
was brought into production by Occidental of Bangladesh in 1999. Additionally, the offshore supply of
natural gas has increased from the Sangu gas field operated by Shell Bangladesh.
Gas to the project site will be transported through the Ashuganj-Bakhrabad and the Bakhrabad-Demra gas
pipelines. The Bakhrabad-Demra gas pipeline has a capacity of over 200 mmscfd. The daily gas
consumption of the project would be approximately 80 mmscf, which is much less than the total supply
capacity of the gas pipeline. As noted, Titas will build the 400 metre long interconnecting gas pipeline
through a local contractor, and the regulating and the metering station (RMS) by foreign contractors.
Funding would originate from Titas itself and/or the Government of Bangladesh. The RMS will, be
designed to handle a maximum gas delivery capacity of 125 mmscfd to provide for flexibility in the
system.

1.7 Project Alternatives Summary
This evaluation of alternatives, utilising data from various published reports, has resulted in the following
project-specific conclusions:
*  project site location - MPSA (Phase I) land leased from the BPDB;
*  project fuel resource - indigenous natural gas;
*  generation technology - combined cycle power;
*  mode of transportation - river and road transports for project materials;
*  electrical lines - PCGB to construct and maintain under ADB guidance and PSMP
recommendations; and
*  natural gas pipeline - Titas to construct and maintain independently pf this project.
A quantitative cost-benefit analyses was undertaken to further supplernent and refine the conclusions of
this qualitative review of altematives. The cost-benefit analysis is contained in Section 2.

2. Cost-Benefit Analyses
This cost-benefit analyses utilizes previously published data from Acres (1995) and Mott Ewbank Preece
(MEP) (1997). Where appropriate, these data have been refined to reflect the project-specific conditions
of the Project Sponsor's undertaking.
Review of the Acres and MEP reports, coupled with a exarnination of project-specific costs and benefits,
supports the alternative conclusions (Section 1) that the least-cost option for a new large thermal power
plant includes implementation of:
* Phase I of the MPSA;
*   indigenous natural gas; and
* combined cycle technology.
The following sections are provided in support of the above conclusions.

2.3   Project Benefits
Construction and operation of the power plant will also provide a number of local, regional, and national
benefits, including:
*   contribution of a reliable source of electrical power to the national grid, potentially reducing the need
for load-shedding by the BPDB consequently attracting additional foreign investment;
*   the efficiency of the CCGT, coupled with the use of indigenous natural gas fuel, will allow power to
be produced at the lowest rate in the World while rninimising harmful air emissions and creating
secondary jobs in the gas sector;
*  short-term employment of a large local work force during construction;
*   long-term employment for operations and maintenance personnel;
*   local and regional benefits associated with the procurement of domestic goods and services; and
*  direct foreign investment into Bangladesh and its power sector.
Where local or regional dis-benefits occur as a result of the is project, the Project Sponsor will apply
appropriate protective and mitigative measures and/or compensatory packages.
In addition to these benefits, the comparative evaluation of fossil fuelled power plants undertaken by
Acres (1995) indicates that combined cycle generation technology, while having a moderate installation
cost, provides the highest thermal efficiency. Further, corribined cycle technology offers a wider operating
range (i.e., annual duty) when compared to other fossil power plants (Table 5).

2.4 Cost-Benefit Summary
Review of the identifiable project costs reveals that least-cost alternatives (e.g., combined cycle
generation technology fuelled with indigenous natural gas), also have fewer adverse environmental
effects when compared to other large fossil fuelled power plants. The analyses further indicates that
construction of a CCGT power plant at the MPSA will have positive benefits for local and regional
economies while contributing a reliable power source to the national grid. Should local dis-benefits
occur, the Project Sponsor will undertake the appropriate steps to reduce and/or alleviate the identified
adverse impacts.

With regard to the above subject and reference, the undersigned is directed to inforn you
utt. permission/license is hereby given, as per the rules of this authority and subject to
compliance wih the following conditions, to construct a purca Jetty measuring 40 meter x 20
meter and to use a foreshore land measuring 200 meter x 40 meter In Char Ramjanpur
Sunaulah Mouza (at the place shown in the design) of Sonergeon Thena under Narayangar4
Port:
Conditions:
I . The perrnission/license will be valid for a period startiag from June 2000 to July 2001 and
the license has to be renewed every year after expiry as per the rules of the aulhority.
2. A pucce jetty of 40 meter x 20 meter will be built at the place shown in the design and no
more than a foreshore land of 200 meter x 40 meter = 8,000 square meters can be used.
3. A wharf will be constructed extending 40 (forty) meters toward the river f*tm the
permanent river bank. Moreover, the intake and outfall structures will be built at the
places marked In the design. Only the outfall discharge point will be constructed 32 meter
torward the river from the high water bank.
4. No other structure can be built In any other place except the one proposed and no extra
foreshore land can be used. To ensure the normal river flow, the foreshore land of the
river can not be reclaimed.
5. During the construction and use of the jetty, the river traffic cannot be disturbed and no
obstruction can be caused to the river traMfic In front of the jetty.
6. The applicant will have to pay duties as set by the authority.

Reference:  Lease! Licenses for Use of Foreshore Land for Construction of
Unloading Wharf for Barges and Other Infrastructures on
Meghna River
Dear Sir:
We are pleased to inform that AES Meghnaghat Limited ("AESM") entered into an
Implementation Agreement with the Government of Bangladesh ("GOB") on July
29, 1999 for the development of Meghnaghat 450 MW Combined Cycle Power
Plant (the "Project") on a Build Own and Operate basis. The site for the Project is
located at Char Ramjan Sonaullah Mouza under Sonargaon Thana of the
Narayanganj District on the northem bank of the river Meghna.
In order to construct and operate the power plant, it is essential for us to use the
foreshore of the river for the construction of an Unloading Wharf and other
77,re tP0cw;r      infrastructures. The Wharf will be used for unloading the machinery and other
equipment for the Project. The location of the wharf shown in the provisional
construction plan may change when the design is finalized.
A Water Intake Structure will be built to withdraw necessary water from the Meghna
River mainly for use as cooling water for the plant, which will be circulated back to
river at a point downstream through an Outfall Structure. Both the Intake and Outfall
Structures will be constructed within the Project premise and will be connected to
N=<z\-          the river through canals. However, the Outfall Structure will have an erosion
protection structure that will extend 32 meters inside the river from the high river
'bank.
As part of the requirement, we are enclosing the following attachments:
1. Provisional Site Layout (General Arrangement)  (Fig. 1.A)
*  Construction Plan of Unloading Wharf        (Fig. L.B)
*  Construction Plan of Intake Structure        (Fig. I.C)
*  Construction Plan of Outfall Structure      (Fig. L.D)
\._   A%\4&f   *  Site Plan                                       (Fig. 2)
*  Hydrographic Chart                          (Fig. 3)
*  Mouza Map                                    (Fig. 4)
-2. Money Receipt for the Application Form
.    



We, therefore, request you for lease / license for a period of three years for an area
of total length of 200 meters along the shoreline for the construction of the above
mentioned structures.
If you have any questions, please call Enamul Latifi, Project Manager or myself at
913-2361.
Thank you.
Yours sincerely,
Scott Kicker

Nature and type of Project    A 450 Mega Watt (MW) combined cycle gas turbine (CCGT) power plant,
and supporting facilities. The major components of the power plant will
consist of two gas turbine generators, two heat recovery steam generators,
one steam turbine generator, a distributed control system with mechanical
and electrical support systems, one extra high voltage switch yard, and
pumps.

Master Specitcation
vapour and at a constant pressure of 14.73 psi and under standard gravitational force
(acceleration 32.174 feet per second squared) with air of the same temperature and pressure
as the Gas, when the products of combustion are cooled to the initial temperature of the Gas
and air and when formed by combustion is condensed to the liquid state. The heating value
so determined shall be corrected from the conditions of testing to that of the actual condition
of the Gas as delivered (including the conversion from saturated to actual water vapour
conditions) expressed in Btu per SCF.
Btu means British thermal unit, defined as the quantity of heat required to raise the
temperature of one (1) pound of pure water from fifty eight and one-half degrees Fahrenheit
(58.5F) to fifty nine and one-half degrees Fahrenheit (59.5F) at a constant pressure of
fourteen and seventy three hundredths (14.73) psia.
1.3   ENVIRONMENTAL CRITERIA
The Plant shall conform with the requirements of the Environmental Impact Assessment (EIA)
prepared by the Employer, Govemment of Bangladesh and World Bank Environmental
Guidelines which are in effect at the time of signing the EPC Contract.
1.3.1  Air Emissions
Stack Height: 2 60 m (stack height shall not be less than 60 m above grade)
J                The Plant shall be demonstrated to be capable of complying with the air emission criteria as
outlined in Table 6
TALE 6 - AntEwM=otfOCwnim
Pollutant                   100% MCR
INOx                                  25  ppmv
CO                                   50  mg/Nm'
CO2                              34,350  ppmv
Particulate (PM1 0)                  50  mg/Nma
Notes:
(a) ppmv is defined as parts per million by volume at 15 percent oxygen dry at 320C, 85%
relative humidity, 1.013 bar.
(b) The proposed guaranteed value for NOx emission level is based on site conditions of
32C ambient temperature, 85% humidity.
(c) Values given are related to 3% excess 02 in dry exhaust gas, where Nm3 = 1 m3 at
l                   1.01 325 bar, dry, 0C.
(d) Corrections shall be allowed for ambient temperature and Gas composition based on
correction curves provided by the Gas Turbine supplier.
The stack shall be provided with safe access to sampling points for continuous emissions
monitoring. rontinuous emissions monitoring (CEM) equipment is required for the
measurement of air emission levels in the exhaust stacks of both HRSGs.
The sampling points for the continuous emissions monitoring equipment shall be provided on
the stack.
All necessary equipment to meet the guaranteed NOx emission limits shall be included.
The Gas vent stack shall be at a height sufficient to ensure that the concentration of Gas at
ground level is significantly less than the explosive limit and that the odour of Gas cannot be
detected.



Master Specification
The vent from the lubricating oil tank shall be fitted with coalescers or electrostatic
precipitators.
1.3.2  Noise Emissions
The Plant is located in a primarily industrial area; however, commercial and residential land
uses are scattered amidst the existing industrial facilities. The Plant shall be demonstrated to
be capable of complying with the noise emission criteria specified in Table 7,and shall meet,
at the nearest residence, the more restrictive of the Bangladesh DOE or World Bank
guidelines.
TABE7?- NozsrE EMSON CBTNA_
Location             Daytime Noise Level        Night-time Noise Level
Limitation (dB(A))          Limitation (dB(A))
Plant Boundary                  70                          60
Nearest Residence                55                           45
Equipment                     85                          85
(1 meter from source) I_I
The Gas Turbines shall have noise attenuation. As a minimum air intake silencer are is
required and acouftic insulat9n added around to comply with the nosemission ctea in
Table 7. 
Noise levels within the Steam Turbine building shall be less than 85 dB(A).
The Central Control Room shall have sufficient sound insulation to ensure a sound level
below 55 dB(A) when the Plant is operating at MCR.
To ensure that the background noise criteria level for any room adjacent to a noise source
greater than 55 dB (A) does not exceed the values as set out it is essential that the building
wall, floor and ceiling elements are designed with the required sound reduction performance.
In this respect not only must the materials used in construction be adequate but the design
must ensure that noise is prevented from flanking at the junctions of walls to floor, walls to
ceiling, and through doors or access to the adjacent rooms.
Noise levels in any area in which an operator may be continuously exposed shall be less than
85 dB(A).
All above ground piping outside buildings shall be acoustically insulated as necessary to
reduce the sound power level from the piping to a value that can be neglected in comparison
with the other Plant noise sources.
The specified noise criteria shall be met under all operating conditions including Start-up,
Shutdown, normal operation and lifting of safety, relief and vent valves. An exceedance of the
Noise limitations will only be allowed during bypass operation (limited to 100 decibels) and
emergency operating conditions where physical damage to the Plant or physical harm to an
individual may result, this shall include the lifting of safety relief valves.
All single frequencies generated (including transformers) may be significant and require
abatement. The Contractor shall ensure that this is included in the noise assessment.
All Plant shall run without undue vibration and with the least practicable amount of noise in all
modes of operation.
Waming notices shall be provided at all entrances to rooms where the noise level may exceed
75 dB(A).
During the term of the Contract, the Contractor shall submit to the Employer interim noise
reports to demonstrate that the specified noise limits will be met. These will include
1-11



Master Specirication
equipment noise levels, details of noise control measures and preliminary calculations for
environmental and in Plant noise.
A final noise report shall be submitted to the Employer when sufficient definitive equipment
noise data is available. This report shall include but not be limited to the following:
a) All equipment suppliers' noise guarantees and supporting data.
b) Test reports for all equipment noise tests.
c)  Details of all noise control measures.
!d) Calculations of in-Plant and environmental noise level to demonstrate compliance with
the specified limits.
Noise during the construction phase of the project when measured at nearby residences or
communities under neutral weather conditions shall not normally exceed the sound levels
specifed in. (MEF Guidelines for Mixed Use Areas - predominately residential areas mixed
with commercial and industrial use):
TABLE 8 - MAUmmf NOIEYLE  ArCLOSESTRIMZZENC

Night            2100 - 0600 hours                45
Construction work during the hours of 2100 and 0600 on weekdays will be to the approval of
the local authority.
1.3.3  Aqueous Emissions
The cooling water and all other effluents shall discharge to the Meghna River.
Bangladesh maximum allowable river water temperature:  40C
Maximum allowable cooling water temperature rise:      5.5C
A differential temperature of 30C between the circulation water inlet and the point 100 meters
downstream of the outfall shall not be exceeded
The cooling water discharge shall be continuously monitored for temperature.
Rain and surface water from the Site shall be discharged via two 'Hume" type pipes to the
Meghna River.
Plant wastewater and all effluents shall be treated to comply with the effluent discharge limit
criteria as outlined in and discharged to the Meghna River.

Sub:  No Objection Certificate for use of Water from Meghna River for the 450 MW Power project of

Ref:   Your letter Dated September, 28,1999.
Dear Sir,
Kindly refer to your letter under reference regarding issuing of No Objection Certificate for use of
Water from Meghna River for the 450 MW Power Project of AES Meghnaghat Limited.
Bangladesh Water Development Board does not have objection to the above noted proposal for use
of Water from Meghna River for 450 MW Power Project of AES Meghnaghat Limited subject to complying with
the following terms and conditons:
1)    All necessary intake and discharge infrastructures and mechanism are to be built by the
company so as to avoid any bank erosion, bed-scouring etc.
2)    The above infrastructures will not create any obstructions on river transportation and negative
)                 impact on the river bed, river bank and river flow.
3)    It must be ensured that this withdrawal and discharge of the water will not create any negative
impact on environment on Hydrauliq'Morphological characteristics of the river.
4)    Clearance in respect to Environmental Management is to be obtained by the AES
Meghnaghat Limited from the Directorate of Environment, Govemment of the People's
Republic of Bangladesh.
5)    Violation of any of the above conditions shall render this clearance void.
Sincerely Yours,
(G.A.  a )

INTRODUCTION
It is accepted that industrial development contributes to economic growth, but now it is
universally recognized that it brings along with it a host of environmental problems. In
Bangladesh where the density of population is one of the highest in the world, the impact of
environmental degradation will be significantly more compared to other less densely populated
areas of the world.
The need to create more jobs and raise productivity through industrialization in order to
alleviate poverty is essential for less developed countries like Bangladesh but it is equally vital
that the environment or the eco-system is conserved.
In Bangladesh whatever industrialization has taken place, due attention to the environmental
aspect was not given. In the wake of further industrialization by local entrepreneurs, joint
ventures and Direct Foreign Investment, the environmental issues can not remain
unaddressed.
Therefore, time has come to choose the path whereby degradation of the environment is
mninimized and at the same time the process of industrialization can continue by giving
emphasis on choice of technology, internal and external economics of production and extent of
environmental impact and its mitigation.
Recognizing the changed circumstances and the potential degradation of the environment, the
GOB found it necessary to upgrade the Environmental Pollution Control Ordinance 1977. The
Environmental Conservation Act was passed by the Parliament in February 1995 and came
into force in June 1995 repealing the Environmental Pollution Ordinance Act 1977.
In order to enforce the Act, rules and regulations were required. The Ministry of Environment
and Forest under GOB in a gazette notification published the Environmental Conservation
Rules in August 1997. The rules specify the powers and functions of the DOE and the
responsibilities of industries to ensure conservation of the Eco-system.
The World Bank commissioned BCAS to translate the Act and the Rules and prepare a
guideline with a view to enable industry to have quick access to the requirements of the
Environmental Conservation Act '95 and the Environmental Conservation Rules '97, a
question and answer format is used to make it as user friendly as possible.
A brief description of waste and waste management and aspects of Initial Environment
Examination (IEE), Environment Impact Assessment (EIA), Environment Management Plan
(EMP), and Environmental Management System (EMS) have been covered for appraising
industries of the terminologies used by environmentalists and in the laws on environment.

Vehicles exceediing the standards given in schedules 6 and 7 shall be considered harmful
environment or injurious to health.
5.   Application Concerning Environment Pollution or Deterioration
(1) Vide clause 8 (1) of the Act, any person affected or likely to be affected by determJ
of environmental pollution shall apply for remedy and damage or apprehend damag(
the Director General in the format as per forrn 1.
(2) On receiving the application as per Sub-clause (1), the Director General shall settle
same vide Clause 8 (2) of the Act within three months.
6.   Notice for Sample Collection

of the site in the format as per ferm 2.
7.   Procedure for Granting Environmental Clearance
(1) For the purpose of granting Environmental clearance certificate, industrial units
projects has been divided into four categories depending upon environmental impaci
location:
(a) Green
(b) Orange A



Environment Conservation Rules, 1997   49
(c) Orange B, and
(d) Red.
(2)The lists of industries and projects mentioned in Sub-clause (1) are given in schedule 1.
(3) All existing industrial units and projects as well as proposed industrial units and projects
of Green category shall be granted Environmental Clearance.
(4) For proposed industries units and projects of Orange A, Orange B and Red categories at
first Location Clearance and thereafter Environmental Clearance shall be given. It is
also provided that, upon application by an industrial unit or project, if the Director
General feels proper, he/she may grant Environmental Clearance to the same directly
without first giving Location Clearance.
(5) The sponsor of the industrial unit or project with payment of required fees described in
schedule 13, shall apply in the format as per in Form 3 to the relevant Divisional officer
for Environmental Clearance.

(a) For Green Category

(iii) No Objection Certificate from the local authority.
(iv) Process Flow Diagram.
(v) Layout Plan (showing Effluent Treatment Plant).
(vi) Waste discharge arrangement.
(vii) Outline of relocation or rehabilitation plan (where applicable).
(viii) Other necessary information (where applicable).

Diagram, Layout Plan (showing location of Effluent Treatment Plant (ETP),
diagram of ETP.

of the industrial unit or project, Layout Plan (showing location of ETP), diagram

A category, and orange B and Red category or the application will be turned down giving
reasons.

programme.

project of Orange A and Orange B category only).

without Environmental Clearance and shall not be able to start trial production in
case of industrial unit and operation in other cases (applicable for industrial units
and project of Orange A and Orange B category only).

(10) Upon receiving of application vide Sub-clause 9 (iii), Environmental Clearance shall be
granted to the sponsor within 15 and 30 working days for industrial unit and project of

working days for existing industrial unit and project of Orange A, and Orange B and Red
Category respectively; or the application will be turned down giving reasons.
B.   Validity of Environmental Clearance
(1) The validity of Environmental Clearance shall be 3 years for green category and 1 year
for other categories from the date of issue.
(2)Every Environmental Clearance must be renewed 30 days before expiry date of the
certificate.
9.   Appeal
(1) Reasons of objection must be stated clearly as well as briefly to appeal file under Clause
14 of the Act against any notice, order or direction.
(2) Each appeal must be accompanied by the following documents:
(a) An attested copy of the notice, order or direction against which appeal in filed.
(b) Copy of Environmental Clearance (if available).
(c) Treasury receipt showing proof of deposit of appeal fee of Tk. 1000.
(d) Any other paper relevant to the appeal.



ErLviroLrinent Conseroation Rules, 1997   53
14. Environmental Clearance/Renewal fees
Environmental Clearance or Renewal fees under these Rules shall be payable as described in
schedule 13.
15. Other services and their fees
(1) Upon application by any person or organization the Department will analyse sample
of water, liquid waste, air and noise, and supply data and information from such
analyses.
(2) Appropriate fees described in Schedule 14 shall be payable for services vide Sub-
clause (1).
16. Procedure of payment of fees
All fees payable under these rules must be deposited Bangladesh Bank vide Treasury Receipt
in "65 Miscellaneous Income, Non-Tax Revenue" in favour of the Director General, and the
Treasury Receipt must be attached with the application.
17. Informing Important Incidents
If environmental pollutant discharge or effluent exceed set standards in any place, or some
areas face threat on account of any accident or any unforeseen activity or occurrence, then the
affected or threatened inhabitants of the area will inform the Director General of the incident.

43            NATIONAL ENVIRONMENTAL POLICY
4.3.1        Introduction
In recent years, environmental management has assumed a higher priority in the political agenda of
Bangladesh due to the recognition of the environmental and natural resource pressure exerted by the
nation's growing population. As a result. the govemment has developed a detailed policy framework that
incorporates environmental considerations into all economic development planning. The key policy
docunents are listed below;
*  National Environmental Policy (1992)
*  National Environmental Management Action Plan (NEMAP), 1995.
* National Conservation Strateg,y. 1992
*  Fifth Five Year Plan (1997-2002)
I Environmental Gutidelinesfor lIndustries (Juine 1997)
Each of the above is briefly discussed in the following paragraphs, in relation to the proposed project.
.IS71 711/A                                 2-;                                 MottMacDonald
F                         &PDBNIOJEClS537IAWPREUMnSECCt\L.1; LPM                        o



4.3.2          National Environmental Policy
The Bangladesh National Environmental Policy (1992) establishes a framework for environmental action,
together with a broad set of sector-specific actions. Certain general objects are embodied:
*  The need to maintain the ecological balance and to aid development through the protection of the
environment
*  The need to protect the country from natural disasters
*  The need to identify and regulate all types of polluting industry
*  The need to ensure sustainabie utilisation of natural resources
*  The need to promote active association with all environment-related intemational initiatives.
The above objectives represent broad goals that do not specifically apply to industrial development. In
addition to these, the pollution potential of industry is recognised with additional "National Environmental
Policy Objectives". For instance, the Policy recognises the need to conduct Environmental Impact
Assessments for all new public and private industries. It also identifies the need to ensure sustainable use
of raw materials and natural resources.
Finally, the  Policy acknowledges that the Energy and Fuel Sector has significant potential for
environmental impact. In order to limnit such impacts, the government aims to reduce and discourage the
use of those fuels that pollute the environment with particular reference to firewood and agricultural
residues. By contrast, the policy encourages the use of renewable sources.
4S717101/A                                       '-4                                     Mot MacDonald
F:\DPROJECTS\457\  R.\11\ECO\.S.&P I



4.3.3         National Environmental Management Action Plan
The National Environmental Management Action Plan is a wide-ranging and multi-faceted plan that
expands upon the statements given in the National Environmental Policy. The Action Plan was developed
to address issues and management requirements during the period 1995 to 2005, and sets out a framework
within which the recommendations of the National Conservation Strategy are to be implemented.
Its broad objectives are as follows:
*  To identify the key environmental issues affecting Bangladesh
*  To identify actions necessary to halt or reduce the rate of environmental degradation
*  To improve the natural or built environment
*  To conserve habitats and biodiversity
*  To promote sustainable development
*  To improve peoples' quality of life.
In addition, the Action Plan also identifies environmental problems posed by the industrial sector. These
cover issues such as economic constraints on pollution abatement, and lack of incentives for pollution
control.
The plan recognises that unplanned development has resulted in high concentrations of industry adversely
effecting the local environment. In other instances, unplanned development has encroached on to/near to
residential or agricultural land with serious impacts on local people.
2.3.4         National Conservation Strategy
The National Conservation Strategy was submitted to the Government in early 1992. And has undergone
j)             a number of modifications in the years since then. Final approval is expected during 1998. [Is tJzis
statemenz up-to date ??f
The main focus of the strategy is to encourage sustainable development in the industrial sector. In order to
achieve this, strict control whould be placed upon the import of technologies and materials with
environmental significance.  Whilst the import of environmentally sound technology whould be
encouraged, it is recognised that complete dependence on imported technology is unlikely to encourage
environmental and economic sustainability. The strategy also states that hazardous or toxic wastes should
not be imported for use as raw materials.
4-3.3         Fifth Five Year Plan
The Fifth Five Year Plan (FFYP) was formally published in March 1998. It represents one of the most
important planning and policy documents of the government, because it covers all major sectors of
development and intervention.
Within this document, a separate chapter is devoted to 'environment and sustainable development'. This
chapter identifies the major environmental issues of the country. the areas of special concern, the need to
address pollution hotspots. the role of public and private sector co-operation, the level of Government-
NGO co-operation. and financial and disaster management issues. In terms of the goals and objectives. the
plaa calls for promotion of:
4S717/01IA                                    '5                                  Mott MacDonild
F \PDBROJECTI S54597\IA\PRELI.41)SECO.Mc 5:P,.I



a) sustainable environmental management in pursuit of a quality livelihood and to alleviate poverty;
b) participatory, community-based environmental resource management and environmental protection;
C) active participation of the poor, especially women, in environment protection activities;
d) environment-friendly activities in development interventions;
e) preservation. protection and development of the natural resource base;
f) capabilities in the public and private sectors to address environmental concerns;
g) control and prevention of environmental pollution and degradation related to soil, water and air;
h) public awareness for participation in environment promotion activities; and
i) conservation of non-renewable resources and sustaining auto and eco-generation of renewable
resources.
4A .          ENERGY AND POWER POLICIES
The need to develop a reliable system that supplies electricity at a reasonable cost and that overcomes the
country's chronic power shortages and its very low level of electrification, is well acknowledged in the the
govemment considerations of energy policy and the development of the industry in Bangladesh. The
current National Energy Policy was formulated in 1996 by a high level committee headed by the Energy
Secretary. Included amongst its objectives are the following environment-related aims:
-  To ensure sustainable operation of energy utilities
- To ensure rational use of total energy resources
*  To ensure environmentally sound sustainable development programmes causing the minimum damage
to the environment.
In addition to the general incentives offered to private investors in industry, the government has come to
recognise the role that private investment will necessarily have in the energy sector in terms of providing
the level of finance required to ensure that electricity demand is met. Therefore, it has introduced fiscal
incentives to encourage foreign investors into the power sector.
4.3            ENVIRONMENTAL LEGISLATION
4.5.1         Introduction
Althouch a considerable amount of legislation has been established in Bangladesh to (I) protect
environmental health; (ii) control environmental pollution, and (iii) conserve natural resources, only a
small proportion of this legislation will be of direct significance for the proposed project. The legislation
likely to be most important to the project is discussed below.
487170/ltA                                     2-6                                   Mott MacDonald
F.:PDB\FROJECTS597\EZA\PPRLEUMl\SEC04\Lcg LP&A,1



4-5.2         The Environmental Conservation Act, 1995
The Environmental Conservation Act, 1995 represents the principal legislative framework document'
relating to environmental protection in Bangladesh. It repealed the earlier Environmental Pollution Control
Ordnance of 1977.  The main objects of the Act are the conservation and improvement of the
environment; and control of environmental pollution by taking into account the following:
*  Declaration of ecologically critical areas, and restrictions on the processes which can be carried out in
the ecologically critical area
*  Regulation in respect of vehicles emitting smoke harmful for the environment
*  Regulation of the industries and other development activities using discharge permits
*  Promulgation of standards for quality of air, water, noise and soil for different areas and for different
purposes
*  Promulgation of standard limits for discharging and emitting waste
*  Formulation and declaration of environmental guidelines.
The Act is currently being implemented by the DOE who have wide ranging enforcement powers. For
.instance, the DOE has the authority to suspend industrial activities that are harmful to human life or the
environment. However, the operator has the right of appeal. In instances where environmental damage is
atributable to a particular source, the DOE can insist upon rectifying arrangements by the polluter.
The Act also requires that project Sponsors secure environmental clearance from the Director General of
the DOE, prior to construction. The environmental clearance procedure is described in the following sub-
sections.
Z43I3          Environment Conservation Rules 1997
These represent the first rules. promulgated under the Environment Conservation Act 1995 and establish
a) the National Environmental Quality Standards for ambient air, atmospheric emissions, water, industrial
effluent and noise- and b) the procedures for preparation of an Environmental Impact Assessment and an
Initial Environmental Evaluation and for securing Environmental Clearance.
4.5.4         EIA Guidelines for Industry 1997
The DOE have developed a set of guidelines for carrying out Environmental Impact Assessments. as a
result of the project entitled " To Develop and Apply Sector-wise Industrial Guidelines and Standards and
Standards and to Monitor Compliance".  The guidelines explain the environmental and planning
requirements for developers and highlight the requirements of the Environmental Conservation Act.
4.6            ENVIRONMENTAL STANDARDS
4.6.1         Introduction
As described above, the appropriate national environmental standards are those applied under the
Environmental Conservation Rules, 1997. No specific requirements for the power sector currently exist in
Bangladesh, but they are being prepared (Ensture this statemnent is up-to-datel
4S'71710)lA                                   2-7                                   MolN MacDonald
F .UDFTRO1ECT\5T97%EAV REUMISEC\>Ig.P.'I



However, because financing for the proposed project is likely to be sought from the World Bank, via
IDCOL. it is important that the scheme also satisfies the appropriate World Bank/IDCOL environmental
criteria for approval of funding.
4.6-2          National Environmental Quality Standards
The National Environmental Quality Standards, conmnonly referred to as the environmental quality
standards, are legally binding across a range of industries.  In addition to these general industrial
standards, the DOE also apply a number of sector-specific ones, covering the following industries;
fertiliser, tannery, integrated textile, food and cement. However, no specific power project standards exist.
The general emission standards have particular reference to oxides of nitrogen in relation to gas based
power plants of different capacities; and to sulphur dioxide emissions, but only from coal fired power
stations. The appropriate Environmental Quality Standards are given at the end of this section.

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY
1.   Infrastructure Development Company (IDC), Bangladesh. has been established by the
Government of Bangladesh (GOB) as a Company under the Companies Act to facilitate private
investment in infrastructure development. Using credit made available to the Govemrnment of
Bangladesh by the International Development Agency (IDA), IDC will provide part financial
support to private investors in the power, gas, telecommunications, port, water, waste
management and the highway sector. Private project sponsors are expected to raise at least 60
percent of the required financing in the form of equity and commercial debt.
2.    The Environmental and Social Framework (ESF) has been designed by GOB to provide
IDC with an overall framework to guide the identification, preparation, appraisal and
implementation of environmental and social concerns at the project and at the organizational
level. The ESF reflects the environmental and social guidelines and standards of IDA, since such
guidelines and standards for infrastructure projects in Bangladesh are yet to be developed.
3.    The ESF was prepared, on behalf of the GOB, by the Bangladesh Centre for Advanced
Studies. a leading non-governmental organization active in environmental and social issues. The
report was prepared with desk research on legal and institutional framework, analysis of priority
issues in the infrastructure sector, requirements of the operational directives of the World Bank
Group, and best practice lessons from countries such as India and Sri Lanka. There have been
discussions with NGOs and other interested parties during the preparation of this report.
s    Environmental and Social Policy of IDC
4.    The environmental and social policy of IDC is enshrined in three cardinal principles:
(a)   Enhance the quality of life and environment in and around project locations;
(b)   Prevent adverse environmental and social impacts; and
(c)   Mitizate possible adverse environmental and social impacts.
Environmental and Social Assessment Process
5.    The Environmental and Social Assessment for IDC has been designed taking the
following factors into consideration:
(a)   The legal and institutional setting, and the requirements of the Govemment of
Bangladesh agencies;
(b)   Major environmental and social issues that could be expected in projects to be
financed by IDC;
(c)   IDC's project cycle;
iv



(d)      Requirements of the World Bank's Operational Directives:
(i)     OD 4.01 on Environmental Assessment;
(ii)     OD 4.30 on Involuntary Resettlement; and
(iii)     OD 4.20 on Indigenous People
The Environmental and Social Assessment Process is outlined in Table 1. These procedures will
dovetail with the project cycle of IDC. Once the details of the IDC project cycle have been filly
developed. the Environmental and Social Assessment Process will need more definition. The
ESF should be viewed as a dynamic document that should be periodically reviewed to ensure
that it reflects changes in business practices of IDC and the external environment.

7.      The   ESF   framework   incorporates   measures   for  environmental  and   social  risk
identification, assessment, allocation and management during different stages of the project cycle
as part of the Environmental and Social Assessment Process.
IDC - IDA Interface
8.      In order to ensure that IDC's infrastructure projects are in conformity with IDA's OD
requirements and business practices, it shall submit the following documents for IDA review.
Table 3 outlines the institutional interface matrix. IDA concurrence to the outputs generated at
each stage will be obtained prior to proceeding to the next stage.

Organizational Support
9.    IDC shall establish an institutional structure capable of implementing the provisions of
the ESF. IDC shall:
(a)   Integrate the Environmental and Social Assessment process with the [DC project
cycle;
(b)   Ensure that the Investment Manager's Unit, established in IDC. has the capability
to undertake the tasks outlined in the ESF; and
(c)   Appoint consultants, as necessary, to undertake special assignments with respect
to environmental and social issues.
10.   In order to facilitate the conduct of these tasks:
(a)   IDC's Investment Manager will be the operational manager with overall
responsibility for implementing the provisions of this ESF:
(b)   IDC will initially engage consultants for implementing the different stages of the
Environmental and Social Assessment process.  In due course, if sufficient
number of projects are forthcoming. IDC shall build in-house capacity to address
the process on an ongoing basis: and
(c)   Increase awareness among all departments /staff of [DC regarding the importance
of addressing environmental and social issues through integration with the project
cycle.

CHAPTER I
PURPOSE OF THE ENVIRONMENT AND SOCIAL FRAMEWORK
Background
1.1   The Infrastructure Development Company (IDC) is a Government Owned Company
established by the Govemment of Bangladesh to promote private investment in infrastructure
development. IDC is being established through the IDA-assisted Private Sector Infrastructure
Development Project (PSIDP).
1.2   The PSIDP will have a mix of technical assistance and lending. Technical assistance will
assist the Government to develop enabling policies and regulation in the power, gas,
telecommunications, port, water, waste management, and highway sector.  The lending
component will address project financing through the provision of long-term subordinate debt
financing through the IDC. The IDC shall contract an Investment Manager (IM) to carry out the
sub-project evaluation, negotiation, recommendation for approval, implementation monitoring,
and supervision on behalf of IDC.
Purpose of the Environment and Social Framework
1.3   The Environment and Social Framework (ESF) is the core policy document on
environment and social issues for the IDC and outlines the operating procedures for addressing
environment and social issues associated with sub-sector projects. The main purpose of the ESF
is to provide IDC with an overall framework to guide in the identification, preparation, appraisal
and implementation of environmental and social concems at the project and at the organizational
level.
1.4   As the executing agency for the PSIDP. IDC will ensure that the contractual framework
for each project complies with the provisions of the ESF prior to obtaining approval of its Board
for financing the project.
1.5   As a detailed guide on principles and procedures for incorporating environmental and
social issues into project preparation, the ESF would be a useful reference to potential project
sponsors and other financing agencies likely to participate in future IDC operations.
Users of the ESF
1.6   As a core policy and procedural document for the IDC. the ESF is designed for use by the
following actors:
(a)   IDC staff: as a document enshrining operating principles and guidelines to ensure
that projects are adequately assessed to ensure compliance with environmental       )
and social standards;
I



(b)   Project sponsor: as a document that spells out requirements with respect to
environmental and social issues that need be met for financing from IDC; and
(c)    Proiect associates (other shareholders, consultants, lenders, etc.): as a document
that explains the compliance requirements for environmental and social
requirements for projects that receive financing from IDC.
(d)   Other relevant government agencies. including DOE for reference.
Structure of the Report
1.7   The ESF is divided into eight Chapters.
*  Chapter 1 explains the purpose of preparing the ESF;
*  Chapter 2 summarizes the environmental and social principles which constitute IDC's
Policy on these issues;
*  Chapter 3 outlines the Legal and Institutional setting of implementation of
environmental and social mitigation plans in Bangladesh and provides the legal basis
for establishing the environmental and social standards/guidelines proposed in the
ESF;
a  Chapter 4 briefly describes some of the major environmental and social issues that
could be expected in the priority infrastructure sub-sectors;
*  Chapter 5 describes the procedural framework for processing candidate projects with
respect to environmental and social issues. including preparation of the
Environmental and Social Assessment Report:
*  Chapter 6 explains the interface between IDC and IDA at various stages of the project
cycle;
*  Chapter 7 outlines the environmental and social risk management in IDC;
*  Chapter 8 describes the institutional structure for facilitating compliance with ESF
provisions.
Preparation of the ESF
I.8   The ESF was prepared by the Bangladesh Centre for Advanced Studies (BCAS). a
leading NGO in Bangladesh. for the Infrastructure Development Company (IDC). The policy and
2



operating procedure outlined in this report will be reviewed after a year. and if necessary,
revised, based on experience with implementation.
1.9   The report was prepared with desk research on legal and institutional framework, analysis
of priority issues in the infrastructure sector, checks with the operational directives and
guidelines of IDA, discussions with NGOs and relevant government agencies.
1.10 The ESF has been formally approved and adopted by the Board of Directors of IDC.

CHAPTER 2
ENVIRONMENTAL & SOCIAL POLICY OF INFRASTRUCTURE DEVELOPMENT
COMPANY
.1   Infrastructure Development Company is committed to promoting private participation in
infrastructure development in Bangladesh with the understanding that promoting environmental
protection and social development is an integral part of the corporate mission. Environmental
and social issues will be handled through a consultative process integral to IDC operations, along
with policies and procedures which facilitate sustainable development.
2.2    The environmental and social statement of IDC is embodied in the following principles.
(a)    Enhance the quality of life and environment in and around project locations, by:
(i)    conserving and protecting natural resources: and
(ii)    addressing the legitimate concems of relevant stakeholders. especially the
project affected persons.'
(b)    Prevent adverse environmental and social impacts, by
(i)    minimizing the release of pollutants into the environment;
(ii)    reducing pressure on natural resources towards preserving biological
diversity and ecological equilibrium
(iii)    avoiding  or minimizing  land  acquisition  and  resettlement through
appropriate location and design of projects.
(iv)    ensuring protection of vulnerable groups, such as the economically and
socially disadvantaged. women, children. physically handicapped and
indigenous people.
(v)    minimizing health and safety hazards.
(c)    Mitigate possible adverse environmental and social impacts by
(i)   integrating   waste   management  measures  and   maintaining  the
environmental quality of project locations.
(ii)    ensuring that the standards of living and income levels of project affected
persons are improved, or at least restored after project implementation.
This would be facilitated by participatorv resettlement and appropriate
economic rehabilitation of project affected persons.
For the IDC. Project Affected Persons (PAPs) are defined as- all persons. residing in. cultivating or carryin, out
economic activities within the areas required for the project. prior to a formallv recognized cut off date"
4



CHAPTER 3
LEGAL AND INSTITUTIONAL SETTING
3.1   The institutional and legal setting in Bangladesh provides the context in which the
environment and social assessment procedure for IDC is developed. It is imperative that IDC
financed projects be aware of and respond to the legal and institutional requirements of
Bangladesh.
Environmental Aspects
Constitutional Provisions
3.2   Rights to life, personal liberty and property are enshrined in article 31 and article 32 of
the Bangladesh Constitution, 1972, as fundamental rights. Such provisions exist in many
national constitutions of the world. In India, for example. the right to "life" has been interpreted
by the Supreme Court of India to include, inter-alia, the right to a decent environment to sustain
life with dignity. It is presumed that in an appropriate case dealing with environmental matters,
the Supreme Court of Bangladesh may resolve to make a similar interpretation of right to life,
and if this is done so, then a gross deprivation of the standard environrmental condition would be
endorsed by the said Court under its extraordinary jurisdiction (Art. 102) as a fundamental right.
In a recent High Court ruling, it has been established that well known Non-Govermnental
Organizations can lodge com'plaint in a court of law in case of interference with any public
interest This was endorsed by High Courts Extraordinary Jurisdiction provided in Art. 102 of
the Constitution.
Environmental Legislation
3.3   The umbrella legislation is the Bangladesh Environment Conservation Act. 1995 (refer to
Annex I for an unofficial English translation). This Act of 1995 was developed on the earlier
Environment Pollution Control Ordinance, 1977, and came into force on June 5. 1995. through a
notification of the Ministry of Environment and Forests (dated May 31, 1995). However, a total
of 23 laws have been identified which contain provisions regarding conservation of environment
and control of pollution from various sources. For example, the Penal Code, enacted as early as
1860. has provisions to check pollution to the atmosphere: the Fish Conservation Act. 1950.
provides for measures to ensure undisturbed spawning grounds; the Bangladesh Wildlife
(Preservation) Order. 1973, prohibits certain dealings with specified species of wildlife. etc.
Table 3.1 lists some of the major legislation which regulate environment in Bangladesh.

Major International Conventions, Treaties and Protocols (ICPTs)
3.5     There are a number of ICPTs in the field of environment, dating back to as early as 1933.
Not all of them have the same significance or relevance for Bangladesh. A list of the ICPTs that
have relevance to Bangladesh are listed in Annex 2. IDC will strive to be current on the
evolving climate of intemational agreements, and implications for projects to be financed.
Regulatory and Institutional Framework
3.6    In 1989, the Ministry of Environment and Forest was established to address the emerging
environment related issues. In 1995, the Bangladesh Environment Conservation Act (BECA) was
enacted, the Department of Environment (DOE) was established, and the Director-General
(DOE) empowered to undertake activities for the "conservation of environment,.development of
environmental standards, and environmental pollution control and reduction which may be
appropriate and necessary under the provisions of the Act". The DOE is operational. though the
complete organizational structure is yet to be established. However, several line Ministries have
legal and regulatory power related to the Environment as shown in Table 3.3
