3.7   The National Environmental Policy of 1992, provides policy guidance for environmental
protection and preservation. In 1992, the National Conservation Strategy was drafted, and in
1995. a National Environmental Management Action Plan (NEMAP) was prepared.  The
National Environmental Policy Statement underscores the emphasis on maintaining a balance
between development and conservation of the environment and natural resources:
*     Maintenance of ecological balance along with overall progress and development
of the country;
*     Protection of the country against natural disasters;
*     Identification and control of all types of activities leading to pollution and
degradation of the environment;
*     Environmentally-sound development in all sectors.
*     Sustainable, long-term and environmental congenial utilization of all natural
resources, and
*     Active association with all environment-related international initiatives.
Rules, Guidelines and Standards
3.8   Rules, guidelines and Environmental Quality Standards (EQS) in different sectors are
being framed. Some sectors such as water, rural infrastructure development, etc. developed
environmental assessment guidelines before the Bangladesh Environment Conservation Act of
1995 was enacted. However, since the enactment of the BECA, all development projects fall
under its umbrella. Under section 20 of the BECA, the DOE/MOEF is mandated to formulate
the regulatory framework, rules, procedures and EQS. To date, guidelines for Environmental
Assessment in the Industrial Sector (discussed elsewhere in the Report) and a draft EQS for the
industrial sector have been developed.
3.9   The DOE has formulated the draft environmental quality standards for the industrial
sector comprised of the following.
*  water quality standards
  treated sewage standards
*  industrial effluent standards
*  ambient air quality standards
*  air emissions standards
*  motor vehicle exhaust emission standards. and
*  noise standards.
The proposed EQS for Bangladesh and a comparison with other countries in the Region is shown
in Annex 3. Surface waters are classified into seven categories of beneficial use: (1) drinking
water source: (ii) recreational, (iii) fishery; (iv) industrial;  (v) irrigation:  (vi) livestock
watering; and (vii) coastal waters. Three sets of general effluent standards have been specified in
the draft EQS -- for discharge to inland surface waters. discharge to sewers connected to effluent
10



treatment plants, and discharge onto land for irrigation. The draft EQS proposes four sets of
ambient air quality standards to be applied to the following areas:
Category                                    Type of Land Use
A                                           Industrial and mixed use
B                                           Commercial and mixed use
C                                           Residential and rural
D                                           Sensitive areas
Environmental Assessment Process in Bangladesh
3.10  The BECA, 1995, stipulates that "no industrial unit or project shall be established or
undertaken without obtaining environmental clearance from the Director General (DG),
Department of Environment (DOE) in the manner prescribed by the Rules. Further, the Act has
bestowed DOE with the rule-making power vide section 20 of the Act; clause (2) (f) of this
section requires that rules be made to " evaluate. review the environmental impact assessment
(EIA) of various projects and activities and procedures be established for approval". These Rules
are expected to be promulgated vide government notification, following completion of the
preparation of industrial guidelines, and will describe the procedure to be followed to obtain
environmental clearance. According to the guidelines, the project proponent is responsible for
preparing the EIA, either with in-house resources or by employing the services of a consultant.
3.11   There are slightly different procedures for industrial projects, and projects in other
sectors. The EIA procedure for industrial projects consists of three stages: (I) screening; (ii)
initial environmental examination (IEE); and (iii) detailed examination. The EIA Process for
Industrial Projects is described in Annex 4.
3.12   Currently, for non-industrial projects. either EIA's are done by the project sponsor and
then sent to the DOE for environmental clearance by the sectoral line agencies of the
govemment. or sometimes project proposals are sent by the line agencies to the DOE for
environmental clearance without an EA. In both cases. DOE reviews the projects and conducts
environmental screening and decides whether the projects require an Initial Environmental
Examination (IEE) or an EIA, or no EIA. For reviewing both industrial and non-industrial
projects and providing environmental and site clearance, the DOE has constituted a technical
committee chaired by the Director (Technical), and comprised of Deputy Director
(Enforcement). Deputy Director (Research), Joint Director (Biodiversity) and Project
Coordinator. For the non industrial sector project there is no clear cut guideline for preparation.
and review of environmental assessments. Thus the procedure followed by the DOE for giving
environmental clearance of the projects in the non industrial sectors is still very much on adhoc
basis. In practice. committee uses the draft industrial sector guidelines and guidelines of some
many multilateral institutions as guidance while reviewing the non industrial sector projects.
though there is no executive order of the government to do so.
It may be mentioned here that in some sectoral EA guidelines are being prepared such as gas and
oil sector. inland water transport, etc. However, in many of the sectors, EA guidelines are yet to
ll



be developed. It may be recommended that in absence of any sectoral guidelines, the DOE
should make one environmental clearance procedure for the non industrial sector, by combining
J )    the EA  guidelines of the World Bank. Asian Development Bank, etc., until guidelines in other
sectors are prepared.
World Bank Operational Directive on the Environment
3.13    The World Bank's Operational Directive 4.01 (OD  4.01) outlines policy and procedures
for environmental assessment of projects funded by the World Bank Group (which includes
IDA). Key characteristics of OD 4.01 include categorization of projects based on potential
environmental impact, the EA process throughout the entire project cycle, the consultation with
affected groups and public disclosure of EA reports. For details of OD 4.01, refer to Annex 5.
Operations of IDC will conform with the requirements of OD 4.01
Comparison of Bangladesh Requirements with OD 4.01
3.14    The EIA  process under both the legislation in Bangladesh and OD 4.01 have their own
requirements. which do not necessary match. A  comparison is made to identify similarities and
differences, so that a process meeting more stringent of the requirements can be applied to IDC
projects.   Table 3.4  lists some  key  comparisons, and  discusses the requirements  for the
Bangladesh law with OD 4.01. In general, OD 4.01 requirements are more comprehensive when
compared with the requirements of Bangladesh legal system.

Social Aspects
3.15   The laws, regulations and guidelines that are applicable to projects involving land
acquisition, resettlement and other social issues in Bangladesh are discussed below. These laws
and  guidelines  and  the  World  Bank's  Operational Directive  number 4.30  (Involuntary
Resettlement) and 4.20 (Indigenous Peoples) have been taken into account while preparing the
ESF. Preparation, processing, implementation and monitoring of the social issues component of
the specific sub-projects will be carried out in accordance with the specific provisions of the
ESF.
Constitutional provisions
3.16   The fundamental rights guaranteed under the Constitution of Bangladesh indicate the
general guideline for a policy on resettlement/rehabilitationof citizens affected adversely (whatever
be the mechanism) due to any activity of the State. However, there is a certain ambivalence.
Article 40 states categorically that every citizen has the right to practice any lawful occupation
which implies that anything that impedes such right should either be not done or there should be
supplementary   measures   to   make   Food   the   losses   incurred   by   the   citizens.
Resettlementlrehabilitation of adversely affected people due to infrastructure development very
clearly falls within such supplementary measures.
3.17   The Constitution. however. restricts the right of citizen categorically when under Article
(42). sub-clause (2) it states that no law with provision of compensation for acquisition of land can
be challenged in a court on the ground that such compensation has been inadequate.
13



Land Acquisition Acts
3.18  In 1982. the Acquisition and Requisition of Immovable Property Ordinance, came in force.
This law replaced the earlier law. The Land Acquisition Act. 1894 (I of 1894) and others that have
been in force between 1947 and 1982. and. is the major basis for all the present actions regarding
acquisition. resettlement and rehabilitation. The relevant and salient points of the 1982 law are as
follows:
*     "Property" means only immovable property (land and building) and includes any
right in such property.
*     "Owner' includes the occupiers;
*     Matters to be considered in determining compensation include
-     the market value of property
-     damage to standing crops or trees due to acquisition
-     damage due to severance of acquired property from other property at the
time of actual taking of permission by concerned authorities
-     damage to other properties or earnings
-     expenses for relocationof residence
-     damage due to lowering of profit of the property to be acquired between the
serving of acquisition notice and actual acquisition.
3.19   While the rules under the Act 'appear' fairly generous, problems often arise in.
implementing the provisions of the Act. Determining market value and damage to property or
income are difficult to establish in normal circumstances. It becomes more so in an emotion
charged situation such as acquisition of land in a land-scarce and agricultural-dependent society.
Arbitrariness is almost certainly likely to result. The situation is not helped by assigning by the
government to itself sweeping powers in matters of acquisition. Read with the Article 42. sub-
clause (2) of the Constitution referred to above, there is every chance that the acquisition may not
be entirely necessary. that compensation may be rather inadequate or paid such later than actual
acquisition.
3.20   To sum-up the legal context. while there are constitutional and legal provisions for
acquisition and payment of compensation for acquisition of land and other immovable property for
state-determined purposes. there are also uncertainties in the actual practice because of lack of clear
guidelines. sweeping power given to Deputy Commissioners who actually serve notice and take
possession of acquired property and the denial of legal instruments to citizens against such actions.
3.21   Of late. however. there have been certain changes in practice. Thus, one finds a very large
resettlement and rehabilitation scheme for the Jamuna Multipurpose Bridge (JMB) financed among
others by IDA. In this case a very large group of people has been affected due to acquisition of
land. A ResettlementAction Plan (RAP) to address the issues of resettlementand rehabilitationof
14



this and other. groups of project affected people (PAP), more or less in line with the IDA's      N
operational directive on involuntary resettlement. has been prepared and put in operation. The
legality of such actions depend on the Jamuna Bridge Ordinance. Other infrastructure development
Projects such as the Coastal Embankment Rehabilitation Project II or the Second Road
Rehabilitation and Maintenance Project have in various degrees followed a similar resettlement and
rehabilitation scheme. While these are positive development the fact remains that these are all ad-
hoc measures.
3.22  The present laws, acts, regulations and rules are not very explicit regarding resettlement and
rehabilitationof project affected people (PAP). One can. however, as indicated earlier interpret the
spirit and letter of these laws (including constitutional provisions) and rules to imply that
resettlementand rehabilitationof people adversely affected due to the project is the responsibilityof
the project authorities. As a result, in recent years there have been several instances where attempts
have been made and are being made to take affirmative action. In all such cases the core idea is to
prepare an entitlement matrix based upon an entitlement policy. Entitlement here means the rights
of the persons adversely affected by the project to receive certain benefits from the project
authorities to compensate for their losses which may include land and other immovable property,
income. standing crops. occupation etc. The compensation is often in terms of cash grants but also
includes training and credit facilities and other necessary facilities in resettlement and
rehabilitation.
3.23  The most widely referred to and the most comprehensive in terms of size and scope is the
resettlement plan under the Jamuna Bridge Project (JBP). Others include the Second Road
Rehabilitation and Maintenance Project (RRMP-I[), Coastal Embankment Rehabilitation Project-1l
(CCERP-Il). River Bank Protection Project (RBPP) and Second Rural Roads and Markets
Improvement and Maintenance Project (RRMIMP-2) of LGED. Other such plans or experiences
include those of the Occidental Petroleum Company in development of gas fields in the Jalalabad
Franchise Area. The proposed Resettlement Action Plan (RAP), Entitlement Matrix (EM) or Land
Acquisition Plan (LAP) for IDC incorporates the spirit and experiences of these projects and
activities.
World Bank Operational Directives regarding Social Aspects
3.24  The World Bank's Operational Directives OD. 4.30 and OD 4.20 describes the Bank's
policies with regard to involuntary resettlement and indigenous peoples affected by projects
financed by the Bank. Refer to Annex 7 for these Directives. Salient points from these Operational
Direciives are discussed below:
(a)    World Bank OD 4.30 (Involuntarv Resettlemen). This directive explains the Bank
policies and procedures on involuntary resettlement and the conditions that
borrowers are expected to meet in operations involving resettlement. The overall
objective of the Bank policy is to ensure that the population displaced by a project
also benefits from the project and that the standards of living are improved. or at a
minimum. maintained. It emphasizes the development approach in planning and
15



implementation of resettlement action plans. with the participation of the affected
groups.
(b)     World Bank OD  4.20 (Indihenous Peoples).  This directive describes the Bank
policies and procedures for projects affecting indigenous peoples - social groups
with a social and cultural identity that is distinct from the dominant society. The
objective of the policy is to ensure that development programs are socially and
culturally compatible, that they take place with the informed participation of these
groups; and that indigenous people do not suffer from adverse impacts. For a project
that affects indigenous peoples. an Indigenous Peoples Development Plan (IPDP) is
required. This is to be prepared in consultation with such groups.
Comparison of Bangladesh Rcquirementswith ODs 4.30 and 4.20
3.25    While Bangladesh law  provides for land acquisition. the regulations and rules are not very
explicit regarding the resettlement and rehabilitation of PAPs. The World Bank ODs. on the other
hand, are more comprehensive and stringent. requiring, among other things, the following:
-   paymentofcompensationfor various losses at replacementvalue
-   rehabilitationto ensure improvementlrestorationof the standard of living
-   public consultation during the entire process of social assessment and disclosure of
information.
a   a  Resettlement  Action  Plan,  and  where  appropriate, an  Indigenous  Peoples
Development Plan

.CHAPTER 4
MAJOR ISSUES IN PRIORITY SECTORS
4.1   IDC is committed to ensure that environmentally and socially sound practices are followed
in preparation. implementation. and operations of projects financed by the company. This section
describes briefly the generic environmental and social issues that could arise in projects financed by
IDC.
Environmental Issues
4.1    Recently Bangladesh has forrnulated a National Environmental Management Action Plan
(NEMAP) through the participation of all sectors and wide range of professionals and people at
grass root level. The plan has arrived at a consensus in respect of key environmental issues in the
major sectors. The following is an assessment of the key issues in the sectors of projects likely to
be financed by IDC, and also presents a list of environmental impacts generally associated with
such projects
Power
4.2   Owing to constraints in the expansion of alternate sources of energy, there is tremendous
stress on the country's biomass resources leading to rapid deforestation,loss of soil fertility and soil
degradation. In order to relieve the environmental stress from the biomass resources, the NEMAP
has proposed, among others, sourcing energy from renewable resources such as wind, solar etc. and
increasing the power generating capacity by establishing new power plants, focusing on gas-fired
plants, and updating the existing ones. The environmental impacts which normally associated with
establishment of power plants are:
*     Change in landuse.
*     Air pollution due to emission.
*     Therrnal pollution of water resources.
*     Noise pollution.
*     Change in aesthetic environment.
*     Soil contamination, sediment and dust pollution during the construction
phase.
*     Interference with path ways of wild life and birds.
In the power sector projects incorporation of environmental aspects are being seriously considered.
In recently in some thermal power plants in Bangladesh. environmental considerations have been
incorporated in the project forrnulation.
17



Gas
4.3   In gas development projects, both off shore and on shore, different activities are carried out
from prospecting stage to development. production and transmission. Each of these activities have
wide ranging environmental impacts depending on site and technology used. Some of the generic
environmental impacts associated with gas development, production and transmission project are
listed below:
Land Occupation (for seismic surveys. drilling, site treatment. plant. access
road etc.) resulting in involuntary movement of people, crop damage,
occupational disruption. landuse changes etc.
*     Erosion and sedimentation, - atmospheric impacts.
*     Disturbance (nuisances such as noise, traffic congestion, interruption of
services).
*     Change in water quality and water resources base.
*     Impacts flora and fauna.
-     Soil contamination.
*     Impact on cultural heritage including landscape and visual impact.
3     Impact on waste management.
-     Socio-economicimpacts.
-     Safety and health related impacts.
4.4   Though the gas sector has been developed for a long time in Bangladesh, consideration of
environmental impacts has begun only recently. In the recent past, an environmental clean up of
eight old drilling swamps was conducted by a donor agency who funded the drilling when
contamination of surrounding environment was reported. Recently the Govemment has granted
concessions to the foreign companies under Production Sharing Contracts. These companies are
proactively undertaking environmental assessment of their activities in response to their own
corporate environmental guidelines and participating financial institutions. Petrobangla, the
govemment agency for overseeing gas and oil development in the country, has recently established
an environmental division which has started preparing environmental guidelines for the gas sector.
Telecommunications
4.5   Impacts associated with telecommunication development are generally as follows:
Standing crop loss during construction of transmission lines.
Interferencewith the passage of wild life and birds.
Disruption of farming activities.
Loss of prime agricultural land due to construction of infrastructure.
Soil erosion and sedimentation on agricultural land due to earth works
associated with construction activities.
Interference with the aesthetics of the environment.
18



Port
4.6    Activities associated with port development in Bangladesh could lead to several
environmental impacts depending on the scale of operations including, among others. the
following:
*     Impact on fish fauna.
*     Impact on benthic fauna.
Impact on sensitive ecosystems such as intertidal zone, mangroves etc.
*,    Pollution of marine water due to oil spills and ship and wastes.
Landuse changes
*     Soil erosion and increased sedimentation due to civil construction,jetty construction
and management of dredge spoils.
*     Change in the hydraulic behavior of the estuarine regime due to maintenance
dredging.
*     Interference with fishing activities
*     Disturbance of spawning and nursery grounds of the estuarine and marine
fish species.
No environmental assessment has so far been conducted in the port development sector in
Bangladesh. However, environment guidelines are being prepared for the inland transport and port
operations.
Water sector
Sewerage
4.7    The following are environmental problems common to community sewerage and excreta
disposal systems (CSEDs) which may not be considered in usual project planning and design in
Bangladesh:
(a)    Problems related to siting of facilities such as:
(i)    Routing of sewers
(ii)    Selection of sites for treatment/pumpingplants
(iii)    Historical/cultural monuments/areas
(b)   Problems related to design phase. such as:
(i)    Overflow hazards
(ii)    Receiving water standards
19



* -.           (iii)    Protection of receiving waters
(iv)    Sludge disposal
(v)    Discharge of hazardous materials into sewers
(vi)    Control of industrial waste discharges to sewer system
(c)    Problems during construction stage, such as:
(i)    Control of silt runoff during construction, (may require use of temporary
holding ponds).
(ii)    Resurfacing/replantirg of exposed areas, both to avoid erosion and to
preserve environmental aesthetics.
(iii)    Other construction stage hazards as appl icable.
(iv)    Monitoring construction (to ensure that contractor complies with specified
constraints).
(d)   Problems during operations stage, such as:
(i)    Health and safety hazards to workmen
(ii)    Operations monitoring
(e)    Environmental Problems for use of subsurface leaching systems for individual
building excreta disposal. such as:
(i)    Overflow hazards
(ii)    Groundwater pollution hazards
(iii)    Dislodging service
(iv)    Disposal of sludge
Water SupPly
4.8    The following are some of the environmental problems commonly associated with
community water supply (CWS) systems which may not normally be considered in project
planning and design in Bangladesh.

A draft EQS has been prepared by DOE which provide standards for different types
of water but strict compliance is yet to be established in Bangladesh.
Waste Management
4.9   In the context of growing urbanization, waste management has been identified as one of the
key environmental concerns. The local govemrnment authorities who are responsible for the
management of urban waste have serious limitation of institutional capacity and resources to
address this environmental problem. The environmental impacts associated with waste
management, among others, are:
a  poor handling of waste leading to pollution of sunToundi ng environment.
*  occupational health hazards.
*  hazardous spill/fire/exposition.
*  poor management sludge and ash etc.
*  air pollution through emission.
v  contanination of ground and surface water.
*  depreciation of environmental aesthetics.
*  effect on adjacent properties.
*  blockage of wildlife passage.
*  degradation of wetlands.
In Bangladesh waste management. particularly in the Urban sector has been identified as a major
environmental issue. The National Environment Management Plan (NEMAP) has also taken this
issue into accounts and has proposed actions to undertake environmentally sound waste
management practice. setting guideline for compliance.
Highway
4.10  In a low lying country like Bangladesh . environmental impacts due to development in the
highway sector would be tremendous. In the past, development projects in this sector did not
consider environmnental impacts. The types. magnitudes and levels of environmental impacts would
22



vary according to the location. type of the project, technology etc. In Bangladesh. environmental
consideration in projects in this sector started receiving attention in the 1980s as a requirement
imposed by funding agencies. Under highway projects. a guideline to consider environmental
impacts has been developed. The Roads and Highway Department recently established an
environmental cell to look into environmental aspects of projects in this sector. The environrmental
impacts of the development project in this sector are, among others, the following:
*  degradation of wetlands.
*  impact on wild life.
*  impact on forests and wood lands.
*  soil erosion.
*  blockage of passages for wild life.
*  change of land use.
*  loss of top soil.
*  impact on ecologically sensitive areas.
v  drainage congestion and increased floatability.
*  loss of standing crops during the construction phase.
*  accident hazards.
*  dust, noise and vibration.
*  increased lead pollution.
*  increased air pollution due to vehicular emissions.
Social Issues
4.11   The major social issues related to infrastructure projects include: (i) involuntary
resettlement; (ii) protection of marginalized and vulnerable groups; and (iii) public consultation.
participation. and consensus building. Each of these are discussed briefly:
(a)   lnvoluntarv resettlement. Often. large infrastructure projects involve involuntary
resettlement of people. One of the primary tasks in resettlement is to identify an
appropriate site for resettling affected population. Once selected. infrastructure
development, conservation of cultural practices. capacity of the new site to
support the population in terms of resource availability etc. have to be factored in.
Timing of transport to new site, assistance during transition. and rebuilding are
very important. While there is often a preference for a land-for-land
compensation, opportunities for cash compensation. and skill assessment and
development need to be considered. The issues of host communities already
living in the new site also needs to be addressed.
(b)    Protection of marginalized and vulnerable izroups. Some infrastructure projects.
may affect marginalized and vulnerable groups such as economically and socially
disadvantaged groups; the elderly, women and children; physically handicapped:
and indigenous people. Social mitigation strategies have to take such groups into
consideration and prepare plans with their participation.
23



(c)   Public consultation. The best conceived projects can fail if project preparation and
implementation does not involve the concemed stakeholders, including affected
people and beneficiaries. A whole range of social issues can be effectively
addressed if a transparent and participatory process is followed through the entire
project cycle. For each project, a combination of methods may be used, based on
the specific project situation. Annex 8 provides some suggested methods.
24



CHAPTER 5
OPERATIONAL PROCEDURES FOR ENVIRONMENTAL AND SOCIAL
ASSESSMENT
5.1   This section describes the operating procedures that will be followed by IDC in each of
the infrastructure projects that it finances. The underlying principle followed in developing these
procedures is that environmental and social issues are best addressed when they are made an
integral part of the project cycle.
5.2   IDC is expected to follow the project cycle as described in Table 5.1. Since IDC is yet to
establish its detailed operating procedures for the project cycle, the table presents a typical
project preparation, appraisal, and implementation cycle in a project financing company. The
Environmental and Social Assessment Process is designed based on this project cycle.
The IDC Project Cycle
5.3    As the executing agency, the primary task of IDC will be to appraise projects and provide
financial support provided the projects are commercially viable as stand-alone entities, and are
able to meet the financial, technical, environmental, social and organizational requirements as
outlined in the operating manuals of IDC.
5.4   The IDC project cycle contains various stages as described in Table 5.1. As the concept
of private sector sponsored investment in large infrastructure projects is novel in Bangladesh,
IDC will be required to guide the sponsors through the project preparation process. However,
responsibility for preparation and all documentation rests with the project sponsor. At the
conclusion of the project preparation phase, IDC will undertake an independent and
comprehensive appraisal of the project to ensure that it meets the requirements of IDC, prior to
approval of the project.
5.5    As a first step in the project cycle. IDC will screen the project. The objective of screening
is to decide whether the project should proceed to the next stage, or be screened further, or be
dropped.
(a)    where project preparation has been sufficiently rigorous and comprehensive and
is consistent with the requirements of IDC, the project will be appraised and
approved for financing.
(b)    where a project is under-prepared. IDC shall require the project sponsor to
undertake further preparatory activities/studies in line with IDC requirements.
prior to undertaking an appraisal of the project.
5.6   The overall objective of project preparation is to make sure that the project sponsor
provides IDC with a well researched and documented report(s) on the project. so that IDC can
assess the creditworthiness, and concomitant risks of the project. During appraisal. IDC will
25



verify all project documentation, establish viability of the project, and finalize the contractual,
institutional, legal framework  for establishment and  operation  of the project, prior to  project
approval.

5.7      During implementation, IDC  has the responsibility to ensure that the project complies
with the standards, agreements and benchmarks agreed during project approval. Besides
requiring the project sponsor to submit periodic progress reports, IDC shall undertake field visits,
and interact with local govemments, public and other stakeholders to appraise progress on the
ground.
5.8     The Environmental and Social Assessment Process will dovetail with the IDC  project
cycle in such a manner that at each stage of the project cycle, environmental and social issues
will be addressed concurrently. Based on these principles, the rest of this section details the
Environmental and Social Assessment Process to be followed.
Environmental and Social Assessment Process
5.9     The Environmental and Social Assessment Process for IDC  is described in Table 5.3.
The process is based on:
(a)     The Environmental and Social Policies of IDC as described in Chapter I
(b)     Legal requirements in Bangladesh
(c)     Operational guidelines and requirements of IDA
(d)     Priority  Environmental and  Social issues in projects expected  to  be financed
through IDC. and
(e)     The project cycle for IDC, as outlined in Table 5.1.
27



5.10   Processing of envirornental and  social aspects of the candidate projects will be
integrated with processing of other aspects of the project according to the IDC project cycle. The
Environmental and Social Impact Assessment Process is the main vehicle to ensure that the
IDC's environmental and social development objectives embodied in the ESF are achieved in the
process of specific project implementation. The main objective of the Environmental and Social
Impact Assessment process is to ensure that (i) measures are incorporated in project design to
prevent, minimize and mitigate possible environmental impacts; and (ii) the standard of living of
project affected people and others living in the vicinity of the project site(s) is at least restored. if
not improved after project implementation. In order to ensure achievement of this objective. a
comprehensive process to identify, study, plan for, mitigate, and monitor enviromnental and
social impacts has been designed under the IDC. The process consists of the following steps:
1.     Environmental and Social Screening
2.     Environmental and Social Scoping
3.     Finalization of the terms of reference of Environmental and Social Assessment
Studies
4.     Appointment of consultants
5.     Environmental and Social Assessment Study
6.     Review of Environmental and Social Assessment Report (ESR)
7.     Translation of agreements into legal instruments
8.     Project monitoring.
9.     Environmental and social audit.
5.11   An Environmental and Social Assessment Report (ESR)) will be prepared as part of this
process. The format for an ESR is shown in Table 5.2. A detailed outline is provided in Annex
10.

5.13    Each project that comes to IDC for financing will follow  the procedures as outlined in
Tablc 5.3. For each stage of the Environmental and Social Assessment Process, the details are
described below:
5.14    Environmental and Social Impacts Screening:  As soon as the locational and design
parameters of candidate projects are known, an environmental and social impact screening
should be carried out by the Project Sponsor. The screening process will:
-7 a(a)                 examine broadly the likely environmental impact of the project;
(b)     outline the environmental mitigatory measures required;
(c)     check consistency with govemment regulatory requirements;
(d)     make a preliminary assessment of land acquisition requirements
(e)     verify whether the land required for the project falls into forest/tribal or other
special areas.
(f)     Define project stakeholders
(g)     describe the potential benefits of the project to the people living in the vicinity of
the project.
5.15   The screening report will be prepared by IDC staff/consultant based on a desk review of
project information provided by the project sponsor and verified through field visits. For
environmental issues. IDC will follow the proiect classification and EIA reguirements as outlined
in OD 4.01. (Refer to Annex 6). Upon completion of the screening process, the responsible IDC
staff / consultant will advise [DC management whether to proceed ahead with the project or
otherwise. The recommendation will be based on identification of certain highly adverse
environmental and/or social consequences of the project whose mitigation may not be possible.
IDC will share the screening reports of the candidate projects.
5.16   Environmental and  Social Issues ScoDing. Based  on  feedback received  through  the
screening process. the Project Sponsor is required to seek public opinion and build consensus on
30



the scope and extent of the environmental and social assessment required to be carried out. A
consultant may be engaged to conduct the scoping exercise.
(a)   Environmental Scoping: The outline Terms of Reference (TOR) for an
environmental assessment will be developed from an understanding of the project
location, project component, environmental attributes to be impacted, previous
studies, suggestions received during screening, and reference to regulatorv
requirements and World Bank OD requirements. The outline will be developed in
consultation with appropriate GOB agencies, and the public. The methods used
for public consultation may be a combination of those described in Annex 7.
(b)   Social Scoping: Based on the feedback received through the screening process.
the project sponsor and local authority will outline the scope and extent of social
assessment required to be carried out. The social scoping exercise will be carried
out based on the needs of the project affected persons. other stakeholders. special
needs of marginalized and vulnerable groups, past experience in the sector and
reference to the national regulatory requirements. The scoping outline developed
will be discussed with the appropriate public authority to incorporate their
concerns. The details of the scoping and the follow up process will be agreed with
the appropriate public authority at this stage.
5.17 Finalization of TOR for Environmental and Social Assessment Report (ESR). The
objective at this stage of the project cycle is to finalize the TOR for the Envirorrnental and Social
Assessment Studies. After completion of the scoping exercise, the project sponsor and the local
authority will prepare the TOR for the Environmental and Social Assessment Studies. The TOR
will provide the technical components of the study as identified during the screening and scoping
stage, a brief description of the project, the methodology to be adopted, expected outputs.
qualification of the consultants, and details of issues to be addressed in the ESR. including the
required mitigation plans (EMP, RAP. IPDP), and the details of the public consultation process.
The TOR should be checked for consistency with the ESF. The TOR will be submitted to DOE
for its clearance. TORs of all proiects to be financed by IDC will be reviewed and cleared bv
IDA.
5.18  Selection of Consultant for Social Irrpact Assessment Consultant. The Project Sponsor
will appoint a consultant. in accordance with IDC business practice. to prepare an Environmental
and Social Assessment Report for the project.
5.19  Environmental and Social Impact Assessment and Preparation of Mitigation Plans. The
consultant will prepare a comprehensive Environmental and Social Assessment Report (ESR)
consisting of information on environmental and social issues and the necessary mitigation Plans
to address the adverse environmental and social impacts identified.  An outline of the
Environmental and Social Assessment Report is given in Chapter 5 and in Annex 10. The social
mitigation plans will be prepared in accordance with the entitlement framework described in
Annex 8. and the Bank's ODs 4.30 and 4.20. In addition to the mitigation plans. which are
mandatory in nature. "area development plans" to increase the effectiveness of beneficial
31



initiatives of the project sponsor in the project area may also be prepared. The mitigation plans
to be prepared as part of ESR may include:
(a)   Environmental Manazement Plan (EMP) containing detailed mitigation measures
to address the environmental consequences associated with the project.
(b)   Resettlement Action Plan (RAP) to address the adverse impacts on project
affected persons. A proposed outline of the RAP is attached in Annex 8. The
resettlement entitlement policy to be followed in implementation of candidate
projects financed by IDC is given in the resettlement entitlement matrix given in
Annex 8, Table 1. The various likely categories of impacts have been identified,
and the resettlement entitlement policy for each category is described. A
description of the proposed resettlement entitlements for the various categories of
impacts are also given in Annex 8.
(c)   If ethnic minority communities are affected by a project. an Indigenous Peonies
Development Plan (IPDP) for tribal communities to address specific concems
related to them would need to be prepared. A proposed outline for an IPDP is
given in Annex 8.
5.20   The mitigation plans should contain detailed implementation monitoring plans, clear
allocation of responsibility among project sponsor, govemment agencies, community-based
organizations. and the IDC for implementation and monitoring of mitigation plans, and should be
developed in consultation with affected people, public authorities and other stakeholders.
5.21   Review of ESR. Upon preparation, the ESR needs to be reviewed by IDC for ensuring
compliance with the ESF. The Consultant or other responsible staff of IDC will review the ESR
and mitigation plans and submit their report to the Investment Manager(IM) of IDC, regarding
consistency of the ESR with the provisions of the ESF2. If the IM is satisfied with the ESR, then
it is submitted to the relevant Govemment agencies and IDA for review and clearance. Clearance
from IDA and statutory clearance from relevant GOB agencies is necessary for approval of the
project by IDC, and subsequent implementation.
5.22  Implementation Responsibility for Mitigation Plans. Although the primary responsibility
for implementation of mitigation plans (EMP/RAPI IPDP) rests with the respective project
sponsors. the oversight responsibility vests with IDC. However, in the concession agreements
between government counterpart agencies and the project sponsor. altemative arrangements (for
example. implementation of mitigation plans by the govemment) might be agreed. All
mandatory permit requirement and clearance in respect of project will have to be procured by the
project sponsor. IDC will also carry out regular supervision and monitoring to ensure that all
project agreements are complied with. The specific nature of this responsibility would vary with
2 In practice, the project sponsor will submit an initial draft ESR to [DC for review. and after incorporating
comments bv IDC will submit final draft ESR to the [DC.
32



the type of arrangements for land acquisition and resettlement with the counterpart government
agencies. The three possible scenarios are as follows:
(a)   The project sponsor purchases the required land from willing sellers with clear
ownership titles. Land transfer through such regular market mechanism does not
require any resultant resettlement, unless the land so purchased has encumbrances
such as squatter settlements or tenants. In case the land has encumbrances,
resettlement will need to be carried out by the project sponsor in accordance with
the provisions detailed in the ESF.
(b)   The counterpart government agency under a formal agreement with the project
sponsor, arranges to acquire the land under local land acquisition procedures and
transfer it free of all encumbrances to the project sponsor. In such cases, since
mitigation measures need to be completed before transfer of land, the cost of
mitigation would initially be borne by the counterpart goverrunent agency.
However, the cost could be reimbursed to the government agency or could form
the government equity in the project. Mitigation would still need to be carried out
in accordance with the provisions of the ESF.
(c)   The counterpart government agency, under a formal agreement with the project
sponsor, arranges to acquire land under the land acquisition procedures and
transfer it with all encumbrances to the project sponsor. In such cases the
responsibility for mitigation will rest with the project sponsor under the oversight
of IDC. The agreement between the government and the project sponsor should
clearly reflect the division of mitigation responsibilities.
Whatever implementation arrangements out of the above possible scenarios are agreed upon,
they would need to be clearly reflected in the project legal agreements.
5.23   Translation of Anreements into Lecyal Instruments. The objective of this step is to ensure
that the measures suggested in the various components of the ESR, especially the mitigation
plans, are incorporated into legal instruments that govem project implementation. The
obligations of the different stakeholders with respect to environmental and social issues as
described in the ESR will be translated through specific provisions in the following legally
binding documents. The order of agreements shall be as follows:
(a)   Concession Agreement will record the respective obligations and responsibilities
of project sponsor and Government in respect of, inter alia. environmental
standards to be met, acquisition of land. transfer of land to the project sponsor.
implementation of the mitigation plans and other arrangements. As it may be
necessary to discharge some of these obligations prior to the execution of the
concession agreement. the sponsors and the Govemment may decide to enter into
a Memorandum of Understanding at the initial stage of project development in
order to allocate responsibilities on these aspects.
33



(b)   Shareholders Agreement will confirm the project sponsor's obligations as spelt
out in the Concession Agreement and will conform to the IDC ESF.
(c)   Construction Agreement will record the respective obligations of the Contractor
Consortium and the Project Sponsor with respect to actions related to mitigation
of environmental and social impacts during the construction phase.
(d)   Operation and maintenance (O&NM) Agreement will record the respective
obligations of the O&M consortia and project sponsor with respect to
environmental and social management action during the operation phase.
(e)   Lenders Agreement between the project sponsor and IDC will take on record,
inter alia, the Concession Agreement, Shareholders Agreement, Construction
Agreement and O&M Agreement. and shall be executed after all the
aforementioned documents have been executed.
5.24  Monitorinz of Mitigation Plans. The project sponsor would include a satisfactory
monitoring plan in the EMP and IFC would supervise its implementation. The consultant could
be the same as those responsible for review of ESR. Each mitigation/development plan will
specify the schedule and indicators for monitoring. Corrective action, if necessary, will be
proposed to the Investment Manager and the project sponsor. Follow up actions initiated by the
project sponsor will be reviewed in subsequent monitoring exercises.
t      5.25   Periodic Social Audit. The IDC may conduct periodic Social Audits of various projects
under implementation to provide an independent assessment of performance on social issues.
This process can be useful in providing feedback on ongoing and new projects. An independent
consultant will undertake this review on the basis of project documentation, including all the
components of the ESF, project agreements. and the various monitoring reports. The consultant
will submit its audit report to the Board of Directors of IDC. The audit report shall be shared
with IDA. and can be released for disclosure to public.
34



CHAPTER 6                                                 X
IDC - IDA INTERFACE
6.1   As a financial intermediary, IDC may access funding from a variety of lenders including
multilateral agencies, such as IDA. In order to ensure that the preparation of the candidate
projects is in conformity with IDA requirements and IDC business practices, IDC will submit the
following documents for review by IDA. Though the suggested interface is applicable only to the
interaction of IDC with IDA, other financiers are encouraged to follow a similar process while
reviewing candidate projects financed by them.
6.2  In order to ensure that its infrastructure projects are in conforrnity with IDA's OD
requirements and business practices, IDC shall submit the following documents for IDA review.
Table 6.1 outlines the institutional interface matrix.

6.3   IDA concurrence to the outputs generated at each stage will be obtained prior to
proceeding to the next stage. However. when the capacity of IDC is established, IDA
concurrence and approval will be required only for the TOR, and ESR (EMP. RAP. IPDP) and
the associated agreements, prior to approving finances for candidate projects. In all cases where
more than 200 persons are affected by land acquisition and I or resettlement. or an IPDP is
required. the RAP and/or IPDP will be sent to IDA for review and approval.

CHAPTER 7
ENVIRONMENTAL AND SOCIAL RISK MANAGEMENT
7.1   Infrastructure projects have a range of associated environmental and social risks and
liabilities. IDC's project management procedures will include provisions to handle these risks
and the liabilities that could fall on IDC as a lender. However, IDC will remain exposed to
several risks: risks of interference by govemment, political stability, legal and regulatory risks.
environmental and social risk etc. While some of these risks are identifiable, others are often hard
to recognize.
7.2   IDC will approach environmental and social risks by a principle of Avoid, Reduce, Limit,
Control, and Share. IDC will work with project sponsors to use insurance schemes and contracts
to effectively allocate, manage and mitigate risks. A simple risk identification and management
process is outlined in this chapter.
Environmental and Social Risks
7.3   Environmental and Social Risks are often caused by non-recognition of a problem, not
taking measures to deal with it, design failure, non-compliance and unforeseen incidents. A
typical list of risks associated with infrastructure projects is described below:
3    Environmental
a Catastrophic explosion in a gas-based thermal power station
* Source for a water supply project is contaminated
*  Environmental standards in the country made more stringent
*  Increased floods due to reclamation of flood plains for a project
Social
*  Non-compliance with RAP/IPDP
*  Accident during construction/operation
*  Severe impacts on most vulnerable groups
*  Sustained opposition to project from non-govemmental organizations
Risk Evaluation Process in the IDC Environmental and Social Assessment Process
7.4   The IDC risk management strategy will consist of four steps: (i) risk identification: (ii)
risk assessment: (iii) risk allocation, and (iv) risk management. These steps are incorporated as
part of the IDC Environment and Social Assessment Process (outlined in Table 5.3). At each
stage. IDC will ensure that project confirms to the process. Table 7.1 outlines how the risk
36

CHAPTER 8
9}                             INSTITUTIONAL SUPPORT FOR ESF
8.1   IDC will establish an institutional structure capable of implementing the provisions of the
ESF. This main principle for institutional development in this regard is that the environmental
and social objectives of IDC (as embodied in the ESF) are best achieved when they are made an
intrinsic part of the project cycle. The institutional support and development reflects this intent.
8.2   The main objective of developmcnt of IDC's capacity on environmental and social issues
is to ensure that projects submitted for financing conform to the ESF. lDC's responsibility is
limited to review and monitoring of ESR submitted by project sponsors in order to ensure that
implementation is in accordance with ESF objectives, principles and procedures. In order to
achieve the objective described above, IDC shall:
(a)   Integrate the Environmcntal and Social* Assessment process with the IDC project
cycle:
(b)   Ensure that the Investment Manager's Unit has the capability to address
environmental and social issues.
(c)   Appoint consultants, as necessary, to undertake special assignments with respect
to environmental and social issues.
8.3   IDC shall build capacity in the IM's unit (or through consultants) for the following
activities:
-  Screening of projects.
*  Finalizing the terrns of reference for ESR.
*  Advising project sponsors on appointment of consultants for preparing ESR.
*  Review of completed ESR.
*  Translation of mitigation agreements into enforceable instruments
*  Monitoring project implementation.
*  Conduct periodic Environmental and Social Audit.
8.4   In order to facilitate conduct of above tasks:
(a)   IDC's Investment Manager will be the operational manager with overall
responsibility for implementing the provisions of this ESF.
(b)   IDC will initially engage consultants for implementing the different stages of the
Environmental and Social Assessment process -- for the purpose of reviewing the
ESR. IDC will retain a corporate consultant to advise on environmental and social
issues.
38



(c)   Increase awareness among all departments /staff of IDC regarding the importance
of addressing environmental and social issues through integration with the project
cycle. A training program for the invest manager and other staff of IDC to
familiarize them with the provision of the ESF and their application. I

performance of controls as well as their design standards. In the exceptional circumstances where new plants are
proposed to be located in significantly polluted areas, the guidelines require that an Environmental Assessment

Annex A - Plants Smaller Than 50 MWe
For plants smaller than 50 MWe including those
burniing non- fossil fuels, the PM emission levels
may be up to 100 mg/Nm3. If justified by the
EA, PM emission levels up to 150 mg/Nm3 may
be acceptable in special circumstances. The
maximum emission levels for NO. remain the
same, while for SO. the maximum emission
level is 2,000 mg/Nm3

ANNEX I: ATTACHMENT 1
INrTIAL ENVIRONMENTAL EXAMINATION FOR PROJECTS
IN THERMAL POWER
1.   The initial environmental examination (EE), as indicated in the checklist,
shows that the project involves potential sexious adverse environmental impacts
which must be given careful attention in the planning, design, construction, opera-
tion and monitoring of the projects in order to minimize and offset adverse effects,
and therefore a follow-up EIA is required.
2.   The feasibility study for the project, to be done by the Project Consultant,
should include an EIA (FS/EIA). The FS/EIA should include a study of each of the
environmental effects found by the IEE to be of significant importance. (These are
items D2, D3 and D4 marked on the checklist.) For each of these items, the Con-
sultant will conduct a study, as part of the overall EIA, sufficient.
(a) to make an assessment which delineates the significant environmental
effects of the project;
(b) to describe and quantify the effects;
(c) to describe feasible mitigation measures for minimizing, eliminating, or
offsetting unavoidable adverse effects; and
(d) to recommend the most appropriate mitigation and/or enhancement
measures.
3.   The selected significant environmental impacts (SEls) to be studied, as part
of the overall EIA, are the following:
A. Environmental Problems Due to Project Location
1. Disruption of hydrology
2. Resettlement
3. Encroachment on precious ecology
4. Encroachment on historical/cultural values
5. Cooling water abstraction (excessive)
33



B. Environmental Problems Relating to Design (including assumptions on
O&M)
1. Cooling water system (once through)
2. Pollution control equipment selection
3. Environmental pollution control operations
(a) surface waters (fresh/estuarine/marine)
(b) air environment
(c)  noise
(d) bottom sludges (special problem)
(e) impacts on adjacent land economic uses, including recreation/tourism
(f) occupational health and safety
(g) hazardous spills/fires/explosions
C. Environmental Problems During Construction Stage
1. Silt runoff during construction
2. Continuing erosion of unprotected exposed areas
3. Other construction stage hazards
4. Monitoring during construction
D. Environmental Problems Relating to Inadequate Operations
1. Inadequate O&M due to poor management
2. Occupational health and safety programs, including accidents
3. Nuisances from handlingtranLsportation of fuel on access roads
4. Surface runoff from plant yard
5. Operations monitoring
E. Realization of Feasible Enhancement Measures
F. Impacts from Power Transmission Facilities
1. Encroachment on precious ecology
2. Depreciation of environmental aesthetics
3. Erosion/silt runoff during construction
4. Continuing erosion/silt runoff from unprotected exposed areas
34



4.   The overall EIA will approximately require    man-nonths , p,frofessional
input This estimate assumes that the EIA will be done as part of the oyera ,project
feasibility study.
5.   The estimated optimal time required for the EIA is    months.
6.   The total estimated cost of the recommended  EIA is approximately
$           including approximately -    per cent for foreign exchange.
7.   Other comments

ANNEX I: ATTACHMENT 2
CHECELIST ANNEX
ENVIRONMENTAL EFFECTS COMMONLY ASSOCIATED
WIT PROJECTS IN THERMAL POWER
(EXCLUSIVE OF MINING OF FOSSIL FUELS)1
Significant adverse environmental effects which have resulted from develop-
inent projects in thermal power in the past include the following:
A Environmnental Effects Due to Project Location
1.  Disruption of hydrology: Changes in the hydrology of waterways inter-
cepted by the project, without careful planning, can result (1) in creating
or intensifying local flooding problems, and (2) in affecting aquatic ecol-
ogy including fisheries. Through evaluation of the local hydrology, such
potential adverse impacts can be identified and the planning/design ad-
justed to minimize the effects.
2.  Resettlement offamilies displaced byproject:
See Annex M/2.
3.  Encroachment into forests/swamplands:
See Annex E/5.
4.  Encroachment on historical/cultural monuments/areas:
Need to avoid/minimize/offset such effects by careful design.
5.  Cooling water abstraction: Are the available water supply resources in
the region sufficient to meet project needs for cooling water without dis-
ruption of existing beneficial water uses?
6.  Regional flooding and drainage hazards: Will the structures be
secure against regional flooding hazards? Is the regional drainage
1 See separate guidelines ror mining operations.
36



pattern inadequate to meet project needs? Should the projectbe enlarged
to obtain additional flood protection?
7.  Waste emissions problems: Is this siting appropriate with respect to
achieving proper disposal of liquid or gaseous or solid wastes (keeping in
mind that many environmental pollution problems stem primarily from
poor siting)?
B. Environmental Problems Relating to Planning and Design (including
assumptions on quality of O&M [see Annex 11.4])
1. Cooling watersystem. For 'once through' coolingwater systems, is the
design appropriate considering other water rights allocations and effects
of plant processing (heating, mechanical abrasion of microorganisms, and
chemicals added to the cooling water) on downstream beneficial water
uses? Is the cooling water intake design adequate for screening out fish?
2. Pollution control equipment: Is the selection of sophisticated equipment
for controlling pollution emissions consistent with realistic expectations
on O&M quality levels for the DMC, including provisions for training?
3.  Pollution control
(a) surface wwaters: Does the design take into account all existing
downstream beneficial uses and furnish suitable protection to these,
including provisions for monitoring based on realistic environmen-
tal standards? The wastes include the fossil fuel bottom ash residues
after burning, salts and toxic chemicals in blowdown from recirculat-
ing cooling water systems (see Annex 11.4, 11.6).
(b) groundwaters: If the groundwater is used for water supply, does
the design for management of liquid and solid wastes afford ap-
propriate protection to this resource, including provisions for
monitoring?
(c) air environment: Does the design for control of fly ash and other
air pollutant emissions furnish appropriate protection to environ-
ment considering local and regional air mass movements, including
provisions for monitoring?
37



(d) noise: Does the design afford appropriate protection for both
workers and neighbors?
(e) boiling sludges (bottom ash): Does the design provide for proper
disposal of steam boiler sludges when these are periodically cleaned?
This can be a serious pollution problem (Annex II.5). If access to the
open sea is feasible, it may be advantageous to dispose of this at sea.
Usually disposal is by landfilling.
4.   Occupational health. Does the projectplan provide for a reasonable oc-
cupational health program for protection of the workers' health and
safety?
5.  Hazardous spills/fires/explosions: Does the design take these hazards
suitably into account, including provision of emergency action measures,
for appropriate protection of workers and nearby residents and
properties?
C. Environmental Problems During Construction Stage
1.  Silt runoffduring construction: Does the construction plan include ade-
quate provision for control of silt runoff during construction, including
use of temporary holding ponds and other measures if necessary?
2.  Erosion of unprotected exposed areas: Does the construction plan in-
clude provisions for replanting or other resurfacing of exposed cut-and-
fill areas to prevent continuing excessive erosion following construction?
3.   Other construction stage hazards: Does the project construction plan
incorporate provision for other potential adverse effects during construc-
tion such as described in Annex m sections including: (1) runoff erosion
during rains from unprotected excavated areas resulting in excessive soil
erosion, (2) safety of workers from accidents, (3) communicable disease
hazards from lack of proper sanitation at workers camps, (4) com-
municable disease hazards, especially malaria, from imported worker
vector carriers, (5) hazards of slum formation following construction,
(8) dust/fume/odor hazards, (9) noise and vibration hazards, (10) quar-
rying/blasting hazards, (11) hazard of disrupting other utilities service
lines, (12) disruption of street traffic for prolonged periods, (13) pollution
of groundwater from dumping of construction spoils, (14) local flooding
38



- by use of excessive flushing water, (15) dredging/filling in waterways
areas.
4.  Monitoring during construction: Does the project construction plan
provide for necessary construction stage monitoring?
D. Environmental Problems Relating to Operations
1.  Adequacy of O&Mfunding: Assuming a realistic O&M plan, is it realis-
tic to assume adequate funding will be made over a continuing basis?
2.  Occupational health and safety: See Items (b) (v) and (vi). Given ade-
quate plans, will the provisions/budget for O&M be able to implement
them?
3.  Nuisancesfrom haulingfueL  WiU the noise, traffic and dust emissions
along access routes be excessive?
4.  Surface runoff from plant yard: Wil this runoff contain sufficient
amounts of pickup of fuel, oils and other pollutants so that treatment of
the runoff will be needed?
5. Operations monitoring: Does the project operations plan and budget in-
dude provision for minimum necessary periodic monitoring to ensure
that all essential environmental protection measures are being done, and
to recommend needed corrections?
E. Realization of Feasible Enhancement Measures: Does the project plan
take advantage of opportunities for feasible modifications in the plan-
ning/design for incorporating special measures which wil significantly en-
hance environmental values, thereby serving both to offset unavoidable
adverse impacts and to improve the project's overall benefit/cost ratio? Pos-
sibilities which have been feasible for large industrial plants include provision
of good water supplies for rural villages in the vicinities, and for power plants,
rural electrification in the plant vicinity or subregion.
F. Impacts from Power Transmission Facilities
1.  Encroachment onprecious ecology: Same as for A(3) above. (See Annex
III/5.)
39



2.  Depreciation of environmental aesthetics: Siting and design should
minimize any adverse effects, including use of trees for screening.
3.  Erosion/silt runoffduring constructiorL  Same as Item C(1) above. (See
Annex m/1.)
4.  Continuingerosion from exposed areas: Exposed areas not replanted or
covered have been a common serious problem in the DMCs (same as for
Item C(2) above).
G. Overall Critical Environmental Review Criteria (Policy Issues)
1.  Will the project cause unwarranted losses in precious/irreplaceable
natural or other resources?
2. Will the project make unwarranted accelerated use of scarce resources in
favor of short-term over long-term economic gains?
3.  Will the project result in unwarranted hazards to endangered species?
4.  Will the project tend to intensify undesirable migration from rural to
urban sectors?
5.  Will the project tend to increase the income gap between the poor and
the affluent?
H. Other Potential Environmental Problems These include aspects
which will normally be accounted for in project planning by the Bank staff
specialists in engineering, economics axid finance, as discussed in Annex m,
Section 2.
40

HYUNDAI
SAFETY. HEALTH and ENVIRONMENTAL POLICY
and PROCEDURES MANUAL
FOREWORD
This manual represents HYUNDAI safety policy and guidelines established by others who have
done the kind of work you are doing. Read it carefully and understand it fully. Your knowledge of
these rules and your complete cooperation in carrying them out is essential for the maintenance
of a safe place to work and your own safety.
Safety rules cannot be written to cover every conceivable work condition. The practices
contained herein are written so that they can be readily understood. For more detailed
instructions, you may need to make reference to HYUNDAI Safety Manual, HYUNDAI Material
Safety Data Sheets, Engineering Bulletins, industry publications or other relevant notices.
You will be expected to exercise good judgement and common sense in observing these
practices. Should any doubt arise as to the proper meaning or interpretation of this safety
policy, procedures or any other safety information, ask your supervisor for clarification.

APPENDIX H2:
AN OVERVIEW OF THE ANTICIPATED PGCB TRANSMISSION TOWER
DESIGN, CONSTRUCTION FACTORS, AND
LIKELY ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS
ESG INTERNATIONAL INC.
SEPTEMBER, 2000






AES MEGHNAGHAT LTD.
MEGHNAGHAT POWER PROJECT
FINAL ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACT ASSESSMENT
1. Introduction
The primary purpose of the 1995 Power System Master Plan (PSMP) was to design a 20-year
management plan to ensure the efficient, and timely development of Bangladesh's power system.
To this end, the 1995 PSMP noted that in order to increase the efficiency of the existing
electrical transmission system, while expanding delivery capabilities throughout Bangladesh,
two key tasks required completion:
* a 230 kV ring around the Dhaka; and
* a 230 kV transmission line from Chittagong to Comilla and on to Haripur via
Meghnaghat (Acres, 1995).
As a result of these recommendations, and the proposed development of the Meghnaghat Power
Sites Area (MPSA), the Government of Bangladesh entrusted the Power Grid Company of
Bangladesh (PGCB) with the responsibility to connect the Comilla North sub-station to the
Haripur substation via the MPSA; to facilitate the demand and supply balance between the
eastern region of the country with central and western region as well as to export power
generated at the MPSA.
The PSMP also recommend construction of another high voltage line from the MPSA to
Hasnabad to be able to dispatch all the power to be generated at the MPSA in the future
(attachment 1). Routes were selected based upon a previously prepared environmental report
(MEP, 1997) and technical considerations of the PGCB. Funded with development capital from
the Asian Development Bank (ADB), tower construction along the routes is currently on-going
by the PGCB (attachment 2).
The PGCB is responsible for land acquisition, compensation, construction, and maintenance of
these high voltages transmission lines. Further, since development capital is being provided by
the ADB, the PGCB will comply with their environmental and developmental policies. The
Project Sponsor is not involved in any way with this process.
Since direct information was not available regarding the common construction practices of the
PGCB, the following overview was compiled to provide reviewers with a basic understanding of
the anticipated PGCB construction and operation activities.
2. Tower and Conductor Design
The 230 kV lines exporting power from the MPSA will be a double circuit, three-phase line with
twin conductors per phase and two overrunning earthwires supported on steel lattice towers
(MEP, 1997). The towers will consist of galvanized high tensile steel angles and bars.
Aluminium conductor steel, reinforced with 795 minimum circular mills having a current rating
of 770 amperes, will be used to connect the towers.
It is expected that both straight and angle towers will be required. Typical tower height will be
around 40 metres (i.e., 131 feet) with conductors being strung on the same vertical plane with a
2.5 to three metre (i.e., 8 - 10 feet) gap between them. River crossing towers are generally much
taller than the normal towers utilized on plain land, and depend upon the width of the river. The
ESG INTERNATIONAL INC                                                       H2' 1
SEPTEMBER, 2000



AES MEGHNAGHAT LTD.
MEGHNAGHAT POWER PROJECT
FINAL ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACT ASSESSMENT
height of the tower that will cross the Meghna River at the MPSA is 134.8 meters. The clearance
from the highest flood level will be approximately eight metres (i.e., 26 feet). The PGCB will
have to design both towers and lines against cyclonic type winds that can reach speeds of up to
200 km/hr for short durations (Acres, 1995).
Tower construction may also require a workspace of approximately 25m2 at the base of each
tower with suitable access for the construction equipment required to excavate foundations,
insert footings and/or pilings, and to deliver steel tower sections and cable conductors.
Considering the above design criteria, concrete may be used for tower foundations and footings.
All towers will require the support of piles and the piles will be constructed on-site. The
contractors engaged by PGCB are responsible for securing all materials such as bricks, sand,
reinforcement rod, and cement related to tower construction. From previous experience, it is
anticipated that 10 to 12 m3 of concrete will be required for the foundations of each tower.
3. Environmental Considerations
3.1    Construction Impacts
Typically, environmental impacts associated with construction of electrical transmission towers
and lines are linked to the involuntary resettlement of people, transportation of materials along
the route corridor(s), the preparation of foundations, installation of infrastructure such as
transformers, and the erection of safety fencing. Further, in many areas of Bangladesh tower
construction activities are limited to the dry season as flood conditions during the wet season
generally preclude such construction activities.
The impacts commonly associated with transmission line construction are summarized below
based upon previous experience and the anticipated actions of the PGCB.
3.1.1 Tower Routing
Based in part upon the ADB Guidelines (1993), and assisted by an environmental report (MEP,
1997), the PGCB has identified their preferred route corridors. To the extent possible, it appears
that urban areas have been avoided, other linear corridors paralleled, and route length minimized
(attachment 2).
Such alignments should minimize any short-term adverse effects of noise, dust, and construction
traffic. It is anticipated that the PGCB will deal with other construction impacts such as excess
waste (e.g., soil material and packaging) in one of three ways: i) reuse any such materials; ii)
make them available to local communities; or iii) dispose of them in accordance with existing
regulations.
ESG INTERNATIONAL INC                                                           H2. 2
SEPTEMBER, 2000



AES MEGHNAGHAT LTD.
MEGHNAGHAT POWER PROJECT
FINAL ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACT ASSESSMENT
3.1.2 Impact Assessment
- f   It is anticipated that the PGCB will complete, if they have not already done so, an environmental
impact assessment sufficient to meet and/or exceed the requirements of the ADB. Various
components of such a report are discussed in general below.
Involuntary Resettlement
It is expected that all land acquisition and requisition will occur under the supervision of the
Bangladesh Ministry of Land. Additionally, since the PGCB is receiving development capital
from the ADB, is expected that they will implement the resettlement guidelines and policies of
the ADB where appropriate.
It is also expected that any economic dislocation (e.g., loss of agricultural land at tower base)
that may result from transmission tower construction will be compensated by the PGCB as per
the ADB's requirements.
Surface Waters
In order to minimize and/or avoid potentially adverse environmental effects near surface waters
such as rivers and streams, it is anticipated that the PGCB and its contractors during construction
will take special care when crossing any surface waters. Such actions may include:
changing oils and lubricants in pre-designated/authorized areas;
*  prohibiting the cleaning of any vehicle and/or equipment near surface waters;
*  minimizing the use of equipment in close proximity to any surface water feature;
. restricting the amount of vegetation clearing on and adjacent to surface waters; and
* not allowing waste material to be discarded into surface waters.
General Safety Measures
Various safety measures will be implemented by the PGCB, in accordance with both ADB and
Government of Bangladesh requirements. Such measures may include:
*   the installation of protective sheathing around the wires as well as inspection chamber
installed to facilitate monitoring;
*   measures to prevent vehicle collision may be placed on towers located near road access
points; and
* signs indicated Danger: High Voltage and restrictive fencing may be placed around the
newly installed towers to prevent unauthorized third parties from climbing on the towers in
areas of easy public access.
Local Employment
Construction of the transmission towers may involve the use of unskilled labour and skilled
engineers and planners. Should the PGCB not have such personnel on staff, it would be possible
to hire local persons on a short-term contract basis; providing a local positive economic impact.
ESG INTERNATIONAL INC                                                           H2 - 3
SEPTEMBER, 2000



AES MEGHNAGHAT LTD.
MEGHNAGHAT POWER PROJECT
FINAL ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACT ASSESSMENT
Personnel Training
Prior to construction, and pending the hiring of local personnel, the PGCB may wish to
undertake a training program in order to educate all construction staff in accordance with the
policies and procedures required as part of the project. This may include the requirements for
proper construction area preparation, compliance with waste disposal practices, surface water
protection, and occupational health and safety measures, among others.
EPC Contractor
The Engineering, Procurement, and Construction (EPC) Contractor, on behalf of the PGCB, may
undertake site-specific monitoring measures during the construction process in the following
geographical areas:
* rural areas - proper implementation of erosion control devices, topsoil segregation and
storage, drainage replacement, etc.
* urban areas - installation of protective safety fencing, limiting construction activities to the
easement lands, etc.;
water bodies - limited work within and on surface water banks, prohibition on fording
(i.e., driving through watercourses), maintaining existing vegetative bank cover to
minimize the possibility for sedimentation, etc.; and
* easement - restoration of construction work areas.
3.2  Operation Impacts
The operational impacts of electrical transmission lines are generally limited to visual intrusions,
ecology, community severance, electromagnetic fields, and maintenance. Each impact is
summarized discussed below.
3.2.1 Ecology
Each transmission corridor will require some type of permanent access route at various places
along the corridor. Although such access routes would be a permanent feature, it is anticipated
that the PGCB would utilize existing road networks and agricultural trails to the extent possible.
3.2.2 Community Severance
Generally, electrical transmission facilities do not present a barrier to the movement of people.
To ensure this, the PGCB may wish to consider locating the transmission towers as far away as
possible from residential and commercial areas to avoid the visual perception of community
fragmentation.
3.2.3 Electromagnetic Forces
Electrical transmission lines are often a source of public debate over the potential impacts that
electromagnetic fields may have on human health. However, according to the American Cancer
Society, electromagnetic fields "have not been shown to cause cancer..." (ACS, 1997).          )
Additionally, the Government of Sweden formally declared that "the research findings presented
ESG INTERNATIONAL INC                                                            H2- 4
SEPTEMBER, 2000



AES MEGHNAGHAT LTD.
MEGHNAGHAT POWER PROJECT
FINAL ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACT ASSESSMENT
hitherto afford no basis for and cannot be said to justify any limit values or other compulsory
restrictions on low-frequency electric and magnetic fields" (GOS, 1996).
Therefore, based upon the available literature, the publicly debated effects that electromagnetic
forces may have on human health are not anticipated to be an issue for the PGCB. However,
should local persons raise this as an issue, it is the responsibility of the PGCB to resolve the
issue.
3.2.4 Maintenance
The maintenance of transmission towers and lines is generally infrequent and limited to times
following an adverse event (e.g., lightening striking the tower). Further, it is anticipated that
corridor maintenance such as vegetation clearing will also occur infrequently and only on an as
needed basis by the PGCB. It is highly probable that local persons will continue agriculture
activities under the transmission lines, minimizing the need for extraneous vegetation removal by
the PGCB.
