APPENDIX H3:
AN OVERVIEW OF THE ANTICIPATED TITAS NATURAL GAS
PIPELINE CONSTRUCTION FACTORS AND
LIKELY ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS
ESG INTERNATIONAL INC.
SEPTEMBER, 2000






AES MEGHNAGHAT LTD.
MEGHNAGHAT POWER PROJECT
FINAL ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACT ASSESSMENT
1. Introduction
The Titas Gas Transmission and Distribution Company Limited (Titas) will supply natural gas to
the Meghnaghat Power Sites Area (MPSA) via a 500 metre long NPS 20 spur pipeline (i.e.,
nominal pipe size of 20 inches). The steel pipeline will termninate at Titas' Regulating and
Metering Station (RMS), which will be constructed on the AES Meghnaghat project site.
Specifically, natural gas to the MPSA will be transported through Titas' existing Ashuganj-
Bakhrabad and Bakhrabad-Demra pipelines. For reference, the Bakhrabad-Demra gas pipeline
has a rated capacity of over 200 mmscfd while the daily gas consumption of the AES
Meghnaghat power plant is estimated to be 80 mmscfd; much less than the total supply capacity
of this gas pipeline.
Funding for the construction of the pipeline and RMS is expected to originate from Titas and/or
the Government of Bangladesh. The RMS will be designed to handle a maximum gas delivery
capacity of 125 mmscfd to provide for flexibility in the system. Titas will construct, operate, and
maintain the pipeline in accordance with the rules and guidelines of the Government of
Bangladesh.
Titas will undertake any land acquisition, associated compensation, construction, and
maintenance activities associated with the gas pipeline and RMS. The Project Sponsor is not
involved in any way with Titas' works or activities. However, since direct information was not
available regarding the common construction practices of Titas, the following overview was
compiled to provide reviewers with a basic understanding of the anticipated Titas construction
activities.
2. Natural Gas: Demand - Supply Scenario
Natural gas will mainly be supplied from the Titas gas field and other associated fields located in
the northern region of Bangladesh. According to the 1995 Power System Master Plan (Acres,
1995), the country is producing gas at the rate around 1,000 mmscfd, which exceeds the present
rate of consumption. However, to ensure the long term, continuous flow of natural gas to key
end-users, various studies have been undertaken to assess the growing demand for natural gas in
Bangladesh (attachment 1) as well as the country's natural gas reserve/supply potential
(attachment 2).
Although results are mixed, it is a commonly held belief that with increased exploration and
development, natural gas production will coincide with the forecasted demand (Khan and
Imaduddin, 1999). In the short term, however, the gas supply situation in Bangladesh further
improved following the commissioning of the Jalabad gas field by Occidental of Bangladesh in
1999. Additionally, Shell of Bangladesh has been able to increase their offshore supply of natural
gas via their Sangu gas field.
In 1999, the US oil and gas exploration company Unocal, discovered a large reserve of natural
gas at Bibyana, located in greater Sylhet aream with a reserve of around 5.0 trillion cubic feet.
Development of this field may start soon if gas supply from existing operating fields is found
ESG INTERNATIONAL INC                                                        H2. 1
SEPTEMBER, 2000



AES MEGHNAGHAI LTD.
MEGHNAGHAT POWER PROJECT
FINAL ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACT ASSESSMENT
insufficient compared to the demand and/or if permission is given to export gas to the
neighbouring India.
3. Construction Characteristics
Although Titas has indicated that it plans to construct the pipeline parallel the existing access
road to the MPSA, the final route for has not yet been officially confirned by Titas. However, to
construct the pipeline, it is anticipated that Titas will acquire a permanent easement of six metres
(i.e., 20 feet); simnilar to the easement acquired by Titas for the Haripur Power Project. Titas may
also temporarily requisition an additional six metres, on one side of the easement, during
construction to provide for the movement of construction equipment and a workspace. It is
expected that all land acquisition and requisition will occur under the supervision of the Ministry
of Land, through the Office of the Deputy Commissioner of Narayanganj District.
Similar to the AES Haripur Power Plant, Titas will employ a turnkey contractor to construct the
RMS. On August 17, 2000, Titas invited international bid for design, procurement, and
construction of the RMS under the financing of the Government of Bangladesh. It is anticipated
that the design and procurement of all RMS equipment (e.g., gas measuring metre, pipes, valves,
fittings, etc.), their installation and commissioning would occur within eight to ten months from
the award of the contract.
The Natural Gas Safety Rules, 1991 (Rules) identify safe distances between pipelines operating
at various pressures and the development of civil works. The Rules also set out minimum depths
of cover for pipelines with respect to operating pressures. It is anticipated that Titas will follow  e
the development criteria contained within these Rules (attachment 3).
4. Environmental Considerations
4.1 Construction Impacts
Typically, environmental impacts associated with construction of gas pipelines and facilities are
linked to the transportation of materials along the route, the preparation of pipeline trench,
installation of required infrastructure such as valves and the RMS, and the erection of safety
fencing. The impacts commonly associated with pipeline construction are summarized below
based upon previous experience and the anticipated actions of Titas.
4.1.1 Pipeline Routing
It is probable that Titas will route its spur pipeline immediately adjacent to the recently
constructed access road to the MPSA. Such an alignment should minimize any short-term
adverse affects of noise, dust, and construction traffic to this area. It is anticipated that Titas will
deal with other construction impacts such as excess waste (e.g., soil material and packaging) in
one of three ways: i) reuse any such materials; ii) make them available to local communities; or
iii) dispose of them in accordance with existing regulations.
ESG INTERNATIONAL INC                                                           H2- 2
SEPTEMBER, 2000



AES MEGHNAGHAT LTD.
MEGHNAGHAT POWER PROJECT
FINAL ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACT ASSESSMENT
4.1.2 Economic Dislocation
As discussed, it is expected that all land acquisition and requisition will occur under the
supervision of the Ministry of Land. Therefore, it is expected that any economic dislocation
compensation will occur under the laws and regulations of Bangladesh.
At the present time it is understood that there will be no involuntary resettlement associated with
construction of the pipeline and RMS. To assist Titas with their planning activities, persons
affected by the RMS have been identified within the Resettlement Action Plan (RAP) prepared
by AES Meghnaghat Ltd. (AES). Further, it is anticipated that virtually the same landowners
and persons affected by the construction of the MPSA access road will also be affected by
pipeline construction. The names of these persons have also been documented in the AES RAP
and are available to Titas upon request.
4.1.3 Local Employment
Construction of the pipeline and RMS may involve the use of unskilled labour and skilled
engineers and planners. Should Titas not have such personnel on staff, it may be possible to hire
local persons on a short-terrn contract basis; providing a local positive economic impact.
4.1.4 Personnel Training
Prior to construction, and pending the hiring of local personnel, Titas may wish to undertake a
training program in order to educate all construction staff in accordance with the policies and
procedures required as part of the project. This may include the requirements for proper
construction area preparation, compliance with waste disposal practices, and occupational health
and safety measures, among others.
4.1.5 Grading and Excavation
During site preparation and construction activities, Titas may implement the following
protective/mitigative measures to reduce the associated construction impacts:
grading should only occur on those surfaces where construction will occur;
*   topsoil may be stockpiled during construction and stored separately from any subsoil
encountered during trenching activities;
*   where necessary, topsoil piles should be protected from wind and water erosion via the use
of tarpaulins and/or vegetative cover;
all open trenches should be clearly identified with flags, barriers, plastic tape, etc. to
prevent third party injury within the work areas;
* trenches should be backfilled as expeditiously as possible to minimize the potential for
both human injury and pipeline damage; and
* if appropriate, temporary drainage channels should be constructed so as not to affect the
adjacent agricultural activities.
ESG INTERNATIONAL INC                                                            H2 - 3
SEPTEMBER, 2000



AES MEGHNAGHAT LTD.
MEGHNAGHAT POWER PROJECT
fINAL ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACT ASSESSMENT
4.1.6 Trenching and Laying of Pipe
To the extent possible, Titas should minimize the width of the trench, while ensuring sufficient
room to safely install the pipe, in order to reduce the potential for any unnecessary disturbance of
adjacent soils and land-uses. Titas should also consider the schedule for both the handling and
laying of pipe so as to minimize the amount of time the trench is open and exposed to the
environment. As noted, trench backfilling should occur expeditiously and with the materials
excavated from the trench.
4.1.7 General Safety Measures
During the construction phase of the gas pipeline, Titas may consider implementing the
following general safety measures:
* any changing and handling of oils and lubricants, as well as machinery maintenance,
should be conducted in designated areas only and not on adjacent agricultural lands; and
* any fuel storage should be within designated areas, away from residences and high traffic
areas.
4.1.8 Spill Prevention
Should an accidental spill occur during construction, Titas may wish to consider implementing
the following procedures:
*  all spills should be immediately contained and remediated;
*  contaminated material should be safely stored prior to transport to an accredited recycling/
disposal facility;
*  personnel should be properly trained in containment practices and equipped with the
necessary supplies (e.g., absorbent materials, shovels, storage containers, etc.); and
*  fuel storage should be limited to areas with secondary containment mechanisms such as
berms.
4.1.9 Hydrostatic Testing
Hydrostatic testing should be conducted on the pipeline prior to its operation in order to ensure
its ability to withstand the operating pressures. Typically, testing is done by pressurizing the
pipeline with water at a minimum of 150% of its normal operating pressure over a given period
of time (e.g., 24 hours). As the pipeline will be 500m long, a limited amount of water will be
required for this hydrostatic test. Considering the location of the Meghna River, and its known
flow volumes, this would seem to be an appropriate source for the test water. As water
withdrawal for this purpose will be temporary only and insignificant compared to the flow, Titas
would not likely require permission from Bangladesh Water Development Board.
Since a large volume of water is required, the water should be recycled to the extent possible by
Titas. One such use may include the provision of the test water to local farmers to assist in the
watering of crops. However, if the test water is laden with rust and sediment, it should be
directed to a temporary settling pond prior to its use by a third party and/or discharge back into
the Meghna River.
ESG INTERNATIONAL INC                                                            H2- 4
SEPTEMBER, 2000



AES MEGHNAGHAT LTD.
MEGHNAGHAT POWER PROJECT
FINAL ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACr ASSESSMENT
4.1.10 Post Construction Restoration
Once construction and hydrostatic testing are complete, the original soil horizons should be
restored to their original profile sequence and surficial grading undertaken to reinstate the pre-
construction topography. Any fuels, oils, or lubricants utilized during construction should be
properly collected and sent for recycling and/or disposal at an accredited facility. Additionally,
any other extraneous waste material should also be collected and sent for recycling and/or
disposal.
4.2 Operation Impacts
The operational impacts of the pipeline and the RMS should be generally limited to accidental
contact with the pipeline, community severance, and maintenance. Each impact is summarized
below.
4.2.1 Pipeline Contact
As the pipeline will be buried around one meter below the ground and clearly marked with
identifying concrete posts, accidental contact with plough is a remote possibility. As the pipeline
will be laid close to the access road, and Titas personnel will be regularly coming to the MPSA
to monitor the operation of the RMS, topsoil stealing is not anticipated. As a result, accidental
pipeline contact is not considered to be a significant issue for Titas.
4.2.2 Community Severance
Generally, pipeline facilities do not present a barrier to the movement of people. To ensure this,
the Titas is considering locating the pipeline parallel to the existing access road easement to
avoid the visual perception of community fragmentation.
4.2.3 Maintenance
The maintenance of pipeline, as it will be laid below grade, should generally be infrequent and
limited to periodic required reviews. Further, since the RMS is located within the MPSA,
adjacent communities will not be disturbed by its maintenance requirements.

(a) Transmission line pressure available at Meghnaghat location will be norrnally around 500

(b) that at Haripur location will be normally around 400 psig.

1.0 INTRODUCTION
History of the natural gas industry in Bangladesh started in 1955 when gas w-Js
discovered at Sylhet. Soon after the discovey of gas at Chhattak field in 19.t,|
production was started from this fieid by supplying gas trough a 4 inch 19 km pipelife|
to the Qhhattak ceme:tt factory, This was followed by gas supply to Natural C^as I
Fertiliz r Factory in Fechugani in 1962 through an 8 inch 43 i,m  pipe0ine and l
Shiddlsirganj Power Station in 1967 through a 14 Inch 83 km pipeline. Since then, tile I
industr. has seen extensive progress both in terms of extension and volume: Industial
and ini astructure growth contributed towards diversified use of gas. Tvday the industry
supplif:;  more than 900 million cubic feet of gas per day (mmcfcf) to more than 887,000
custon 'irs comprising LF power stations, fertiflzer plants, Industries, commercial clients
and dc- nestic users through a network of about 12000 km transmission, distribution and
servic;; pipelines.
The gfr--emment formulated and promulgated a NatIonal Energy Policy (NEP) in 1995
setting !he objectives and strategy for energy sector of Bangladesh up to the year 2020.
The Nl:P has stipulated that in order to achieve economic development, per capita
energy consuimption has to be increased, and the energy consumptitn rate would be
about i .4 times the GNP growth rate. -This indlcates energy growth vste of 8.77%-by
year 2.100 to achieve a GNP growth rate of 6.4%, which is equivalent to 12 million tons
of oil. I.:nergy demand in 2005 would be 19 MTOE. representing energy growth rate of
9.86% 'o achieve GNP growth of 7.2%. Per capita consumption of commercial energy in
Bangtv lesh in 1995 was 67 KGOE (World Bank 1998/99), which increased to 78 kgoe
in 19957198 of which per Capita gas consumption is about 2.5 Mcf (56 kgoe). Currently.
nature' gas accounts for more than 70%/ of the total comnmercial ene;gy consumption.
The rt -'or part of the future energy demand would be met from natural gas.
2.0  ,;URRENT STATUS OF GAS DEMAND -SUPPLY
In 199.'. gas sector of Bangladesh just crossed about a decade long supply crisis. The
crisis v!as mainly due to (i) delay in completing some developmnent drilling program. (ii)
infrast 'cture ltmitation and (iii) production fall in Bakhrabad gas field. The gas
infrastr'cture limitation wras attributed to the absence of Ashuganij  Bakhrabad gas.
pipelin *. At present 12 gas fields under public and. private sector are in production.

900 - 130 mrncf per day depending on customer dem-and, mMinly fr.irn power sector.
After  long interval the supply side is able to cater to the demand witthout any gas

others 254 mmcfd. totaling 915 mmtrfd. Current customerprofile is shown in Table 2.1;

6.0   '.;AS RESERVE,AND DEPLETION SCENARIO
At pre e.nt Bangladesh have 21 discovered gas fields of various dizes. Of these the
latest tiscovery irn Bibiyana is still under appraisal but Is expected to be a major fild.
The c'tner 20 yas fields have a total Gas Initially In Place (GIIP) of about 25 Trlion
Cubic t eet (TCF). Of these four major fields. Kailashtila. Rashidpur. Habiganj and Titas
contai, 13.7 Tcf or 55% of the total GIIP. Major share of gas reserve were discovered
by Inte, national Oil Companies Working -under different legal and finaricial-regime. Gas
fields -: Bangladesh and their reserve are shown in Table- 6.1.
SanglFdesh gas resaryes have been studied by a number of groups. The last one by
IKM ih? 1989 is being 'ised as the official figure. This study however covered only 9
fields, 'or the rest, reserve figures have been calculated by BAPEX or others. In most
cases ihe reserves of IlYe gas fields have been estimated on deterministic method and
on a s igle well basis. The reserve figures need to be updated urgently for pragmatic
long te m planning, as tIie figures in many cases do not coincide with reality any more.
For ex: mple Chattak field, on the basis of a single well, is shown to conitain in excess of
1 Tcd l'3 coverable gas. whereas, this field was abandoned after producing only 26.5 Bcf.
Similar.r, Bakhrabad field was developed to produce 200 mmcfd from 8 wells dn the
basis ef the then reserve estimate, In practice the.field is now limited to produce 50
mmnrmd due to excessive water and sand production after recovering only 39% of GIIP.
The re'-overable reserve of the fiild was estirnated to be 61% of GIIP i.e., 0.867 Bcf. It
is to 1-' mentioned here that the eiht wells in this field are drilled irn the crest of the
structu i   in close proximity. Reserve potentiality of this field need tc, be reassessed.
F8ni vo J Kamta fields were abandoned after recovering onFy 30 % aid 6;5% of GIIP.
Furthr: nore, recent development drillings in Habiganj and Rashidpui indicate that the
previo- .Ay considered extent of reservoiLs do not hold ar.y more and the reServe uf
these  -!lds may downscale significantly. The largest field Titas has a (;lIP of 4.132 lTcf.
consid-- ting a reoovery factor of 51%eg the recoverable reserve was calculated at 2.1 Tcr.
The fie   has already produced 1.567 Tcf with insignificant pressure drop. This indicateS
that t-,K field eitter has a rnuch larger GIIP or it is a clear cut wsater drive case. Three

that ye. rly consuinptioin has increased sharply, has resulted In a steep decline of the'

PEOPLE'S REPUBLIC OF BANGLADESH

FINAL ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACT ASSESSMENT
Environmental Baseline Conditions
1.0 People's Republic of Bangladesh
Bangladesh is one of the poorest, most densely populated, and resource limited nations in the world (Gain,
1998). The estimated population is 127,567,002 creating an average population density of approximately 874
persons/km2. The average life expectancy is 56.66 years (CIA, 1998).
The nation faces numerous environmental problems including limited access to potable water, water-borne
diseases, flood-prone living conditions, water pollution, intermittent water shortages, soil degradation,
deforestation, and severe overpopulation. Along with these problems, the nation's people are regularly
victims of grave natural disasters such as droughts, cyclones,.landslides, and floods (CIA, 1998).
Bangladesh is located in southeast Asia between 200 31' to 260 38'N and 88 01' to 92 41' E (Figure 1.1 of
the main report). Although India surrounds the majority of the country's territory, it shares 193 kilometres of
border with Myanmar to the east. To the south, Bangladesh has 580 kilometres of coastline along the Bay of
Bengal. In total, Bangladesh has 144,000 square kilometres of territory - 133,910 km2 of land and 10,090
km2 of water. The country is mosdy a flat alluvial plain, with the exception of the hill tracts in southeast. The
lowest point in elevation is at sea level, while the highest point is 957 metres above sea level (CIA, 1998).
2.0 Physical and Biophysical Features
Much of Bangladesh lies within the broad deltas formed by the Padma, Jamuna, and Meghna Rivers. These
rivers drain parts of Tibet, most of the Himalayas, and much of the mountain foothills north and east of
Bangladesh. The latter hills first capture the moisture-laden clouds of the summer monsoon and wring from
them several hundred inches of rain in a period of three months. Most of this water ends up flowing down the
AV      complex and ever-shifting system of rivers in the Bengal delta, bringing rich alluvial deposits onto what
geologists believe are the thickest beds of alluvial material anywhere in the world. The geography of
Bangladesh has developed, and is continuing to evolve, through the continuing process of silt deposition
(Bigelow, 1995).
Bangladesb has a tropical climate. It supports a cool, dry winter from October to March, a hot, humid
sunmer from March to June, and a cool, rainy monsoon season from June to October. During the monsoon
season, the country is often subject to severe floods. In 1998, Bangladesh experienced one of the worst
floods in the country's history. Its timing, magnitude, and duration were unlike any other. Approximately
75% of the country was submnerged. The number of people directly affected by the flood was over 30 million.
Out of 64 administrative districts, 52 faced serious consequences due to flooding. Approximately 353,000
houses were destroyed and 1.4 million homes damaged by floodwaters. More than a quarter of the country's
people were left homeless. In total there were 748 deaths caused by drowning, snakebites, capsized boats,
nudslides, house collapses, electrocution, diarreah and other water-borne and communicable diseases (i.e.,
malaria, hepatitis, and typhoid) (Grameen Bank, 1998). In addition to monsoon floods, the Bay of Bengal
regularly spawns cyclones and their associated tidal surges and floods.
Unique agricultural patterns and practices have evolved under the country's extreme climatic conditions.
Different varieties of crops have been adapted to suit not only minor variations in soil types, but also
seasonal variations. For example, rice can be grown under various moisture regimes (e.g., some floating rice
varieties have stocks extending six metres in length). Agriculture remains an important role in most of
Bangladesh and in 1995 approximately 60% of the country's work force was involved in farming. This
represents about 40% of the country's Gross Domestic Product (Bigelow, 1995).
ESG INTERNATIONAL INC                                                                 11.1
SEPTEMBER, 2000



AES MEGHNAGHAT LTD.
MEGHNAGHAT POWER PROJECT
FINAL ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACT ASSESSMENT
Landraces and old cultivars play a significant role in Bangladeshi agriculture. However, no studies have been
carried out within the country attempting to categorize the species that inhabit these areas or understand their
role in the country's natural environment. Farmers grow and maintain these cultivars mainly due to the non-
availability of improved seed varieties and their adaptation to specific ecological niches, resistance to pests,
specific qualities, and low input requirements.
Bangladesh has a long history of settlemnent and a high population density. Thus, it is no surprise that
significant natural habitat areas are limited to isolated pockets scattered throughout the country. World
Heritage sites and key protected areas include the Sundarbans in the southeast of the country, which supports
a population of Bengal Tiger and the Chittigong Hill Tracts to the southeast, which supports Asian
Elephants. Forest cover in Bangladesh is between five and six percent of the country's total land area. It is
estimated that approximately 8,000 hectares of forest are lost annually due to processes of urbanisation and
deforestation (Gain, 1998).
In the past 100 years, Bangladesh has lost 10% of its mammalian fauna, 3% of its avifauna, and 4% of its
reptiles. There are more than 50 critically endangered species in Bangladesh, 23 of which are declared as
endangered by the International Union for the Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources (IUCN). The
country's most endangered mammalian species include the elephant, tiger, wildcat, leopard, serao, and
dolphin. Endangered bird species include the white-winged duck, comb duck, stork, crane, pheasant, and
partridge. Endangered reptiles include the crocodile, python, monitor lizard, roofed turtle, soft turtle and all
marine turtles (IUCN, 1999).
Bangladesh supports approximately 260 species of finfish in the inland open waters (Rahman, 1989), all of
which are imnportant nutritional, social, and economic factors (Ali, 1997). However, fish resources are
shrinking rapidly. Today, there are thirty species of fish at risk, which include the chitol, kalbaus, tatkini,
and aeer. Further, it is suspected that the indigenous swarputi, aleng, and barnosh species are already extinct.
Bangladesh also supports approximately 4500 floral species out of which 300 species are being cultivated,
over 80 species awe endangered and 100 species threatened. Unsustainable harvests and habitat destruction
are the two main reasons behind species depletion (Gain, 1998).
3.0 Socio-Economic and Cultural Features
India's State of West Bengal has been the centre of rnany vibrant and prosperous kingdoms since the timne of
India's first great empire-builder Ashoka the Great, in the second century B.C. Over the centuries, as the
rivers shifted eastward, central and later eastern Bengal became home to important states and principalities.
The accounts of Bengal by Arab, Chinese, and European travellers and diplomats in the centuries after the
Muslim conquest of Bengal (1204 A.D.) provide a picture of great wealth and productivity, together with
political and commercial links as far as the Middle East in the west and China in the east.
In the sixteenth century, Sonargaon and Chittagong were handling huge grain and cotton surpluses produced
in southeastern Bengal for export as far as the Moluccas and Goai. The fine woven muslin of Bengal was
highly valued throughout the world and was known as Dhaka as far away as Central Asia. The project
region, Sonargaon, is renown as having been a major exporter of nation's best muslin (Dunn, 1986; Eaton,
1993).
Eaton (1993) notes in his study of the region's history that large areas of eastem and southeastem Bengal,
around Sylhet, Comilla, Noakhali, Patuakhali, and Chittagong, were only settled from five hundred to two
hundred years ago. This was the result of land grants to Muslim Sufi preceptors (pirs), who organised their
colonisation around Muslim religious centres using co-operative forms of social organisation. The arrival of
the Muslims and the resulting agrarian development in rural Bangladesh absorbed earlier rural organisations
that had evolved over centuries. This amalgamation incorporated the Bengal peasantry's ability to thrive in a
ESG INTERNATIONAL INC.                                                                 11.2
SEPIEMBER, 2000



AES MEGHNAGHAT LTD.
MEGHNAGHAT POWER PROJECT
FINAL ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACT ASSESSMENT
land where vast seasonal inundation was as much a part of life as the unavailability of "dry" land (Eaton,
1993).
As with many regions in the southern hemisphere, conditions for the average Bangladeshi began
deteriorating during the colonial period. Between the Census of 1872 and that of 1981, population density in
the largely agrarian northeast and southeast grew by 376 and 269 percent, respectively. This made Bengal
one of the most densely populated regions in the world and put ever-growing pressures on land, inland
fisheries, and other natural resources. For most Bengalis, this has resulted in a lowering of many key
development indicators such as average daily caloric intake.
Despite the productivity of the land, and the great skill of the peasant cultivators, the agrarian sector cannot
be regarded as a major future growth sector for Bangladesh. In some areas, cash cropping, such as jute for
the mills and vegetables for urban markets, or shrimp farmning, can enhance incomes in areas that have the
right conditions and location, but without industrial development, the prospect for the rural areas is for
growing unemployment and declining standards of living.
Much of the recent sociological literature on rural Bangladesh has focused on the intense competition for
land in East Bengal and increasingly on control over water bodies. Although Bangladesh is not an
abnormnally violent society, social scientists have concluded that to a significant degree violence in rural
areas is engendered by conflicts over land.
The most vulnerable groups are the lowest strata of landowners; poor peasants who have a small plot of land
and lack the resources and power to protect themselves from predatory land grabbers. In the south, in
Barguna and Patuakhali for example, some of the latter are acting on behalf of entrepreneurial shrimp
farmers, who produce shrimp for export by closing off and flooding formerly cultivated areas.
Other issues also produce conflict. Chars, which are low islands formed and reformed by erosion and
deposition of sediments, are frequently subject to control by armed groups who hold newly formed chars by
force. This is true even when the new land is still only an uncultivable sandbar. Those who may have lost
their land to erosion in the same reach of the river, have no rights to the newly formed land, which as rivers
move, is usually on the other side. (Hartman and Boyce, 1990; Jahangir, 1990; Jansen, 1987).
Increasingly, water bodies are also proving to be sources of conflict. Traditionally, inland water bodies,
including the rivers, oxbow lakes, old riverbeds, and village fishing ponds, were regarded as common areas
and resources. Indeed, such bodies of water were the ultimate social safety net in the traditional system, as
fishing required little capital investment. In the last decade, however, due to well-intentioned, but perhaps
maladroit efforts by donors to modemize fisheries and to implement licensing and franchise programs, major
portions of the inland water commons have been taken over by entrepreneurs who come into conflict with
local people over issues of access.
It is perhaps not surprising that rural folk in Bangladesh are sensitive to real or imagined threats to their land
and water resources. Indeed, entrepreneurs who threaten these vital resources often find rural communities
closing ranks in opposition, a demonstration that the old co-operative community values may still be present,
despite the more evident overlay of factionalism. Projects that withdraw land or water resources from the use
of the community will be carefully scrutinised for the value they may or may not bring to local people.
Project development that respects such concerns and involves local leaders in mitigation planning has the
best chance of gaining local support.
Despite its golden history, prosperity is not a word usually associated with Bangladesh today. Indeed, the
image of Bangladesh for most people is one of deep poverty. For its 127 million people, Bangladesh
averages an annual per capita GNP of US$283.00. This places the country economically with Cambodia,
ESG INTERNATIONAL INC.                                                                    11- 3
SEPTEMBER, 2000



AES MEGHNAGHAT LTD.
MEGHNAGHAT POWER PROJECT
FINAL ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACT ASSESSMENT
Laos, and Kenya. The current overall growth rate is 4.7 percent, which lags behind an inflation rate of 4.9
percent.
According to World Bank statistics, approximately 83% of the population lives in rural areas, almost half of
who live under moderately poor conditions (Bangladesh Institute for Development Studies, 1997). This
rural-based population does not have sufficient income or household production to meet the World Health
Organisation's minimum daily caloric intake of 2112 Kcal (Danish Ministry of Foreign Affairs, 1997). This
problem is perpetuated by a population growth rate of about 1.8 percent annually.
Agrarian prosperity is no longer an option for a country with as little land area as Bangladesh. It has been
accepted that industrialisation will be the key component of revitalisation. Currently the Country's industrial
growth is estimated at 8.7 to 8.9 percent. The Country's development should continue to accelerate as long as
industrial progress is not hindered by lack of resources (e.g., electrcal power). The growth experienced is
based in part on the discovery of substantial reserves of natural gas and the government's current effort to
increase the country's supply of reliable power. Unfortunately, the Bangladeshi energy crisis has lead to the
slowing of industrial production and international investment (see attachment). An environmentally sound
increase in power production is essential for Bangladesh to continue to build on its rich past.

flut First Bangladeshi Daily Newspaper on the 1
Editorial Page
Volume 3 Number 64         Wed. October 27, 1999
Editorial
Curse of Power Failure
Frequent interruptions in the supply of electricity to industries in and around Dhaka city
have terribly upset the owners of industrial units. The situation has become insufferable
due to several power dislocations in a single day.
It transpires from the DESA version that PDB, the supplier of power to DESA, has been
generating less electricity than required and asking DESA to make do with the short
supply. The DESA, on its part, is not sympathetic to the industrialists' request to give
priority to the mills and factories in matters of giving them relief from loadshedding. A
lot many owners of small factories in the industrial estates have expressed their
dissatisfaction and frustration to The Daily Star staffer over the highly erratic power
supply. They rightly felt that this led not only to damage of the plants and machinery but
also an enormous drain on the raw materials imported at a huge cost to the foreign
exchange reserve. The report cited examples where the owners either shut down their
factories or sold them out. Apart from the maladies of job loss and fall in the output, the
owners of these industries are thrown into an uncertain future as many of them are likely
to turn into bank defaulters for no fault of their own.
For the last three years we have heard a lot about failure of the previous government in
terms of power generation and management of power distribution in the country. It is
high time the criticism was replaced by performance.

flut First Bangladeshi Daily Newspaper on the    _
Front Page
Volume 3 Number 63         Tue. October 26, 1999
Power failure takes toll on mills, factories
By Staff Correspondent
Mills and factories are the worst sufferers of frequent power failure which has pushed
many manufacturing units towards "sickness" and even closure, industry operators said.
The Dhaka and its adjacent areas have been suffering a shortage of 100-200 megawatts
every day for the last few weeks, according to DESA sources.
"Power goes off 10 times a day on an average," said Insan Ali, head electrician of
General Engineering and Foundry Limited in the BSCIC industrial estate at Tongi. He
said that the power supply situation had worsened recently and disruptions often
continued for several hours.
"Power supply was disrupted as many as 17 times in the industrial estates on a day last
week," he said. "Failure to ensure normal power supply is causing serious disruptions in
production, wastage of raw materials, loss of work hours and damage to the machines,"
said Anwar Hossain, owner of Selim Rabbar and Plastic Industries.
He said: "We urged the government many times to ensure uninterrupted power supply at
least to the BSCIC industrial estates. But no body paid any heed to our plea."
"If the situation does not improve, many factories would be forced to stop production," he
said. Only the larger industries are surviving because they have been able to set up their
own power generation system. "Others are on the verge of collapse," he said.
"Earlier, our factory could produce as many as 100 tube wells every a day but now we
cannot make even 50," Insan Ali informed The Daily Star.
Frequent power failure has caused a loss of around Tk 25 lakh to an engineering factory
in Shyampur, Postagola in a year. "The factory is now closed and the owner is thinking to
sell it off," said Abdul Hamid Bhuiya, manager of the factory, United Traders.



http:l/www.dailystarnews.com/1 9991 0/26/n9 1 026Q1 .htm#BODY2
"It became almost impossible to continue production because we never knew when
power would go off. Sudden disruptions caused loss of huge raw materials," he added.
"The factory deals with iron and steel materials which cannot be processed at a required
temperature without continuos power supply. If power is off for more than one hour after
crushing iron sheets, they become cold and nothing can be produced from the raw
materials," Ahmed explained.
The power supply situation was almost same yesterday as Dhaka and its adjacent areas
suffered 100 megawatt power shortage. The DESA got allotment of 900 megawatt from
the Power Development Board against it's requirement of more than 1,000 megawatt.
A DESA official admitted that priority is not given to the industrial belt in distribution of
power. The industries areas suffer power failure as much as the market and shopping
centres do, the official admitted.
Tongi, which houses around 500 mills and factories alone, had a power shortage of three
megawatts yesterday. Its requirement is around 19 megawatts, the DESA source said.

AES Meghnaghat Ltd                    General Socio-Economic Household Survey
Socio-Economic Survey
at the Surrounding Villages of Meghnaghat Power Plant
Introduction
This report embodies the outcomes of the socio-economic surveys conducted as a part of EIA
of the Meghnaghat 450 MW Power Plant. The survey seeks to find out the general socio-
economic condition of the surrounding villages by focussing on the most pertinent features.
The result of the survey would help ascertain demographic character of the concemed
population apart from the educational, occupational, health and other important background.
There will be also brief discussion on income, agriculture and social support of the
community.
The seventy-acre site for the AES-Meghnaghat Power Plant, one of the upcoming threes, is
surrounded by a cluster of villages located in the vicinity. The entire plant area sizing two
sixty-four acres used to be winter crop and vegetable field and monsoon fishing ground
before its acquisition by the Bangladesh Government a few years ago.
The most closely located two villages are Islampur and Ganganagar while relatively distant
ones include: Dudghata, Korbanpur, Pachari, Char Goaldi. The linkages of these villages and
their residents with the plant site are discernible bearing out socio-economic and
environmental implications.
While certain differences among the villages do not escape attention still they represent the
typical features of the Bangladeshi countryside. Of the six villages Islampur is relatively most
prone to iver erosion owing to its location right on the mighty river Meghna. A very large
number of the residents of this village include the settlers from the neighboring villages
already washed away by the river erosion. Clustered homes of the absolutely landless raised
on the government khas land further illustrates the scale of the impact the villagers are
exposed to river erosion. Physical proximity of the surrounding low lying villages to a very
big river like Meghna clearly suggests annual flood almost regularly affect the people's
livelihood in a substantial manner.
Methodology
The following socio-economic profile delivered from a sample study of sixty households, ten
from each of the six villages. The sample size was determined in advance in order to cope
with the scope of the work, given constraints which was later approved by IDCOL - the main
financier for the project. In order to ensure representativeness of the sample complete
household census was undertaken in each village. The largest was found Dudhghata with 425
households and the lowest Ganganagar with 70.
For each village independent sampling frame was prepared. Then the procedures of
systematic random sampling was applied in order to ascertain Kth interval by dividing total
ESG-DPC                                                               page-I



AES Meghnaghat Ltd                   General Socio-Economic Household Survey
households by ten. For each village the respective sampling proportion was expectedly
dissimilar. To identify the first sample from the first interval random table was used.
Questionnaire was finalized after a number of drafts and pre-testing. The field investigators
were sent to field after desk and field level training. Before computerization the field-in
questionnaire adequate editing was carried to figure out possible errors. Necessary tables and
other output derived from the computerized database.
Demography and Social Structure
Household size and sex distribution: Average household size is 5.68 in the surrounding
villages with 52.5% male and 47.5% female. Large household size indicates higher
population concentration. Proportion of children (below 15) stands highest - 37.63%. The
proportion of the peoples aging more than 45 years is 16%. Uneven sex distribution of
different age groups manifests in varying male and female proportions in different age
groups.

Literacy: Literacy level of the population is relatively better because the proportion of the
illiterate is less than what it is at the national level (more than 40%). Only 24% cannot read or
write. As many as 24.3% are school graduates.
Occupation: Formal salaried job is the leading among all occupations and 26.7% household
heads are engaged in it. It is followed by fishing (16.3%), small trade and cultivation (15.00/o
each). More than 6% are daily wagers both in agriculture and non- agricultural sectors. Most
villagers work in the village or in the vicinity. Some work in the nearby Meghnaghat while a
few in Dhaka city.

Community: Each village consists of traditional institutions like para (neighbourhood),
gushi (lineage) and samqj (community). For example Dudhghata has seven paras what
include Purbapara, Sharkerpara, Bhuiyapara, Sikdarpara, Faldrpara, Sarderpara and
Madhyapara. In those there are nine lineages. For each samaj here is also a leader who
renders commanding influence on the community members. In Bangladesh the role of
community leaders is quite significant particularly from the point of view of social control
and power structure. A consolidated table is presented below to depict the community profile.

lood: Although flood is a seasonal phenomenon in this area, sometimes it occurs with
higher intensity and scale. In normal years about 10%o households located on the fringe
experiencl  flood In 1998 it was much severe thn  normial year and more than 91%

Economy
Land ownership: Small land owners predominate the village agrarian structure. The
proportion of the owners who do not individually cross 50 decimals is more than 63%,
however, it should also be noted that dependence of the households on agriculture for their
livelihood is not very large. Only 8.3% households own more than 100 decimals but none
own more than 300 decimals. Average land ownership is 43.63 decimals.

Livestock: About 38% households own cattle. These cattle owning households own 2.72
cattle on average. However, as many as 58% households own poultry and on average 6.34
chicks.
Income and wa e: More than 400/c of the households annually earn at the range of Tk 15,000
to Tk 40,000 while less than 2% households below Tkl5,000. There are 104/o households
who earn annually more than Tk. 100 thousands. This income pattern indicates the population
of the surrounding villages are economically well of. Average annual income (agriculture and
non-agriculture together) is Tk 68,856. In the light of the poverty line income particularly
(roughly Tk. 15,000 annually for a 4 member household) estimated average income signifies a
relatively satisfactory situation.

Housint structure: Most houses (90%) are built of tin and none completely by bricks,
however, walls of 5% are built of bricks with the roof by tin. There are some completely mud
houses (1.70/!). Predominant housing structure indicate the residents of these villages are
relatively better than other similar villages where bamboo thatched houses predominant.
Starvation: In rural Bangladesh starvation characterizes the poverty situation. Meghnaghat
villages are not exception although the scale is low. Only 20% households have reported to
have experienced starvation in the last seven days of the interview. More than 81%
households reported to take fish in the last seven days of the interview. This is also a sign of
good economic condition.
Agriculture
Location of agricultural plots and irrigation: More than 48.590!o of the agricultural land
owned by the surveyed households now are located in the villages of residence while the rest
in the outside.
More than 67%/. of cultivable land is under mechanized irrigation indicating fair spread of
imgated agriculture compared to national average (not more than 400/!). The rest is irrigated
by traditional methods (swing basket and others). In mechanized irrigation low lift pump or
surface water irrigation is the most popular one followed by shallow tube well and deep tube
well ground water irrigation. Higher propensity of surface water irrigation owes to close
proximity to river. This is not unlikely that deep tube well irrigation has reduced to less than
10%/. since other methods are more cost effective.

In village      Outside vilage
CropDine Dattern and yield: Paddy is the most popular crop. More than 88% of the
agricultural land was cultivated. It was followed by wheat (20.84%/o), oil seeds (20.72%4),
vegetables (18.541%) and jute (9%/e). Wide popularity of paddy signifies its subsistence value
to the villagers.
Per decimal output of paddy is 23 kilogram. This complies with the standard rate. Per
decimal wheat cultivation is 31 kilogram, this is also high level yield. Oil seeds are produced
32.66 kilogram in one decimal of land - satisfactory figure. Vegetable yield is 40 kilogram
and jute is 23 kilogram in one decimal of land.
Different crops are marketed in the following manner: paddy 28%, wheat 28%, oil seeds
12%, vegetable 26% and jute 82%/e.
Health and Leisure
Infant and maternal mortaliti: Both infant and maternal mortality is minimum in the
surveyed villages. Infant (under 5) mortality is only 1.70/ in the last year (1998) and same is
also maternal mortality at the time of delivery. Both figures strongly indicate satisfactory
situation with regard to MCH-FP and immunization program.
Source of food: Although many households derive paddy, wheat, vegetables and others from
own field the dependence of them on market to procure food is substantial. It implies their
requirement is much higher than what are produced.
More than 63% households obtain rice from market, more than 91% households obtain
vegetables from the market and for 70%/o households market is the source of fish. However,
21. 7/o households completely depend on river for fish. Such dependence on market to obtain
ESG-DPC                                                              page-6



AES Meghnaghat Ltd                    General Socio-Economic Household Survey
food implies that cash income determines to a large extent how effectively the surveyed
households would obtain food.
Modes of treatment: Modes of treatment in the health-seeking behavior of the villagers
portrays the practice of 'medical pluralism'. More than 76% report to have visited hospital to
seek treatment while 43.3% report visiting folk healer. There are many over-lapping cases
combining modern and traditional treatment both.
Households' Source of Drinking Water and Sanitation Type
From HIand Tubewell    Using Slab Latrine
Source of drinkin! water and sanitation: More than 91% households use hand tube well to
obtain drinkcing water. This indicates the existence of health awareness. On the other hand,
only 33.3% households use slab latrines for the purpose of sanitation showing a large
proportion do not follow hygienic defecation practices.
Use of contmaeeDtive: Conitraceptive prevalence rate is 51.7%/, a slightly lower figure than
the national average. Among different methods pill is the most popular, followed by
condom, tubectomy and others.
Leisure: Villager-s spend their leisure time mostly by gossiping, visiting neighbors or sitting
in the village tea stalls. Almost 90%/ report of spending leisure time in the above way. So
many of them also watch television and listen to radio. Such percentage amounts to about
50%o. In other words these households spend their leisure time in a multitude of ways.
Social Support
Association with NGThs: Many of the surveyed households are associated with the support
from the NGOs. 25% have received credits from different NGOs. However, a limited number
has received skill training - only 10%.on
Loan from other banks: Apart from NGOs villagers also take loan from other commercial
banks. The scale is comparatively limited. About 20%il households have reported to obtain
loan from commercial banks.
ESG-DPC                                                               page-7



AES Meghnaghat Ltd                   General Socio-Economic Household Survey
Attitude to the Power Plant
Information and attitude: As many as 85% households have heard of the fact that power
plant is coming up in the vicinity. This is likely since earth filling is taking place mobilizing
large equipment and workers. Most villagers think (75%) that the upcoming plant will not
affect them.

Conclusion
Certain features of the Meghnaghat villages are not different from the average countryside of
Bangladesh, particularly population concentration and household size. Bangladeshi villages
on average contain one-fifty households and five is the average household size. More than
four villages of the Meghnaghat consist of more than the average number of households.
Average household size is plus five.
However, Meghnaghat villages are relatively prosperous and exposed to urban influences.
Literacy rate is higher, as well as salaried job is widespread. Income level is also relatively
high rendering different from the average poverty stricken Bangladeshi village. Although
small agricitural holding is predominant, modem technology is very much prevalent,
particularly the fact of more than 67% agricultural land are under irrigation. Infant mortality
is less although morbidity is not known. Open sanitation may have caused high morbidity in
consideration of the fact that about two third households do not use any hygienic latrines.
Future intervention may take place to improve existing sanitation practices.

1.          SOCIAL  IMPACT  ASSESSMENT  OF  THE  AES  MEGHNAGHAT
POWER PROJECT
1.1        Introduction: Project Region and Site
The AES-Meghnaghat Power Project is located in Narayanganj District, about 22 kilometers
south-east of Dhaka. The project area is part of Sonargaon Thana, the subdistrict tier of
administration, and comes under the Pirozpur Union Parishad, the unit of local government in
Bangladesh. Sonargaon Thana is in the south-eastern part of the district, bounded on the east by
the Meghna River. Pirozpur Union Parishad lies on the western bank of the Meghna and is
roughly bisected by the Dhaka to Chittagong Highway. Comilla Division begins on the other
side of the Meghna. Meghnaghat itself is the old ferry station on the Dhaka-Cornilla-Chittagong
Highway, the ferry having been replaced by the high level Meghna River Bridge in 1997. Given
its relative proximity to Dhaka and locus on the highway, Meghnaghat also serves as a river port
and landing, principally for bulk cargoes. (See Map: Plane Table Survey, Scale 1: 10,000.)
The project lies in a region undergoing transition from a largely agrarian economy, based on
paddy cultivation, to a mixed economy, which includes growing business and industry, and the
local bazaar and small business development that is a spin off of these changes. The presence of
the main highway and ferry ghat meant the development of some bazaar and small service
enterprises over the years, but the recent improvement of highway communications and filling up
-       of industrial sites farther west along the Sita Lakhya has engendered considerable industrial
development on both sides of the river at Meghnaghat.
Agriculture and fishing, the foundations of the traditional peasant economy of the site and still
the key livelihoods of the local population, remain important, but both have lost somewhat in the
present scheme of things: fishing because of the impacts of industrial pollutants, and agriculture
due to the loss of cultivable land. While this kind of development does have negative impacts on
land and water resources, particularly if not properly mitigated, the positive aspects of
industrialization should not be ignored, providing as it does higher incomes and new
opportunities to those fortunate enough to find work in this sector.
The project site is on a riverain island (char), marginal agricultural land that remains submerged
during the summer monsoon and only fully emerges during the winter low flow period. The
boundary of the project site begins about half a kilometer below the old Meghnaghat jetty, on the
west (right) bank of the main Meghna Channel and extends another 680 meters down along the
river bank. The entire site is 254 acres, of which 145.5 acres is privately held, 85.3 is
government-owned (kas), and the remainder (13.3 acres) is being created out of the river as the
whole site is raised some 8 meters above the current high point. The AES Meghnaghat Power
Project is the first of three projects planned for the larger site, which also will include the
Metering Station (RMS) for the gas supply and the corridor for the cooling water channel. The
latter two facilities eventually will serve all three power plants. Additional land is being
acquired for the access road, also for the whole site. The AES MPP site will itself encompass 62
acres.
1



/
1.1.1       Historical Significance
lThe locale surrounding the site for the AES Meghnaghat Power Station is in the heartland of the
Bengal Delta, an area intimately connected with key centers of political and economic power
from pre-Muslim times to the present. The proximity of Sonargaon, only four kilometers north
of the site, and of Dhaka, some 22 kilometers to the north-west, places the Meghnaghat area well
within the orbit of those states that dominated the central delta region and which, from time to
time, extended their sway throughout much of the area of contemporary Bangladesh and beyond.
Founded by the Hindu Sena dynasty, Sonargaon became the third great capital of Bengal, and
remained the commercial and cultural hub of Bengal until 1612, when the Mughals shifted the
capital of their Bengal Suba to Dhaka. Sonargaon had become a Muslim capital in 1281, when
the Senas surrendered to Sultan Balban of the Dehli Sultanate. In 1542, the great Sher Shah Suri
made it the eastern terminus of the Grand Trunk Road.
Although Sonargaon declined after 1612, enough remains of architectural and archaeological
treasures-palaces, fortresses, sufi shrines, bridges--to firmly establish the cultural brilliance of
Sonargoan, particularly under Isa Khan, whose political antecedents were spun off from the
Suns, and whose architectural contributions are especially significant. Reports by Arab (Ibn
Batuta), Chinese, and European travelers attest to the commercial and cultural importance of
Sonargaon, and to the extraordinary wealth of its political and conmmercial classes. Musa Khan,
son of Isa Khan, was the last independent Muslim ruler in central Bengal. For much of his reign,
he fought a series of land and naval battles in and around the Dhaka region, eventually ending in
a last stand along the line of the Sita Lakhya River. He submitted to the Mughal Govemor,
Ismail Khan Chishti, in 1611, clearing the way for the Mughals to consolidate their hold on
central Bengal during the emperorship of Jahangir.  (See: AES Meghnaghat Limited,
CULTURAL AND ARCHEOLOGY SURVEY, Ten Km Radius Around Proposed Project Site,
DPC Group of Consultants, Dhaka, 1 September 1999.)
Although somewhat eclipsed by the shift, under the British, of political and industrial power to
Calcutta in the western margin of the delta, Dhaka remained the major urban center in eastern
Bengal. The region regained its importance with independence in 1947, but even more so after
the Liberation War in 1971, when Dhaka became the capital of independent Bangladesh. The
project region has benefited from subsequent development efforts, such as the upgrading of
roads, construction of bridges, and spread of industry, as well the development of social and
human resources.
Clearly, the Dhaka to Chittagong Highway is a major asset in the project region, wherein, one
presumes, transportation has long been a key economic activity. The Meghna has always been a
major transportation waterway between the Sonargaon/Dhaka area and Chittagong. In the mid-
fourteenth century, Ibn Batuta sailed up the Meghna on his way to meet the great sufi saint,
Sayyid Jalal, at Sylhet, stopping at Sonargaon on his way back to board a vessel for Java.
Rennells map and road survey of 1778 clearly shows the Dhaka-Comilla Road aligned through
the project region. Upgraded over the years, this road is now the major transportation link
2



between Chittagong and Dhaka. In the past decade, the ferry ghats at the Sita Lakhya and
Meghnaghat crossings have been replaced by modem, high level road bridges. Further, with the
crowding out of both banks of the Sita Lakhya, new industry has been moving to Meghnaghat,
and even across the river.
1.2         Land and Water: Characteristics of the Project Area
The actual project site is on a riverain island (char), Char Ramzan Sonaullah, located between
the main channel of the Meghna River to the east and two side channels of the river to the west.
(See Map: Plane Table Survey, Scale 1:10,000). Although some erosion is visible along the
bank at Islampur, Char Ramzan Sonaullah is a relatively old and stable island. In this the middle
reach of the Meghna, between Bhairab Bazaar some 65 km upstream and the downstream
confluences with the Dhaleswari and Padma, the Meghna is a meandering and braided stream,
between six to twelve kilometers wide and consisting of numerous channels and islands. These
channels and islands are stable and the river banks low and shelving.
This has been the case since the period 1780 to 1830, when the Brahmaputra shifted its main
channel to the Jamuna stream, which flows into the Ganga/Padma west of Dhaka. Today, the
Old Brahmaputra still carries part of the flood overflow of the Jamuna down to its confluence
with the Meghna at Bhairab, but generally the Meghna bears very little silt and is a much clearer
stream than the silt-laden Dhaleswari and Padma Rivers. Moreover, in contrast to the Jamuna,
where erosion is severe and chars highly unstable, the Meghna is a quieter river, flowing in a bed
formed well in the past by the much larger Brahmaputra. Erosion and deposition do occur, but it
is a slower process along the Meghna. These conditions make the Meghna the most important
fish spawning grounds in Bangladesh, although, according to local fisher folk, this historically
rich resource is beginning to be affected by industrial pollution.
Human life in the project area long ago adjusted to the annual cycle of summer inundation, often
in quite complex ways. The project site itself (Char Ramzan Sonaullah), the low lying paddy
lands along the side channels of the Meghna, and extensive areas leading father inland beyond
the line of villages (Dudhghata, Kurbanpur) along the westernmost branch of the Meghna, are
flooded for anywhere from four to nine months of the year, depending on the strength of the
sumnmer monsoon and the height of the land. The villages are built on platforms a few feet above
the normal high inundation level, anchored by trees and other vegetation. These undoubtedly
were raised by hand filling long ago, a process still visible where new residential or bazaar land
is being created or older land needs repair. The village platforms provide space for houses, sheds
for cattle, kitchen gardens, medicinal plants, fruit trees, small orchards, a local market, schools
and other public buildings. In this region, a flood means the village platforms themselves go
under water, which forces the people onto their roofs or over to the main highway, which is built
on the highest embankment in the area.
Traditionally, the major economic activity outside the village during the summer inundation was
fishing. According to local informants, fish were plentiful year round until a few years ago, so
much so that fish for a meal could be caught quickly from the nearest water body. Now, fishing
takes more time and requires covering larger areas, even for those households simply looking to
3



supplement their diets. In addition, the whole socio-economic structure of the traditional fishing
communities was wrecked by the now defunct franchising system and has yet to fully recover.
Once the inundation begins to recede, the major traditional occupation is paddy cultivation.
Most of the rice cultivation in the project area is irri boro paddy, both the varieties sown on soft
land and those transplanted from nurseries. The land is not suitable for aus paddy, which is
grown on higher ground not normally inundated, but there is some cultivation of long-stemmed
aman varieties (for example, irri paijung) on the lowest paddy land. There are many varieties of
these three categories of paddy, each fitted for particular soil and water conditions--a rich
resource of plant genetic types. At one time a major crop, comparable in importance to paddy,
jute is cultivated less frequently now, as synthetics have reduced the world-wide demand for jute
products.
Paddy is supplemented by wheat, but more land and effort is put into pulses, oil seeds, and
vegetables, all marketable if production exceeds household use. Fodders are not normally
grown, but are harvested from water bodies--mainly water hyacinth. The paddy stalks also are
fed to cattle. Fuel wood is gathered by combing orchards and other trees in the villages.
Villagers also harvest a woody plant (dhaniancha) that grows in the shallows all along the
Meghna and dry it in the eves.
On Char Ramzan Sonaullah, according to informants, the farmers planted irri boro paddy or
wheat as the crown of the island emerged from the descending water, and irri aman paddy when
the river reached its lowest level in December. In between the two paddy crops were vegetables,
pulses, oil seeds, and increasingly in recent years, ground nuts. In many cases, landholdings on
the char were narrow strips running vertically across the island, from the river side to the inland
channel side. Where this was not the case, farmers held separate plots in various parts of the
char, giving them access to different levels. This enabled farmers to cultivate on the crown and
down both sides of the char as the waters receded and the season progressed--at least in this
aspect, a remarkably equitable arrangement. All of this is gone now, as the site is being prepared
by filling for the construction of the Meghnaghat power projects. The last crops were harvested
in March 1999.
Apart from the strip of houses at Islampur, excluded from the project site, Char Ramzan
Sonaullah was uninhabited. Most of the land was owned or leased by inhabitants of the
surrounding villages, some of which (Islarnpur, Ganganagar, Jauchar, etc.) are in the revenue
estate (mauza) of Char Rarnzan Sonaullah, but away from the project site. Other formner
owners/leaseholders are from surrounding mauzas, Dudhghata (includes Korbanpur), which lies
west across the Meghna side channels, Asharia Char, and Char Bhabanathpur. (See Map: Plane
Table Survey, Scale 1:10,000)
1.3         Socio-Economy: The 1991 Census
The most recent aggregate data on the area, the 1991 Census, albeit now somewhat dated, gives a
reasonably accurate baseline from which to judge current social conditions and trends,
particularly when the 1991 data is compared to that of the project Socio-Economic Survey
(SES), conducted in August 1999 (see below). The 1991 Census was done prior to the         )
4



completion of the high level Meghna River Bridge, probably the major event affecting the
Pirozpur Union Parishad in the past decade.
Made up of 21 mauzas (revenue villages or estates), Pirozpur Union Parishad had a population of
25,817 in 1991, 53.2 percent of which were males. This latter is a fairly standard sex ratio for
Bangladesh. The aggregate literacy rate in the Pirozpur UP of those seven or older was 28.0
percent (35.5 percent for males and 19.7 percent for females). In mohallahs of Char Ramzan
Sonaullah (Jauchar, Protaper Char, Ganganagar, Islampur, Kadigaon) the literacy rate was 26.1
(31.2 for males; 17.6 for females. These literacy rates for a rural area can be contrasted to those
of urban Narayanganj, the District Headquarters and the country's largest inland river port, where
the overall literacy rate was 49.6 percent (55.4 for males, 41.8 for females). The highest rates in
the district were in the Municipality Area of Narayanganj: 60.2 percent overall, with 65.2 percent
for males and 53.5 percent for females.
Other indicators in the 1991 Census show that Pirozpur Union Parishad had reached at least a
middling level of prosperity within the Bangladesh rural context. Although the Census did not
record household income data, one rule of thumb used in Bangladesh to gauge the general level
of rural development is the material quality of roofs. One of the first investments households
usually make as they rise on the socio-economic ladder is in their dwellings. Of the 4,113
houses in the Union Parishad in 1991, 480 (11.7 percent) had old style straw or bamboo roofs,
indicating relative income stagnation and poverty, while only 39 (0.95 percent) had expensive
cement roofs. The largest group of 3594 dwellings (87.4 percent) had roofs of tile, tin, or CI
sheeting, materials which indicate a good step up from the least expensive forms of house
construction.
The occupational structure evident in the 1991 Census also suggests a rural area on the verge of
transition to a more multi-sectoral local economy, although these trends are more evident in the
1999 SES. Table One provides occupational data for 1991 for those actually working, 12,470
individuals out of a work force of 16,080, or 77.5 percent. The non-working 22.5 percent largely
reflects the unemployed, but also includes the elderly and the infirm.

Table One shows the salience of four occupations: household work for the women, and, for the
men, agriculture, transportation and communications, and business. A fifth occupation, fishing,
is not listed separately and presumably comes under "other." These are primary occupations.
Undoubtedly many, probably most, worked in other areas: women in the house and in some
agricultural chores, men supplementing agriculture with fishing or day labor, or visa versa. In
this context, business largely means shop-keeping in the small village bazaars and along the
main highway. Pirozpur, Char Goaladi and Asharia Char are close to the main road, while
Dudhghata is a large village off the main highway, to which it recently has been connected by a
small district road. The very small numbers engaged in industry and construction suggest that
industrial development and the construction of the Meghna River Bridge had yet to occur. The
large number of workers in transportation living in the villages of Char Ramzan Sonaullah
reflects the riverside position of these villages and the involvement of many residents in loading
and unloading and transport up and down the river, and across, using small and medium country
boats.
1.4            Project Socio-Economic Survey (SES)
The socio-economic survey for the AES Meghnaghat Power Project was carried out in six
villages surrounding the project site in August 1999. Two of these, Islampur and Ganganagar
are in the same revenue estate (mauza) as the project, Char Ramzan Sonaullah. Two others,
Dudhghata and Kurbanpur are in the mauza of Dudhghata, while Pachari (Pachani) and Char
Goaldi, are separate mauzas. In all, sixty households were surveyed, ten in each village. The
sample size was determined due to considerations of time and other constraints. In order to
ensure representativeness of the sample, however, a complete household census was undertaken
in each village. The largest was found to be Dudhghata with 425 households (338 in the 1991
Census) and Ganganagar the smallest with 70 households (58 in the 1991 Census). Despite an
attempt to make the sample representative, the data do suggest a slight skewing of the sample to



J     middle and higher income groups. Keeping this in mind, the SES data, backed by field
interviews, is useful in presenting current conditions and trends in the Project area.
IA.1        Demography and Social Structure
Household Size and Sex Ratio. According to the sample, the average household size is 5.68
persons in the villages surrounding the project site. The proportion of male to female is: 52.5%
to 47.5%, respectively. This is a slightly smaller ratio than that reported in the 1991 Census (53.2
for males.) Female infanticide does occur in the rural areas, but is not a major problem. The
data show that females suffer at both extremes of the age tree, probably because boys are favored
with better food and medical care in infancy, while women seem to die at younger ages than men
in Bangladesh. Large household size is not unusual for Bangladesh, although the sample size is
lower than that reported for Pirozpur Union in the 1991 Census (6.22 persons per household). In
the SES sample, the proportion of children (below 15 years old)--37.6 percent--is considerably
lower than the 49.8 percent for this age set reported in the 1991 Census. Even accounting for the
smallness of the sample, these figures--average household size and percent of children could
indicate that population growth is slowing in the project region. The proportion of the old people
aged more than 45 years is 16%.

Literacy. Based on data for educational level in the SES, literacy in the project area appears to
be relatively better than that in the nation as a whole, where more than 40 percent are regarded as
illiterate. In the project area sample, only 24 percent cannot read or write and have no schooling.
Fully 75.5 percent of the sample have schooling. Some 24.3 percent have completed secondary
school (High School), while 4.3 have gone on to higher education. These figures are quite high,
when compared to the 28.0 percent literacy for Pirozpur Union Parishad reported in the 1991
Census. Undoubtedly education and literacy have increased in the past decade, though these
high rates probably reflect socio-economic changes in the project area, as well as a slight
skewing of the SES sample toward middle and higher income groups.

Community. The project site lies in a region that still reflects the character of traditional
Bangladeshi rural society. The countryside lacks a true aristocracy or an extended, pyramidal
social hierarchy. The abrogation of the land system inherited under the Permanent Settlement,
the migration of the Hindu zamindars to India half a century ago, and various land reforms since
independence have produced a pattem of small ownership, albeit one which shows considerable
variation within its own narrow limits. Although in no sense a feudal system, kinship identities
and patron-clientism are key elements in the local social and political order. The structure of
local society remains relatively flat, or at least rounded. There most certainly are income
disparities in the villages, but these are neither massive nor of the kind that cut off the wealthier
groups from their roots. Local leadership rises out of lineages that use land, commercial
interests, and access to the administration to build patron-client followings. For the most part, in
Bangladesh, a strong sense of social responsibility informs leading lineages. Many local schools,
madrassahs, dispensaries, and orphanages are founded by powerful patrons and influential
kinship networks.
Set up for administrative purposes, the mnauza, or village revenue estate, is an artificial
jurisdiction and does not reflect a composite community in the rural order. Of far more
importance are the actual residential communities (gram), of which there may be five or six
within the boundaries of the mauza. Each village (gram) consists of traditional territorial
subdivisions like para (neighborhood, also called mohallah), and customary social institutions,
namely: gushti (lineage) and samaj (community). Dudhghata, for example, has seven paras:
Purbapara, Sharkerpara, Bhuiyapara, Sikdarpara, Fakirpara, Sarderpara and Madhyapara. In
these seven paras there are nine lineages. For the most part, each para shelters its own gushti--  S
as in Bhuiyapara for the Bhuiyan Gushti, although in this village two additional lineages are
located in several paras.
For the most part, each gushti has an organization, the samaj, which oversees the range of
customary obligations and serves as a forum for the settlement of disputes. The samaj is
composed of respected seniors and notables and operates informally and by consenus. The
samaj usually has a leader, who can render commanding influence on the members. Some
important samaj leaders in this village include Sirajul Haque Bhuiyan, who is Chairman of the
Pirozpur Union Council, Mostafa Mollah and others. In Bangladesh the role of community
leaders is quite significant, particularly in regard to local social control, political influence, and
the provision of patronage. A consolidated table is presented below to depict the community
profile. (For more detailed information, see: AES Meghnaghat Limited, COMMUNlTY
PROFILE SURVEY: Six Villages Near the Proposed Project Site, DPC Group of Consultants,
Dhaka, 4 September 1999.)

Summer Inundation and Flooding. The project region is subject to summer inundation, the
seasonal phenomenon that dominates the agrarian economy and cultural calendar. The
inundation is a normal occurrence and can be distinguished from a "flood," the latter occurring
when water invades the villages. In normal years, about 10% of the households, those located on
the village fringes come under flood. In 1998, Bangladesh experienced severe flooding over
much of the country, including along the Meghna. More than 91% village households came
under waist deep water.  Village connector roads were inundated, disrupting the local
communication network.
As noted above, erosion along the Meghna River is not a severe problem in the macro sense, but
it does occur and it does, at times, destroy village lands and habitations. The worst hit areas are
actually along tributaries like the Gumti, which flow out of the Chittagong and Tripura Hills into
the Meghna. Villages like Islampur are partly inhabited by people resettled from land lost to
erosion, as are the settlers who leased the govemment land (kas), now taken for the project.
1.4.2       Economy
Land Ownership. Based on the SES, small land owners predominate in the village landholding
structure. The largest proportion own less than 50 decimals (0.5 acre: 1 acre equals 100
decimals), many of these holding very small plots. It should be noted, however, that most of the
households in the SES sample do not depend on agriculture for most of their livelihood. Only
8.3% households in the survey own more than 100 decimals but none owns more than 300
decimals. As noted from field interviews, however, there are a few land owners in the area who
have more than 300 decimals. According to the SES, average land ownership in the project area
is 43.63 decimals.
