Livestock. In addition to cultivation, some 38% of households own cattle and water buffalo. The
average of livestock per household is 2.72, according to the SES. Water buffalo, of course, are
perfectly adapted to the local environment and are common. Cattle are more sedentary during
the inundation season, when they are fed the water hyacinth (kochuri, panah), but are herded  I
through the paddy fields after harvesting in the dry season to browse on the stubble. Goats also
are raised, including the highly productive Bengal Black Goat. Poultry is common, with 58%
households raising chickens and owning, on average, 6.34 adult chickens. Domesticated ducks
also are common in the riverain environment. Cattle and poultry-raising have been promoted by
the Grameen Bank.
Incomes and Wage Data. Income and wage data in the SES suggest the project area people have
acceptable incomes. Only 1.7 percent of the households surveyed annually earn less than Taka
15,000 per year, the presumptive poverty line in Bangladesh. (The Bangladesh Institute for
Development Studies puts the poverty line at Tk 15,000/year for a four person household; the
Bangladesh Bureau of Statistics puts it at Tk 12,000/year.) Some 20 percent of the households
have annual incomes between 15,000 and 25,000, which can be described as "subsistence plus."
The next income group, earns 25,000 to 40,000 a year and constitutes 25 percent of the sample.
This group is "making it" economically. Those households earning between 40,000 and 60,000,
or 21.7 percent of the sample, can afford some amenities, while the next group, 60,000 to
100,000, or 10 percent of the sample, can be described as "comfortable." Those few households
earning more than Tk 100,000/year are "well-off."

Housine. Most houses in the SES (90%) are built of tin. Most of these are built entirely of tin,
although 5% have brick walls and tin roofs. There are some entirely mud houses (1.7%). The
preponderance of tin structures indicates that the residents of these villages are relatively better
off than other villages where bamboo thatched houses predominate.
Starvation. In rural Bangladesh starvation--the non-consumption of food for at least a day--is a
feature of the poverty situation. Meghnaghat villages are no exception although the incidence is
low. Only 20% households have reported they had experienced starvation in the last seven days
prior to the interview. More than 81% households said they took fish in the seven days
immediately prior to the interview. This is also a sign that fishing in the area still provides a
food safety net for local people.
1.4.3        Agriculture
Plots and hrrigation. Agriculture remains a major part of the local economy. It has declined only
in relative importance, due to industrialization and the lost of cultivable land, but has only
marginally diminished in real terms. The land is fertile, gaining at least some alluvial deposition
on the inland channels and paddy areas. Areas along the main channel, such as Char Ramzan
Sonaullah, often receive more sand than alluvium from the river. More than 48.59% of the
agricultural land owned by the households surveyed in the SES is located in the villages of
residence, meaning paddy land proximate to the residential area, while the rest is outside the
village, though it may still be within the common mauza.
More than 67% of cultivable land is under mechanised irrigation during the dry season,
indicating a fair spread of irrigation compared to the national average (not more than 40%). The
rest is irrigated by traditional methods (swing basket and others). In mechanised irrigation, the
low lift pump or surface water irrigation are the most popular technologies, followed by shallow
tube well and deep tube well ground water irrigation. The higher incidence of surface water
irrigation results from the proximity of river. Deep tube well irrigation is used on only about 10
percent of the irrigated area, as other methods are more cost effective.
13



Location of Agricultural Plots
51.41
48.59
h village       Outsde village
Crovping Pattern and Yield. Paddy is the most extensively cultivated crop in the Project region.
More than 88% of cultivable land is devoted to paddy during the winter-spring season. Paddy is
followed in importance by wheat (20.8% of multi-seasonal cropping area), oil seeds (20.7%),
vegetables (18.5%) and jute (9.0%). Most produce is consumed in the home. On an average,
according to the SES survey, local farmers market the surplus. This amounts to 28 percent each
of paddy and wheat, 12 percent of oil seeds, 26 percent of vegetables, and 82 percent of jute.
Crop yields in the Project area range from average to high. The output of paddy is 23 kilograms
per decimal. This is a little above the national average. Wheat production is 31 kg per decimal,
a high yield. Oil seeds are produced at an average of 32.7 kg per decimal of land, a satisfactory
result The vegetable yield is 40 kg/decimal, and jute is 23 kg/decimal. These averages for the
area show the land is fertile and more productive than average in the country.
1A.4        Fishing
Despite annual declines in the overall catch, the middle reach of the Meghna River remains a
major fishing area and an important resource to the local economy. Based on field interviews, it
is apparent that many households do some fishing, the majority to supplement fish purchased in
the market for household consumption. In the Project SES, more than twenty percent of
households depend entirely on the river for fish, at least half of these being traditional fisherfolk,
who catch both for household consumption and the market.
During the monsoon season, Char Ramzan Sonaullah was an important fishing ground for local
villagers. This included both jhal (net) and jhop (trap) fishing. According to field interviews
with women, fishing around the char could bring in from Taka 300 to 500 per day, when
marketed. The jhop is a loose enclosure in the water, constructed of bamboo and other sticks.
Branches are thrown into the enclosure, which creates a spawning area and attracts fish. After
the fish arrive, the enclosure barrier is thickened and made more secure. Building the jhop
14



enclosure is a joint effort, wherein the catch is shared out. In Dudhghata, according to field
interviews, about 100 persons were involved in summerjhop operations on five favored sites
around Char Ramzan Sonaullah. The fish were harvested three times during the inundation
months, bringing in Taka 70,000 to 80,000 each time.
1.4.5       Health and Leisure
Infant and Maternal Mortality. According to the Project SES, both infant and maternal mortality
is minimal in the surveyed villages. Infant (under 5) mortality is only 1.7% in the last year
(1998) and same is given for maternal mortality at the time of delivery. Both figures strongly
indicate a satisfactory situation with regard to MCH-FP and the immunization program.
Source of food. Although many households derive paddy, wheat, vegetables and other food
stuffs from their own fields, they still depend on the market to purchase food. More than 63%
households obtain rice from the market, more than 91% households obtain vegetables from the
market, and, for 70% of households, the market is the source of fish. However, 21.7%
households completely depend on river for fish. Market purchases show that the local
population is not self-sufficient on their own lands and that cash from previous sale of produce
and from non-agricultural work by household members is available when specific needs arise.
Modes of treatment. According to the SES, local people seek medical attention from both
modem and traditional sources, a practice called "medial pluralism."  More than 76.0%
respondents report they have visited hospital in the past year to seek treatment, while 43.3%
report visiting folk healer. There are many over-lapping cases combining modern and traditional
treatment, as well as more than one source of medical assistance. In the rural market centers,
compounders in medical stores give medical advice, while a number of paramedics still practice
in the project area. These are individuals given a short course in medicine and sent into the rural
areas--a program (Pallichi Krishak) that is now ended.
Households' Source of Drinking Water and Sanitation Type
33.3
From Hand Tubewell     Using Slab Latrine



Source of Drinking Water and Sanitation. More than 91% of households use hand tube well to
obtain drinking water, according to the SES. This indicates the existence of health awareness.
On the other hand, only 33.3% households use slab latrines for the purpose of sanitation showing
a large proportion do not follow hygienic defecation practices.
Use of Contraceptives. Some 51.7 percent of married couples use contraception, a rate that is
slightly less than the national average. Among the different methods cited in the SES the pill is
the most popular, followed by the condom, tubectomy, and others.
Leisure. Villagers spend their leisure time mostly in gossiping, visiting neighbours or sitting in
the village tea stalls. Almost 90% report spending leisure time in the above way. Many of them-
-about 50 percent--also watch television or listen to the radio. There is considerable mobility for
males around the region. Women generally stay closer to home, although they do travel for
weddings and visits to the doctor.
1.4.6       Social Support
Association with NGOs. Many of the surveyed households are associated with the support from
NGOs. Some 25% have received low interest loans from different NGOs. A smaller number,
however, has received skill training--only 10%.
Loan from Other Banks. Apart from NGOs, villagers also take loans from commercial banks, a
more expensive proposition as these are given at commercial rates. About 20% households
report obtaining a loan from this source. Loans also can be taken from moneylenders in the
bazaar, usually a wealthy merchant. These "informal" loans carry a far higher interest rate and
are avoided by local people except in cases of immediate need or dire emergency.
1.4.7       Attitude to the power plant
Information and Attitude. Some 85% of households in the survey have heard of the Meghnaghat
Power Project. This is not surprising, as the site is being filled, involving the mobilization of
large equipment and many workers, and the displacement of cultivators and fishermen. Most
villagers (75%) think the upcoming plant will not affect them.

1A4.8       SES Conclusions
w       Meghnaghat villages are, within the Bangladesh paradigm, relatively prosperous and exposed to
urban influences. The literacy rate is high for a rural area and access to salaried jobs is
spreading. The average income is well above the national average for rural areas, although there
are local variations and a strata of very poor households, albeit a remarkably small one in this
area. Although the small agricultural holding is the norm, modem technology is prevalent,
suggesting a household capacity for savings and investment. Infant mortality is low. Open
sanitation is a problem and probably causes some morbidity among those households that lack
hand pumps on deep wells for drinking water. Future intervention to improve sanitation
facilities and practices may be indicated.
1i          Local Industrial Development
Meghnaghat is a rapidly growing industrial site with development on both sides of the river.
This development started a decade ago. Currently, there are eight rnid-sized industries on the
west bank, employing a total of about 11,000 people. In addition, two factories are under
construction, one for edible oils, the other for United Cement, while at least two factories are
planned, one for Meghna Sugar Ltd., and one a chemical plant for Prime PET Meghna
Industries. Industrial wages are standard for the Dhaka region, at Taka 120/day for unskilled
labor, and an average of Taka 400/day for skilled workers. Working a six day week, an unskilled
worker can make more than Taka 35,000 a year--well above the poverty line--and a skilled
worker can make close to Taka 125,000 a year--a very respectable income. Factory managers
say they can employ more people, provided a reliable power supply is achieved. Currently,
power cuts run from five to six hours in a twenty-four hour period.
17



Despite the benefits of industrialization, local leaders and people say they are not getting an
equitable share in local jobs and want more. As Table Four shows, only 683 or 6.3 percent of
factory workers at Meghnaghat are local. Most of the workers come from outside--from
Narayanganj, Dhaka, and Comilla--, and commute to work daily or rent locally. Labor
syndicates and other networks bring their own people to Meghnaghat. Factory managers train
their work forces both elsewhere and on the job. Local leaders admit that local people lack
skills, but they point out that their own literate youths are just as trainable as outsiders and want
to see a larger share of factory jobs go to locals. Only in the garment factory, is there a major
segment from the Project area, although even here the majority are from the outside. This is

interesting, as, for cultural reasons, village women would not travel very far for work. The large
number of outsiders here suggests a limited local supply of female labor--not all men allow their
womenfolk to work in this kind of environment--and hence the need to recruit outsiders,
probably largely from urban areas. The women who work at Hyundai Cement belong to the
traditional river boat communities, that work up an down the river, often in hard labor and
construction activities.
18



1.6         Women in the Project Area
By far, the majority of women in the Project area remain encompassed within the household, an
arena still thoroughly regulated by custom and devoted to domestic work and the raising of
children. (See Tables One and Two.) Purdah in the form of strict veiling does not have a strong
hold in the area, although women lack mobility and expeditions outside the home usually require
permission from the head of the household. There is a strong assumption of female modesty and
a consciousness that this is a requirement of Islam. According to field interviews and the
affectee women's focus group session, women do have important roles in the agrarian cycle,
particularly in the care of kitchen gardens, seeds and seed beds, and the processing of paddy
when it is brought in from the fields. These functions are undertaken in the home and women of
the affectee households say they did not visit the char area during the period of cultivation.
Women do not claim to have a role in family decision-making, but their knowledge of the crop
cycle and fishing arrangements indicate otherwise.
Despite a tendency to repeat the conventional view, times are changing for women. Education
and access to credit, the latter provided by organizations like the Grameen Bank and Association
for Social Advancement (ASA), are enhancing the capabilities and roles of women. Literacy and
college attendance are far higher today than a decade ago. Based on the SES, primary school
attendance for girls is nearly universal. Moreover, adult literacy prograns are assisting older
women who bypassed school in their youth to gain at least a smattering of literacy. Of the 46
women who attended the focus group session, only 6 could not write their own name. The fact
that 189 local women work in the garment factory is a significant figure, although for now there
is a reluctance to admit this, perhaps because this kind of factory work is still regarded as
unconventional, suspect, and injurious to their reputations.
1.7         Social Impact Assessment
1.7.1       Regional Impacts
The AES Meghnaghat Power Project is being located in a region already well advanced in
transition from a rural, agrarian system, dominated by its proximity to the Meghna River, to one
increasingly affected by industrial development, with all that that brings in terms of social
change, new job opportunities for some and impoverishment for others. Other than in a general
way, it is not possible to quantify the degree to which the MPP will enhance those processes
already underway. The fact that the plant will not employ a large number of workers suggests
that in some ways the MPP will have a smaller effect than new industries employing several
hundred. Moreover, the plant will not supply power directly to local customers, but will route its
output to the national grid, so that local industries will benefit from increased power generation
only to the extent that the distribution system provides an enhanced supply.
Nonetheless, the MPP is part of the industrialization of the region and has a role in the changes
affecting the region. The most salient of these general changes are as follows:
* Migration. More than 1 0,000 people already have migrated into the region in the past
decade, some to work on the construction of the Meghna River Bridge, but most to
19



work in the new industries. This does not include the numbers coming in to work on
the construction of the project site. The arrival of this number, even if many are
commuters, undoubtedly puts a strain on local infrastructure, housing, govemmental
institutions, and on the pre-existing fabric of social and political relations. "Outside"
interests, considerably more powerful than local groups have acquired a stake in the
Project area, undoubtedly to the disadvantage of the latter. Moreover, more people
means more unregulated development and more waste and pollution going onto the
land and into the river.
* Economic Opportunity. Clearly, the number of jobs being created in the Project area
is extraordinary. This includes tertiary economic opportunities in rentals and small
businesses spun off from the larger industrial development. While this has benefited
some local people, it is also evident that this positive development is limited and in
some ways negated by massive outsider control of new jobs. Local people feel
excluded from an, equitable share of factory jobs, and even more so from unskilled
and semi-skilled work in the initial construction of the Project itself. [Comment:
These next 2 sentences are obviously highly sensitive; wondering if we can edit or
tone down a bit, especially if/until we have a clear understanding of the resolution of
RAP issues? See conmments on last 2 paras (next page), as well. Had the land
acquisition and site and access road construction phases of the project been covered
by a Resettlement Action Plan, completed under nationally accepted guidelines,
project affected people (PAPs) would have been given priority in these jobs. So far in
the MPP, however, these jobs are controlled by a politically-connected syndicate
from Narayanganj, which has pushed the local people, including the PAPs, aside.]
*  Land Prices. One of the key impacts in the local region is the rapid increase in land
prices. Currently, the price for agricultural land in the project area is Taka 400,000
per kanni. (The kanni is the local unit of land measurement and constitutes 30
decimals, or .30 acre. It is a little smaller than a bigha, the more standard measure,
which is a third of an acre.) Engendered by industrial development, this land price
benefits those who have land, but it works to remove land from the agrarian land
market. Farmers who want to expand their agrarian holdings, or landless peasants
who find some means to step up to landownership, perhaps with money from earnings
abroad, will be excluded from buying land locally. Only business and commercial
investors will buy land at these prices. In effect, the land price rise creates a land
bank for industrial expansion and works against the retention of a healthy agrarian
sector in the Meghnaghat area.
1.7.2       Impacts on Land and Water Resources
{Comment: The following 2 paras seem to raise fairly critical issues about the RAPs themselves
and how we distinguish Phase 1 effects from those of whole site (Phases 1-3). I can foresee
issues from both sides, i.e. our project being 'saddled with' issues actually shared with 2na and
third phases; and inversely, our project making commitments or setting precedents that bind
20



future prts in some way. Does our study design/RAP process allow us to separate out such
effects in a way that will be equitable and defensible as possible for all involved parties?]
The withdrawal of 230.8 acres of seasonably cultivable land from the local agrarian economy
and destruction of a monsoon fishing ground already has reduced the livelihoods of more than a
thousand households. In the area set aside for the AES Meghnaghat Power Project, Phase One of
three phases, plus the access road and area for the demised water corridor, an area comprising
___acres, we estimate that almost a thousand households have been affected by the loss of at
least part of their land. Final data on land acquisition, compensation, and household incomes is
being collected and will be available in the Project's RESETTLEMENT ACTION PLAN (RAP),
currently under preparation.
At a community level, it seems clear that the loss of Char Ramzan Sonaullah has been a blow to
the local economies of at least six villages and to numerous households. The land was used for
the range of crops grown in the area: various types of paddy, vegetables for home consumption
and sale in the market, some grazing, and increasingly the ground nut as a cash crop. Cash
compensation for lost land, even if valued at true market rates and fully paid, is never an
adequate substitute for the loss of a permanent resource. Moreover, the value of the land as a
monsoon fishing ground usually is not factored into land valuation. All indications are, that the
submerged char was an important ground for fishing by net (ihal) and trap-farming (ihop). (See:
AES Meghnaghat, RESETTLEMENT ACTION PLAN, Appendix - below.)

All the villages are situated in Pirijpur Union Parishad under Sonargaon Thana of
Narayanganj district. There are three colleges, and 15 other educational institutions
(individual information are available in the data sheet provided) in or around the villages
of the project site area. Besides, there are several prayer houses made of corrugated iron
sheets (C.I.Sheets) in each village. Generally, each village is covered with greenery
(avenues of different trees, bamboo bushes) along with the vast tract of agricultural land
filled with green field of vegetables or crops almost the year round.
In each village, the head of each lineage controls over people of his own group. In
addition to that one man becomes head of each village by dint of his leadership capacity,
merit riches and support of the majority of the villagers.
In case of government administration at these village level, one man or woman may be
elected member of Union Parishad (Union Council, bottom level of Government
administration) from a ward (A block of Union Council) formed on the basis of
population of several villages. The elected member keeps proper and legal linkage with
the higher unit of administration like the Union Parishad and the Thana Parishad.

In case of population, the ratio of male and female is almost equal. The rate of literacy of
these villages ranges from 45% to 56%.
The mainstays of livelihood of the people of these villagers are 1) Agriculture, 2) Fishing,
and 3) Internal trade & commerce. The purchasing capacity of the villagers is decreasing
day by day due to low income or for want of work.
2.0 Sources of Data Collection
The data presented in the Profile was gathered from both the primary and secondary
sources. Among the secondary sources, Bangladesh Bureau of Statistics (BBS), Country
Series Narayanganj, 1994, LGED prepared Thana Maps (1994-1995) are the main
sources. The primary source is the surveyed data collected by the field mobilized to these
villages.
3.0 Survey Methodology:
Two survey teams were constituted to conduct the survey for the village community
profile. Each team went round each village and collected the required data as per the
questionnaire supplied to the team.
4.0 Survey Implementation
Each team members conducted group discussion with the heads of each lineage and
wrote down the information / data required for the purpose of the survey. The team
members went round each corner of each village for identification of the location and
name of physical, natural, social and educational infrastructure of the villages and noted
down these data in the questionnaire sheets. They also interviewed them about their
occupational and employment status and other related issues.
5.0 Time Period
The Profile survey was carried out during period from 25.July to 25 August, 1999.
6.0 Conclusion
The village profile as well as the settlement pattern is an integral part of our village/
community structure. In our village individual ancestral has been living for centuries and
keeping its own heredity from time immemorial. The greenery of the villages, avenues of
trees, scrubs meadows increase the beauty of nature and enliven the environment by
leaving / emitting oxygen into the air. The trees, plants and scrubs of the villages keep the
ecological balance that is very essential for human habitats, wild lives (Flora & Fauna),
livestock, aquatic animal & plants. Besides, birds are the natural wealth and they are
helpful and useful to us in many ways. Even the birds keep the environment clean by
eating dirty things.

Numerical Model Testing Report
Site    Preparation    Contract
Meghnaghat Combined Cycle Power Plant Project
1.  INTRODUCTION
1.1 Background
The Meghnaghat Combined Cycle Power Plant Project will be constructed on the Right
Bank of the Meghna River immediately downstream of the Meghna Brid2e. The power plant
site will be filled to a level of Im higher than the water level of I in 200 year flood. The
filling material is to be dredged from different borrow areas in the river. The embankunent
around the power plant site will be protected according to the Employer's Requirements. The
numerical model test is to determine the extent of local scouring near the Site. to predict
changes of erosion in the river channel caused by the site development and assess the impact
caused bv dredoing in various borrow areas.
1.2 Objectives
(I) To determine with the 2D  model the flo-w conditions for the embankment
protection. adjacent to the site of the power plant.
(2) To cany out an assessment of riverbed scouring distribution and local scourine
after the Site development with 2D sedimentation model.
(3) To estimate the effect of dredging in the Meghna River on river flow velocity
distribution.
1.3 Prospective Findings
(1) The change of typical velocity of the river flow in the river section of the site.
(2) The change of riverbed scouring in the river section of the power plant ste after the
project.
(3) The local scouring near the site.
1.4 Study Arem
The study area is the river section around the Power Plant Site. The Site will be located
on the Right Bank of the Meghna River. approximately I km downstream of the Meghna
China National Water Resourtes 3ad liydropower Engineering Corporation

2. DATA COLLECTION AND PROCESSING
The simulation analysis is based on the data provided by the Tender Documents and those
obtained by the contractor through additional investigation after award of the Contract.
2.1 Bathymetric Data
(1) On the basis of the bathymetric data of 27 Mleghna River cross-sections in Table
A of Appendix 3 of the Tender Document, we have obtained the bathymetric data
of the main river channel with interpolation method.
(2) According to the analysis of the 2D morphological model founded by the DHI in
the Appendix 5 of the Tender Document, we have obtained the essential data of
channel flooding boundaries near the upstream and downstream of the Mteghna
Bridge.
Bathymetric data used in the numerical model test is showvn in Figure 2. 1.
2. Hydrological Data
(I) Flow survey data in one cross-section (MPP-9) just upstream of the Ne2hna
Bridge collected on I August 1996 wvere supplied in Table B of Appendix 3. The
duration of the measurement was 13 hours. sufficient in covering one full tidal 9
cycle. Water level data at the same section were supplied too. Thes- data were
used for model calibration. For the locations of cross-sections surveved. see
Figure 2.2.
(2) Boundaries' hvdrolorical data were obtained from hourly water level data from
30 July 1996 to I August 1996 at the Meghna river, Baidver Bazar. Meghna
Ghat and downstream of Kalagachia, and calpulated by DHI's MIKCE I1 mode.
2.3 Sediment Data
According to the sorted out results of the river-bed material's samples supplied in
Appendix 6 of the Tender Document, the river-bed material in the main river channel is fine-
sand with d50 (the median grain size of the sediment in mm) of 0.1 2mm-0. Imm while the

1.5 Modeling tools
The computer-programme package developed on the basis of ADI is employed for this
numerical model testing. The package includes four parts. i.e. hydrodynamic model, sediment
transport model, river flow  model and erosion model. The programme package was
developed by CJhina Nanjing Hydratilic Research Itstitute .NHRI) and has been applied for
manv projects with satisfactory results.
The model system requires the following data:
(1) Bathymetric data (including river-bed deposition);
(2) Boundaries current or water level data and sediment concentration:
(3) Hydrological data for calibration:
(4) Design hydrological data;
(5) Information on the site location and size.

discharge Q = 1 9845m3 /s and water level 4= 6.63mPWfD. The Design Flood condition is
adopted for the scouring study. The instant simulation, wkhich gives the highest flow velocilt
near the site of the power plant, is selected and the velocitv distribution for the'c6ndition is
extracted and used in the assessment of scouring depth and scope.
The samne flood conditions have been applied in two layout arraneements of Borrow
Areas in order to determine the flow redistribution and analyze the effect of the power plant
site on stability of the river channel.

3.3 Calculation Procedurc
Equations (1). (2), (3), (4) and (5) are solved by adoptinz Alternating-Direction
Implicit (ADI) Method. The advection terms are solved by a third-order scheme: the diffusion
terms are solved by the central difference.
ADI is a world wide recognized method (Leendense. 1971) in river flow numerical
model simulation field. Since 1970s, it has been used for the numerical calculation of flow
while certain improvements have been made on case to case basis.
The submerging and emerging of tidal flats are simulated by adopting movable
boundar, conditions, the open and close of the boundaries are to be determined vhether the
local water depth is above or beloFy a threshold value (Ah).

3.5 Model Introduction
The 2D model's lengyth is l2km, width is 9km. and ordinate is east-north 'O degrees.
Meghna Ghat Power Plant site is approximately in the middle part of the model. Th- model
uses the square grid as calculation unit. The mesh size of the model &S =Orm. and the total
amount of the meshes is 43.200.
The following parameters are chosen for the model calculation. i.e. time steplength > t
20s. average roughness no = 0.01 5 and coefficient K = 0.01.
There are three open boundaries in the model. i.e. one upstream open boundarv and
two downstream open boundaries. The upstream boundary is controlled by flow disclharge
and the dowPnstrearn boundaries bv tidal levels.
The model used moving-boundary techniques to simulate the moving of flow on the
flood plains and the changing of water borderline.  Water depth A h=O. I m is ad6pted for
determination of the moving-boudary.
The model has been calibrated against flow conditions measured on I August 1996.
Data in Appendix 3 and 5 to the Tender Document provided by the client were used as
controlling information. For the discharge's and water level's calibration. the observation
data in cross-sections (MPP-9) upstream of the Meghna Bridge were applied. According to
the field investigation, the two channels on north of the site flow below a bridge on the
China Nitional Vater Resources and iHydrepower Engineering Corporation
Pagc I of 19 oaacs



Numcrical Model 1-est RepOn                                             Dcsign Documcnts
highway. Under normal conditions, the flow in the channels are negligible comparing agianst
that in the main river channel, even during flooding period with ove:r-bank flow, the flow
velocity in the channels is also marginal. Therefore, the model simplifies them as blind
creeks, which has little influence on flow calculation of the Meghna River. For the section of
the Meghna Bridge, the project is summarized according to layout of the bridge abutments so
as to guarantee good similarity between modeling flow and the natural flow.
3.6 Calibration Results
Figs. 3.1 and 3.2 give the calibration result of the 2D model for the side flow cross-
section (MPP-9) upstream of the Meghna Bridge and discharge process. Based on the
calculated value in the figure and measured value, and their changing tendencv. the two
values have a fairly good agreement, showino that the boundarv control in the model is
reliable and that the bed resistance coefficient determined bv the model is reasonable. The
model can thus be used for hydrodynamic calculations of related engineering problems.
Fi2. 3.3 shows the calibration result of the model for the instant flow regime of the
*Meghna River. Based on the velocity distribution in the figure, the protruding end on the
north bank of the Meehna Bridge causes the formation of a slow-velocitv area ai the
dowvnstream like a groin-protected area where the power plant is located. Besides. there is a
tributarv with a width of about 2OOm-300m located between the West Side of the proposed
plant site and a small char. connectino with the west channel. Based on the yelocitv
distribution of the area. it is clear that the tributary splits the flow of the river.
Due to the lack of measured sediment concentration data, the sediment movement in
the model can not be calibrated. After analyzing the characteristic particle size of some bed
load in the river charmel, it is found that the sediment movement in the main channel is ver;
strong, that the river bed can be easilv eroded awav andlor silted up, and that adjacent to the
river bank} there is covered with fine-grain sediment which is feature with. good erosion
resistance. Based on the above understanding, specific boundary conditions for the riverbed
in accordance with the conditions of the main channel and riverbank slopes have been
considered in the sediment simulation so as to achieve a reliable result.

5. Assessment of Project Simulation
5.1 Distribution of Cross-sectional Velocity and Changc of Rivcr Bed Elevation
Fig. 5.1(a) to Fig. 5.4(a) show the velocity distributions of Sections I, 2, 3 and 4 before
and after the project respectivelv; Fig. 5.1(b) to Fig.5.4 (b) demonstrate the variation of the
river bed elevation of each section. Based on the variation of each curve in these figures. the
following commnents/results can be obtained:
(1)  Under the action of the 50-year flood, in the-downstream nearby river reach of the
Meghna Bridge, the ma:;. velocity in the main charnel may reach about 1.9m/s
(cross-sections 1 and 2), and gradually decreases after passing the M4eghna Bridge
Section.
(2) Under the action of the 50-year flood. Scouring in the main channel is much more
serious (deep) than that adjacent to the riverbank. Without the site development
(natural condition), the scouring depth in the main river channel may reach 2-3m
(section 1) and the scourine at the char in the main channel of the river may reach
5-6m  (cross-sections 3 and 4) while the scnuriine near the river bank} is obviously
smaller.
(3) After the  site development is implemented. the  cross-sectional velocity
distributions have a tendency of the main stream of the river flow- shifting toward
left, it is especiallv obvious from cross-section 2 down2stream. Along with the
shifting of the main stream, the max. velocity of the mainstream increases to
certain extent. For example, the max. velocities at cross-sections 2. 3 and 4
increase about O.lm/s as compared with that without the site development. While
the velocity near the power plant site becomes smaller as compared with that
without the site development.
(4) The riverbed scouring depth at cross-sections I and 2 before and afte; the project
is almost the same. The riverbed scouring depth of cross-sections 3 and 4 adjacent
to the embankment is approximately the same as that before the project. The
scouring depth of the main channel increases obviouslv as compared with that
without the site development.
(5) Borrow Area B, located downstream of the power plant, produces a strong effect
on the velocitv distribution of Cross-sections 3 and 4 and on the scourine extent of
China National Water Resources and liydrupower Enoinecring Corporation



Nti,rcrical Modcl Tcst Repon                                                 Dcsimii Documents
the river bed, i.e. the flow  velocity in the west part of the two cross-sections
increases and so does the scouring depth: the flow velocity in the east part
decreases and so does the scouring depth. Borrow Areas A and A' do not bring
about much influence on the flow conditions and river-bed erosion in the main
channel.

Table 5.1 shows the computation result of riverbed scouring at different locations
adjacent to the embank-ment. It can be seen from the table that at the measuring points 4, 5
and 9, located adjacent to comers of t:;e embankmenlt. serious scouring may occur before
implementation of the site developnment. After the implementation of the site development.
the areas around,adjacent to the southwest and southeast corners of the embanklment are still
the deepest scoured areas. As for the places adjacent to the north pan of the west
embankment, there is almost no scouring either before or after the site development. But for
the central part of the south embankment (measuring points 6 and 7). over- I -ni-deep scouring
can be found before the site development, but after the site is completed, almost no scouringz
occurs there.

the dredging), after dredging(soil borrowing), no further scouring is found.
From Fig. 5.5 one can see even more clearly the local scouring distribution in the area
adjacent to the embankment. Profile A in the figure is 70m away from the boundary of the
south embankment, Profile B is 70m away from Profile A, Profile C is 70m away from
Profile B. and Profile D is 70m away from the wvest embankment boundary (see Fig.4.2).
It can be seen from the scouring distribution curves of the above four profiles under
various plans that:
(1) Under natural conditions (without the site development), the scouring depth of
Profiles A, B and C has a tendency of gradually decreasing- from upstream to
downstream. After the development of the power plant site, this tendency remains
almost unchanged, except for the decrease of the scouring scope.
(2) After the site development, the scouring near the east and west ends of the south
embankment is comparatively remarkable, and especially at the east end (upstream
end) of the south embankment, the max. scouring depth mav reach 2.5m at where
140m away from the embankment boundary (see Profile B), and the scouring
becomes even more deep where further outside.
(3) Scouring at the south part of the wvest embank-ment is obvious. and the max.
scouring depth there may reach 2m.
(4) The excavation at the Borrow Area B may lead to the increase of the river-bed
scouring depth adjacent to the south embankment.
The above shows that after the completion of the site development of the Meghna Ghat
Power Plant. under the action of the 50-vear flood. a comparatively obvious local scouring
will still occur in areas adjacent to the east and the west ends of the south embanknment. and
the max. scouring depth may reach 2.5m (about 140m away from the site boundary); the max.
scouring depth in the nearby area about 70m away from embank-ment boundary is generally
about I m; there occurs a 2-m-deep scoured pit near the south end of the west embankment.
Therefore, while considering the protection measures against the local scouring for the
embanklment, more attention should be paid to the east and the west ends of the embankment.
53 Analysis of Flow Regimc
Figs. 5.6 to 5.9 show the plane flow regime of the power plant site river section under
the design flood. Fig. 5.6 shows the flow regime without the site development while Figs 5.7
China Nationol lvater Resources and Hydropwecr Engineering Corporation
Page IS or 1 9 pagcs



Numerical Modcl Test Rcpon                                           I)csign Documents
to 5.9 show the flow regime for Plans 1, 2 and 3 respectively.
The comparison between the flow regime with the Plans and that without the site
development project indicate the following differences:
(1) Under natural conditions (without the site development), the flood from the
Meghna River runs through the Meghna Bridge with its main stream tending to
move westward, and some of the flood overflows over the shoal, at where the power
plant site is located, into the north channel. After implementation of the site
development, the flood will be forced to run downstream along the south
embanklment. After passing by the south end of the embankment, the flow tums
northwestward. Therefore, a significant change with respect to the hydrodvnamic
conditions in this area will occur, which will cause the change in river bed
configuration in this areas accordingly.
(2) As the backfill project of the power plant changes the flow-splitting environment.
the intensity of the split flow over the shoal to the south of a small char located in
the south of the power plant increases obviously and this split flow has a obvious
tendency of moving southward. The development of such dynamic flow conditions
will probably lead to the formation of a new tributary to the south of the small char.
(3) As being protected by the protruding area of the right abutment of the Meehna
Bridge. an eddv-flow area wNill be formed betwveen the right abutment of the brid2e
and the east embankment. which is conducive to siltation. Therefore. no obvious
scouring wvill occur in this area.
(4) After the site development, the water area to the north of the power plant becomes
almost stagnant, where siltation is unavoidable and no scouring mav happen.
6. CALCULATION AND ANALYSIS ON MODIFIED LAYOUT
6.1 Changes of the Plans
To reflect the latest modifications in the model testing, additional calculation and analysis
ave been conducted by taking account of changes in layout of borrow arcas and the
bathymetric data obtained through the contractor's bathymetric survey. The followinc two
additional plans are calculated and analyzed in the model test:
,lodified Plan 2(Plan 2'): the raised power plant site in combination of dredged borrow areas
China National Water Re5ources and tlydropower Encineerint Corporation
Pauc 16 orf 9pages
..



Numerical Model Tcst Reporu                                             Dcsign Documents
A, B and C (P.S.+A+B+C);
Modified Plan 3(Plan 3'): the raised power plant site in combination of dredged borrow areas
A, A' and C (P.S. +A+A'+C);
The average excavated depth in the borrow areas is 4m, and the modified lavout of the
borrow areas is shown in Fig. 6.1.
The calculation conditions for the modified plans are still the data in Table 4.1.
6.2 Distribution of Sectional Flow and Change of the Elevation of River-bed
Figs 6.2(a)-6.5(a) show the results of the sectional flow distributions for the modified
Plans and Figs.6.2(b)-6.5(b) show the results of elevation variation of the riverbed. From
these figures, it can be seen that:
(1) Velocity distribution of flow and elevation variation of section I are basicallv the
same as those of the original plan (Fig. 5.1), indicating chanee of location of the
borrow area does not affect flow and river-bed near the Meghna Bridge.
(2) Flow Velocity distribution at section 2 has little change as compared with the
original plan, while the riverbed elevation in the middle of the channel decreases
obviously affected by excavation in the Borrow 4 Area B (Plan 2 ).
(3) The modified Borrow Area A' may marginally increase flow velocity and scouring
depth in areas near the south embankment (see Figs. 6.4 &R 6.5).
6.3 Local Scouring adjacent to the Embankment
A comparison of Fig 6.6 and 5.5 shows that with modified borrow areas. local scouring near
the south embankment changes greatly. Dredging in area A-.A' may increase scourino of
riverbed, that of A+B may reduce scouring, especially for the southwest turminsg point of the
south embankment, Dredging of A+A' may lead to a scouring pit over 2m in depth.
6.4 Flow Regime for the Modified Plans
Figs. 6.7 and 6.8 show flow regime for the modified plans. The figures indicate the flow
velocity within all the borrow areas decrease a little (due to excavation), and those near the
area have some increases. Evacuation of the Borrow Area B has obvious effect on diversion
of the main channel and that of Area A' may increase flow velocity of the water area near the
site.

Numerical Model Tcst Repon                                            Design DocumenLs
The flow regimes of the river chlannel far away the sitc area are basically the sanme as the
calculation result of the original plans.
7.    Conclusion
According to the requirement of the Contract, a study on the river-bed stability after the
implementation of the Meghna Ghat Power Plant Site Project has been conducted by means
of a combined model system consisting of a 2-D unsteady flow model and a sedimentation
model: leading to the following findings:
(1) The 2-D unsteady flov model of the Meghna River, based on the data provided in
Appendixes 3 and 5 to the Tender Document. has been proved by the calibratior
test to be ideal in simulatinsg the flow Tegime and sediment movement in the
Meghna River and in conducting the computational study of the project options.
(2) Under 50-year-flood conditions, the natural scouring without implementation of
the site development simulated in the model shows that the scouring depth in the
main channel may reach 2-3m. that the scouring depth at the river-center shoal
mav reach as deep as 5-6m and that the scouring depth at the banak shoal is rather
small.
(3) After the implementation of the site development of the power plant. the main
stream of the river flow tends left bank- with its max. velocity increasin2 by about
0.1rn/s. At the same time. the velocitv distribution near the power plant site
decreases marginallv.
(4) After the embankment of the power plant site is completed, the longitudinal    ;'
change of the river-bed scouring will have a tendency of almost no change at the
upstrearn part and some increase at the downstream part while the cross-sectional
scouring will have following characteristics: the river-bed scouring scope adjacent
to the power plant site decreases a bit and that at the riverbed on the east of the
main channel increases to some-extent.
(5) The local scouring near the embank}ment is mainly found in the vicinity of
southeast and southwest comers of the embankment the max. scouring depth at the
location about 140m away from the south embankrment may reach about 2.5m see
Fig. 6.6).
(6) Borrow Area A and Borrow Area A' according to the Tender Documents bring
about little effect on the flow conditions and TivtT-t-d scouring in the Meghna
China National waier Resources and Hlydropower Engineering Corporation  
Pave i 8r..' .



Numerical Modcl Tcst Rcpori                                             Dcsign Documents
River. Borrow Area B has some adverse effects on the river-bed scouring depth
adjacent to the south embankment. Besides, the cross-section velocity distribution
of the main channel has produced some effects on the westward movement of the
main channel. The modified Dredging B may strengthen transportation capacity of
the main channel of the Meghna River, correspondingly, it may reduce the flow
scouring to the river-bed near the embankment of the site, and the modified
Borrow Area A + A' may increase marginally the extent and depth of the
southwest local scouring of the embankment.
(7) Layout of the embankment in the present model is determined on the basis of
coordinates provided in the Tender Document.

FINAL ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACT ASSESSMENT
Analyses of Dredged Soil Samples
1.     Preliminary Analyses
On August 16, 1999 AES Meghnaghat Limited (the Project Sponsor) collected representative soil
samples of the newly dredged river bottom material at two different locations on their project site.
Mott MacDonald submitted the samples for chemical analysis at a United Kingdom based
laboratory; the results are shown in Tables 1 and 2. Neither the Government of Bangladesh nor
the World Bank have established criterion for soil quality. Consequently, Canadian and
American soil guidelines have been instituted for comparison purposes.
Table 1: Laboratory Analysis of Dredged Soil at Site A
Parameter Description             Result       Units        CCME         U.S. EPA
Guideline'  Guideline2
Arsenic (As), dry weight                   2.65        mg/kg          12           2.4
Cadmium (Cd), dry weight                   <1.7        mgfkg          22           850
Chromium, total (Cr), dry weight            11         mg/kg          87           450
Copper (Cu), dry weight                     7          mg/kg          91          63,000
Lead (Pb), dry weight                       <9         mg/kg          600          400
Mercury (Hg), dry weight                  <0.05        mg/kg          50           510
Nickel (Ni), dry weight                     12         mg/kg          50          34,000
Zinc (Zn), dry weight                       25         mg/kg          360        100,000
Total petroleum hydrocarbons (TPH)         <15         mg/lg          n/c           n/J
All units are in mg/kg.       n/g = no guideline limit
Table 2: Laboratory Analysis of Dredged Soil at Site B
Parameter Description             Result       Units         CCME        U.S. EPA
Guideline'  Guideline2
Arsenic (As), dry weight                   4.30        mg/kg           12           2.4
Cadmium (Cd), dry weight                   <1.7        mg/kg          22           850
Chromium, total (Cr), dry weight            12         mg/kg          87           450
Copper (Cu), dry weight                     8          mg/kg          91          63,000
Lead (Pb), dry weight                       <9         mg/kg          600          400
Mercury (Hg), dry weight                  <0.05        mg/kg          50           510
Nickel (Ni), dry weight                     16         mg/kg          50          34,000
Zinc (Zn), dry weight                       28         mg/kg          360         100,000
Total petroleum hydrocarbons (TPH)         <15         mg/kg          n/g           n/g
All units are in mg/kg.       n/g = no guideline limit
T Ihe Canadian Council of Ministers of the Environment (CCME) have adopted these guideline numbers as the
Canadian Soil Quality Guidelines for the Protection of Environmental and Human Health - Industrial Land-Use
pl999).
The United States Environmental Protection Agency (U.S. EPA), Region 9, has adopted these guideline numbers as
their Risk-Based Screening Levels for Industrial Land-Uses. Region 9 (including the states of California, Arizona,
Nevada, and Hawaii) was selected for comparison, since it is understood from the U.S. EPA that this region's standards
are amongst the strictest in the country.
ESG INTERNATIONAL INC                                                                   t15- 1
SEPTEMBER, 2000



AES MEGHNAGHAT LIMITED
MEGHNAGHAT POWER PROJECT
FINAL ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACT ASSESSMENT
At Sites A and B, the laboratory analysis indicates that arsenic levels were within the identified
CCME guidelines. However, at Site A the analysis shows a slight exceedance of the U.S. EPA
guideline by 0.25 mg/kg, while the sample collected at Site B exceeds the American guideline by
1.9 mglkg. All other sample parameters were within the guideline limits.
Although both samples were within the CCME guidelines, they do exceed the limit of the stricter
U.S. EPA guideline. Thus, the Project Sponsor again undertook additional soil sampling at Sites
I and 2 (equivalent to Sites A and B respectively) on June 22, 2000. At each site, five samples
were collected and were shipped to Philip Analytical Services Corporation (PSC), of Canada for
detailed laboratory analyses.
2.    Detailed Analyses
PSC is a certified and accredited laboratory under the joint Standards Council of Canada and the
Canadian Association of Analytical Environmental Laboratories (SCC/CAEAL) accreditation
program. The detailed sample results obtained by PSC, as well as the quality assurance and
quality control documentation, are provided in Attachment 1.
In total, five samples were collected at each site by the Project Sponsor and analysed for the
following parameters: metals, TPH, polynuclear aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs), volatile organic
compounds (VOCs), phenoxy acid herbicides, organophosphorus pesticides, EPA 608 priority
pollutant pesticides, polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs), and asbestos. PSC completed their
laboratory analysis using U.S. EPA standard methods.
The results of the analytical analyses, yielded the following results:
* phenoxy acid herbicides and organophosphorus pesticides were not detected during the
chemical analysis;
EPA 608 priority pollutant pesticides, PCBs, and VOCs were not detected during the
analyses;
various PAHs compounds were detected during the analysis (e.g., phenanthrene, pyrene,
and chrysene), however, all parameters are within the guidelines;
* asbestos was not detected in any samples; and
*   various metals were detected during the analyses and are within the guidelines, with two
exceptions: arsenic and selenium.
2.1    Arsenic
Generally, arsenic exists in the environment in its natural pentavalent form that is less toxic than
the trivalent form of arsenic that is typically associated with anthropogenic introductions. The
primary natural sources for arsenic and arsenical compounds are volcanic eruptions and
biological methylation during soil weathering. Anthropogenic sources include coal combustion,
copper smelting, and gold mining.
Arsenic is a carcinogen to humans and the primary exposure is occupational (e.g., production and
application of arsenical pesticides and smelters). The primary route of exposure of humans to
arsenic is drinking water and inhalation.
ESG INTERNATIONAL INC                                                        t5- 2
SEPTEMBER, 2000



AES MEGHNAGHAT LIMITED
MEGHNAGHAT POWER PROJECT
FINAL ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACT ASSESSMENT
Arsenic in soil is not readily available in its soluble form because it strongly adsorbs to clay
articles; groundwater contamination usually occurs after the adsorption capacity of the soil has
been exceeded. Typically, arsenic must be in its soluble form to be bioavailable and speciation of
arsenic is pH dependent. It does not bioaccumulate in either plants or animals.
At sample site 2.4 (i.e., Site B), the chemical value calculated for arsenic was 3.8 mg/kg; 1.4
mg/kg above the U.S. EPA guideline. Once again, consistent with the preliminary analytical
results, the value falls well within the CCME guideline of 12 mg/kg. The CCME guidelines used
for comparison purposes relate to the protection of human health based upon the ingestion of dirt
and is a conservative value among international standards. Subsequently, the Project Sponsor
undertook no additional sampling.
2.2    Selenium
The principle anthropogenic sources of selenium are from copper smelting and refining.
Selenium is also found in paints, varnishes, rubber, solar batteries, glass, fungicides, and
insecticides. It is, however, an essential nutrient (i.e., mineral) for both plants and animals.
While an essential nutrient, selenium can accumulate in plants to levels sufficiently high
(>25ppm) to cause toxicity in livestock. Animal exposure is generally via elevated levels of
selenium in food stuffs and forage, while human occupational exposure pathways generally
include inhalation (i.e., hydrogen selenide).
At virtually all the sample sites, the chemical analysis yielded results that were less than 60 ppm.
The laboratory equipment used in the analysis could not specify levels below 60 ppm, which
makes it hard to derive any meaningful conclusions. Although the CCME guideline of 10 ppm is
exceeded, the U.S. EPA guideline of 8,500 ppm has not been breached. Subsequently, the Project
Sponsor undertook no additional sampling.

To help reduce the human death toll caused by these violent storms, Bangladesh has been continually refining
its national cyclone warning system. With the assistance of satellite and radar imnaging technology, weather
forecasts and warnings are issued a minimum of 24 hours in advance of landfall by the Storm Warning Centre
of the Bangladesh Meteorological Department (Ahmed and Afreen, 1992).
Soon after the formation of significant depressions, special weather bulletins are issued to radio and television
stations, port authorities, the Ministry of Relief and Rehabilitation, national media, the Bangladesh Red Cross
Society (BDRCS), and other concerned agencies/organisations (Ahmed and Afreen, 1992). The Bangladesh
Cyclone Preparedness Program, administered by BDRCS, trains, equips, and manages over 25,000 volunteers
who are responsible for evacuation, shelter, safety of people and property, medical assistance, and post-
cyclone food, clothing, clean-up, and sanitary measures. In the event that local communication services are
disrupted during or after a cyclone, BDRCS maintains a field wireless system.

APPENDIX 18: SUMMARY OF AMBIENT NOISE MONITORING
ESG INTERNATIONAL INC.
SEPTEMBER, 2000






NOISE MONITORING OF EXISTING CONDITIONS
Procedures & Instrumentation
All measurements were taken using a Larson-Davis Model 820 Precision Integrating Sound Level Meter
(SLM). The Model 820 uses a Larson-Davis Model 828 preamplifier and a Larson-Davis Model 2560 precision air-
condenser microphone, that have been factory calibrated with the SLM unit. Calibration was checked before and after
measurements with a Larson-Davis Model CAL200 precision acoustic calibrator.
Meteorological Conditions
The weather conditions during the monitoring periods were generally favourable for the collection of ambient
noise levels.
Monitoring Sites
Noise monitoring was conducted at two sites. The locations used have been identified as the most noise-
sensitive receptors, representing mixed and residential land-uses in the vicinity of the proposed power plant Also
factored into the site selections were proximity to the proposed power plant and security considerations during
measurement. The selected sites are described briefly below:
a)     Location 1 - Islampur Village: This site was selected near residences within the Islampur village which lies
immediately to the south of the proposed power plant on the north bank of the Meghna River. The area is
predominantly residential.
a)     Location 2 - Ganganagar Village: This site was selected near residences within the Ganganagar village which
lies approximately 500m to the northeast of the proposed power plant. The area is predominantly residential.
Noise Measurement Results
Measurement results are summarized in Tables I and 2, and plotted in Figures 1 and 2. Both sites were
influenced by spurious high-level noise events sucb as vehicle homs, animals, human voices, and the Islamic calls to
prayer (Azan). These events serve to increase the Lq values in certain 30-minute periods, however, no particular event
was determined as being more dominant than another.
Location I - islampur Village
Continuous sound exposure level monitoring was conducted between 0900h on September 4,1999 and 0830h
on September 5, 1999. The noise descriptors (Lq, Lgo L.0, Llo, etc.) at Location 1 vary throughout the day, but do
follow a typical diurnal pattern with a night-time "dip" characteristic of urban environments. The daytime levels are
dominated by nearby industrial/commercial sources that operate during the day, road and river traffic, and other
activities within the village. The minimum measured night-time (2200h to 0700h) L,q (lhr) was 49 dBA, and the
minimum daytime (0700h to 2200h) Lq (lhr) was 51 dBA.
Location 2 - Ganganagar Village
Continuous sound exposure level monitoring was conducted between 1030h on September 5,1999 and 1000h
on September 6, 1999. The noise descriptors (Lw, L90, Lso, L1o, etc.) at Location 2 vary throughout the day, but do
follow the typical diurnal pattem characteristic of urban environments. The daytime levels are dominated by nearby
industrial/commercial sources that operate during the day, road and river traffic, and other activities within the village.
The minimum measured night-time ; (lhr) was 45 dBA, and the minimum daytime L., (lhr) was 49 dBA.

AES Meghnaghat Ltd                                   Ecological Survey
Ecological Survey
1.0 Introduction
Conservation of biodiversity is now a matter of great concern within Bangladesh. There has
been increasing concern over the environmental consequences of unplanned and unregulated
development of residential, commercial and industrial infrastructure: Human population growth
is also placing an increasing demand upon natural resources. Therefore, conservation of ecology
should get priority for the greater interest of the future generations and in recent time
Government has started attaching higher priority to protecting the nature and ecology.
During the last 100 years at least 18 species of wildlife have become extinct from the country
and about 60-70 species are either endangered or threatened. To help conserve wildlife and
habitat, Bangladesh has 14 protected areas such as National Parks, Archaeological Sites and
Recreational Parks, etc.
2.0 Methodology
The study area for this survey consisted of about a 10 kilometre-radius from the proposed project
site. A team under a ecologist visited the study area several times during the period from 24 July
to 20 August 1999 in order to gather information on ecological aspects by direct observations as
well as from interviews with institutional sources and local people. Specialists in relevant fields
in the country were consulted, (see Acknowledgements) and secondary information was
collected from concerned local offices and published books, journals and periodicals (see
-       Bibliogranhv). Population estimates for the various species present in the study area, were made
from direct surveys, observations, and discussions with specialists and local peoples.
3.0 Ecology and Habitat of the Project Area
The Meghnaghat area is a composite of agricultural land, village settlements, and some industrial
units (i.e. a small dockyard, paper and pulp industry, cement/stone processing unit, garments
industry, vegetable oil mills, etc. on the northern bank, and jute mills, packaging/board mills,
cement/ stone processing units on the southern bank of the river). Except for village settlements
and industrial units, the land is primarily used for agricultural purposes, mainly for growing
crops.
The project site belongs to Pirojpur Union of Sonargaon Thana of Narayanganj district. The
proposed location of the power project is approximately 500 meters to the west of the Meghna
Bridge and is adjacent to the Meghna river bank. The villages that surround the site are Islampur,
Ganganagar, Dhudghata and Kurbanpur. These village settlements are relatively recent,
apparently with the formation of 'char land" formed by sediment and silt deposits adjoining the
river-banks.
4.0 Soils and Crop Production
The surface soil is a mixture of sands and clays and is grey in colour. There remains enough
moisture in the soil for growing crops during the dry season. The crops grown in the surrounding
area include rice, wheat, pulses, oilseeds, vegetables (tomato, eggplant, etc.), sweet potato, and
DPC Group                                                       page-1



AES Meghnaghat Ltd                                     Ecological Survey
watermelon. These are grown mostly during the dry months (October-November to March/April)
because the agricultural land remains under water during the summer months.
5.0 Terrestrial Habitat
The basic landscape of the study area is flat, with village settlements and industrial units on
raised lands (4- 5 meter above the sea level). The surrounding soil belongs to the alluvial flood
plain type with 'low to medium low' elevation (i.e. about 2 m or less from the sea level). Much
of the agricultural land is subject to annual inundation and remains submerged for 4-5 months
during the summer months. Because of extensive development of the surrounding land for
agricultural, industrial and residential uses, truely natural habitats are absent from the study area.
No designated nature reserves or parkland is present within the study area.
The entire proposed power plant site was used for agricultural uses, primarily paddy land as
much of the land remained inundated year-round. During the dry season, some vegetables, wheat
and oil seeds were also grown on the site. No trees or shrubs were present on the site.
6.0 Aquatic Ecosystem
Bangladesh, being a country of rivers and open to the south with Bay of Bengal, has a diverse
range of aquatic and terrestrial resources. The greater study area, in addition to some permanent
wetlands, has long flood plains on either bank of the Meghna River, with these low-lying areas
becoming a temporary flood plain during the monsoon period. Therefore, the environment within
the Meghnaghat area is very favourable to grow and sustain a diverse group of plants and
animals. Further details of the aquatic ecosystem of the project area have been discussed in the
fishery study report.                                                                        0
7.0 Terrestrial Flora
The project area is no different than many other areas of alluvial delta of Bangladesh with mixed
crop vegetation and monoculture tree plantation and homestead based agro-forestry.
Predominantly a very fertile agricultural area, the study area grows mostly high yielding rice
varieties and rabi crops, similar to other flood plain agricultural activities within Bangladesh,
including vegetables in the winter (dry) season. The villages within the study area contain
backyard trees/forests comprised of species common throughout the country. Perennial species
occur mainly on raised lands: road sides, homesteads and the industrial units.
Low growing grasses, herbaceous vegetation and other common plant communities constitute the
floral habitat in the project area. Data collected from field through visits, observations,
interviews and institutional investigations suggests that the project area contains of a plant
community of 82 floral species. As the project site was used for growing agricultural crops, only
those plants (such as paddy, vegetables, wheat and jute) and some common low growing grasses,
were present on the site itself.
Besides cultivated agricultural crops and vegetables, the major floral species as identified during
the survey are shown in Table-1. The institutional sources and the local community in the
project area reported no vulnerable, threatened or endangered plants in the area.

8.0 Terrestrial Fauna
A thorough investigation and survey was carried out in the field and institutional sources were
consulted (see Acknowledgements) to find out the status of terrestrial fauna in the project area
and its immediate vicinity. During field visits a number of avian species, particularly birds of
common identities, were observed throughout the project area.
The terrestrial wildlife species inhabiting in the project area ranges from small organisms like
insects to large mammals like Asiatic Golden Cats. Like other floodplains of the country, the
project area consists of birds, reptiles, amphibians and mammals. The section below will
describe wildlife species separately to reflect the current status of ecological resources in the
area.
8.1 Avis
About 600 species of birds are reported to be found in Bangladesh including about one third
winter migrants (Husain 1997)1. Birds adapted to forests/trees and wetlands have been affected
due to destruction of habitats, especially clearance of forests, felling of trees in village groves
and loss of wetlands. Table 2 provides information on avian species expected to be present
within the ten-kilometre radius of the proposed project site, including those listed as vulnerable,
threatened or endangered. Table 2 also provide names of birds present seasonally and other
species that are typical inhabitants at the local and regional level.
It is reported from the field and institutional sources such as, Department of Forest Department
of Zoology, Dhaka University and National Herbarium that the approximately 35-40 avian
species common in the study area are also common to other parts of the country. The habitat and
breeding ground (i.e., trees) needed by the vulnerable, near to threatened, threatened and
endangered species was absent on the proposed project site as it was use for only agricultural
crops.
'Husain, K. Z. 1997. Birds of Bangladesh. The Weekend Independent, January 3, 1997.

9. Terrestrial Animal Species
Bangladesh, being located at the confluence of the zoo-geographical regions of the Peninsular
India, Himalayas and Southeast Asia, is rich in animal diversity.
Like avian species, several terrestrial animal species are also endangered, threatened or
vulnerable in Bangladesh because of habitat destruction and/or human interference (clearance of
forest areas, felling of trees, clearance of village bushes, 'development' of waste land, reduction
of pasture land, etc.). The various animal species expected to be present within the study area
and reference to their country-wide status is discussed in the section below.
9.1 The Mammals
Terrestrial animal species within Bangladesh include 119 mammals. Of these at least 10 species
have been identified as endangered and 5 species as threatened (NCS, 19912).
During field survey and investigations with the institutional sources around 20 wild mammals
were found to be expected in the study area. The common species in the study area are also
common to other parts of the country. Like other flood plains of Bangladesh, the study area has
some common mammals that include species of jackal, rat, cat, mouse, squirrel and others. These
species basically constitute the wild mammal group in the study area.
The Asiatic Golden Cat typically lives in areas of natural vegetation, including trees and bushes.
No Asiatic Golden Cats were seen on the site and no suitable breeding habitat (i.e., bushes,
foxholes) was observed due to the agricultural use of the site and the large number of people in
the area.
A river mammal -Ganges River Dolphin (Platanista gangetica) -  is found occasionally in the
Meghna River. The dolphin's range extends to into the Ganges, Brahmaputra, Kamaphuli and
Meghna river systems of India, Bhutan, Nepal and Bangladesh. According to the IUCN, the
populations of Ganges River Dolphins as a whole are considered 'endangered" due to a
population reduction of at least 50% over the last three generations, based on direct observations,
a decline in extent of occurrence and/or quality of habitat, and actual or potential levels of
exploitation. Perhaps the greatest threats to the dolphins is dam construction on the Ganges River
(now over 20) which have isolated the population into fragments, boat traffic, pollution, loss of
habitat, and illegal hunting.
The Ganges River Dolphin is about 1.5 to 2.5 metres long and weighs 70 to 90 kilograms. At
birth, calves measure 70 to 75 centimetres and about 7.5 kilograms. Food consists of bottom-
dwelling fish (catfish), mollusks and crustaceans.
The Bangladesh Flood Action Plan (1993) refers to the occurrence of the Ganges River Dolphin
in the North-eastern region in the Kushiyara, upper Meghna and Kalni rivers and their branches.
These regions mark the southernmost range of the dolphins. The dolphin is observed in the study
area particularly in the monsoon season. The dolphin is indicator of deep-water areas with an
2NCS, 1991. Towards Sustainable Development: The National Conservation Strategy of Bangladesh. Ministry of  7>
Environment and Forests & International Union for Conservation of Nature IUCN), 1991
ESG-DPC                                                                     page-13



AES Meghnaghat Ltd                                   Ecological Survey
abundance of large-sized fishes, and fish migratory routes in river channels, which is very much
true for Meghna river. There is no commercial fishery of dolphin. Fishing nets occasionally catch
some. Its oil is extracted and is thought to be beneficial for human health. IUCN and department
of Marine Biology, Chittagong University confirmed not more than 100 dolphin population in
the whole Meghna region. The total population is less than 5,000.
The list of wild mammals are presented in Table 4, including the threatened, endangered and
vulnerable mammalian species.

10. The Reptiles and Amphibians
The National Conservation Study of Bangladesh (1991) recorded 124 reptiles and 19 amphibians
in the country. Of these at least two amphibians and 11 reptiles are threatened.
During survey and field investigations it was found that 11 reptiles and amphibians species
inhabit in the survey area. Although they are not well represented in terms of individual numbers
the species of reptiles and amphibians present in the study area including river and land turtles,
are quite common in flood plain areas like the Meghna Basin. Lizards are very common in the
survey area like any other part of the country, which is also true for frogs.
Several fresh water species of turtles are commercially exploited in Bangladesh for export and
local consumption. The species of highest economic importance are Trionyx gangeticus, Trionyx
hurum, and Lissemys punactata. The District Fisheries office states that fresh water turtle meat is
widely used as a source of protein in the study area. In most of thewetlands of the estuary the
temporary dry season fishing camps (Khola) are built near the water bodies. Most of the
fishermen living in these camps regularly consume turtle meat which they catch. Resident
fishermen also trap turtles throughout the year either for their own consumption or to sell in the
markets. The Hindu community of the area consume turtles as food and use them as medicine
and on religious occasions.
The species which are common in the area are Roof Turtle (Kachuga tecta), Brahminy Turtle
(Hardella thurjii), Peo Soft Shell Turtle (Aspideretes hurum), Spotted Pond Turtle (Geochlemys
hamiltonii), and Spotted Flapshell Turtle (Lissemys punctata). The remains of the turtles found
near human habitations indicate that the group was part of man's diet for centuries in the Meghna
area and the rest of the country.
The turtles are present in both the wet and dry seasons. They lay their eggs on the gound near by
the water or other suitable place near by the bush or swampy areas in the wetland.
The Gharials travel in the deep water of the entire Meghna River along the main course. They
nornally take rest on the sandbars or shoals in the river. They also stay near by the bushes,
catkin forest (bush) in the shoals in the river. They also stay near by the bushes, catkin forest
(bush) in the shoals of the river. It is also reported that oil from turtles is extracted and used for
medicinal purpose to cure respiratory diseases, rheumatic fever and skin diseases.
Table 6 presents the list and other particulars of reptiles and amphibians inhabit in the area,
including threatened, endangered and vulnerable reptiles and amphibians.

11. Acknowledgements
The ecological survey team was led and the report under discussion was prepared by Dr Gul
Hossain, a well named ecologist/crop botanist of our country, recently retired from Bangladesh
Agricultural Research Council (BARC) and by associated with environmental studies.
During the process of the study, Dr. Kazi Zaker Hussain, Department of Zoology, Prof. Sajjadur
Rashid, Department of Geography and Environment, Dhaka University, Dr. Makbul Ahmed,
Dhaka Zoo and Mr Abdur Razzaque from Department of Forest, was extensively consulted by
the team. The Author of this report and DPC gratefully acknowledge their valuable contributions
to the study and appreciate comments on the report.
Acknowledgements are also noted to the field level institutional sources, like Thana Agricultural
Extension Office, Divisional Forest Office and the local community leaders and members who
provided their extreme co-operation during the surveys, interviews and investigations in the
field.

decreasing. Fish contribetes abouit 64% prote.ini intake to Uangindeshi people. About 19%
people or Bangladesh  are eithfer on full timie or parl time basis living 013 fislhin. A substantial

niajor export fish species of Bangladesh, along withi few species from marine fislieries.
