A river mammal - Ganges River Dolphin (Platanista gangetica) -  is found occasionally in
tbe Meghna River. The dolplpin's range extends to into the Ganges, Brahmaputra, Karnaphuli
atd Meghna river syslems of India, Blhutan. Nepal and Bangladeshi. According to tlle IUCN,
the populations of Ganges River Dolpl)ins as a whole are considered 'endangered" due to a
population reduction of at least 50% over the last three generationis, based on direct
observations, a decline in extetit of occurrence and/or quality of habitat, and actual or
potential levels of exploitation. Perhaps the greatest threats to the dolphins is dam
construction on the Ganges River (now over 20) which have isolated the population into
fragments. boat traffic, pollution, loss of labitat, arid illegal hunting.
The Ganges River Dolphin is about 1.5 to 2.5 metres long and weighs 70 to 90 kilograms. At
birth, calves tmeasure 70 to 75 centimetres and about 7.5 kilograms. Food consists of bouton-
dwelling fisli (catfish), mollksks and crustaceans.
Tihe Bangladesh Flood Action Plan (1993) refers to lthe occurrence of the Ganges River
Dolphin in the North-eastern region in the Kushiyara, upper Meghns and Kalni rives and
their branches. These regions mark dhe southernmost range of the dolphins. The dolphin is
observed in tEie study area particularly in the monsoon season. The dolphin is indicator of
deep-water -reas with an abuidance of large-sized rishes, and fish migralory routes in river
channels, which is vcry much true for Meghna river. I'here is no commercial fishery of
dolphin. Fisling nets occasionally catLch some. Its oil is extracted -and is thought to be
beneircial fur human health. IUCN and department of Marine Biology, Chittagong University
confirnmed not more than 100 dolplin population in the whole Meghna region. Ibe total
population is less than 5,000.

B.O Fislueries Comniunity
A major poition of the people residing along Ihe Megluia estuary are either directly or
indirectly involved with rishery activities. Sotme of them deal in fish and some culture fishCe
in the area. Traditionally, a lower caste of Ilindus is involved in fisihing as a community for
centuries. With the change of the national economy the character and composition of
fishermen community has been changed. Now, all people having the fish cultivating land aTe
more or less related with fishiing activily and rtsh trading within the immediate vicinity in the
study Area. A generat esLiatle suggest that about 35-40 villages in the Meghna estuary area
are r-edoninantly fishiLng villages.
9.0 Life and Economy of Meghon Estuary People
The rich and diverse nature of the water environments in the Meghna river flood plain
provide the opportunity to tlhe niajority of the farming population to engage in fishing
sometime during tIie year. In addition lo such fishing, there are some professional activities
for lull-time fishers for whom fishing is even main occupation. Even they fish seasonally and
many or them were dependent upon non-fishing jobs to make ends meet. Onset of heavy rains
in June and July, the breeding move out of the large rivers like the Meghna and farmers begin
to rish in hollows and paddy fields in which was found a large number of smnall fishes.
Many professional fishers are boatmen who weave their nets, transport fish from catching
points to markets, spin ttiread for lines, make missiles, fix anid mobile traps, cure and preserve
fish, manufacture fish oil. The District Fisheries office, Narayangonj lhat more than 12
percent households in the Meghna river system catchlnent area are engaged in fishing
activities. TI,e community life and household economy in remote nural villages are directly
influenced by fishery and related activities. Because of relative familiarity of local people
witb fishing activities, in recent days richer segmentts of fishery community are moving to
cultural fisheries and this has now become quite common in the Meghna river area.
10.0 Aquanlic lRabitals
Bangladeshi possesses 260 species of rresh water fishes, some species of molluscs (so far 20
species have been identifed), arthropods (60 species of prawns), reptiles, 477  mmals and
other invertebrates.
Tlhe upper Mcglua river as a floodplain including wet lands, swamps, canals, haor/ baors,
beels, other water bodies are the important habitats for fisihes. In addition, the excavated
ponds, and compartmenLalized water reaches are also used as rishing grounds for the
cultured piscicultue. Paddy fields during the monsoon become the vast tract of fish habitats
for a definite period from May to December. Moreover, hatcheries, specially protected waLer
pools are breeding grounds of the spawns, fries and shrimps.
11.0 Breeding Nrlod aiid Ground
Bangladesh has the unique advantage of possessing the world's largest delta, the Ganges
DelLa, whliclh offers a vast and varied fisheries potential in its fresh, brackish and marine
waters. Several river systems such as the Meghna, the Brahmnaputra and the Gumti being
comprise the vast tract of fishing culture and breeding ground. The inland waters of

Bangladesh are inhabited by 260 indigenous and 1  exotic species of fish (Rahman 1989) ard
25 species of Prawn (Ali, 1992).
Both the Kushiiara and ilhe Surnia river drain into the upper Meglina near Habiganj district
town of greater Sylliet district. All of these rivers and their tributaries and distributors
overflow their banks and flood extensive areas of the low lying lands during the monsoon
from May to October. Bangladesh have 9,300,000 ha of flood plains including 2,834,000 ha
of paddy fields inundated for three to four months of the year. Out of which the Meghna river
syslemns occtupy about 33.592 ha. These flood plains are also important fishi breeding habitats.

of major carps are April to June. Major carp spawning grounds are located in the headwater
streams of the Surma and Kusliiara rivers and in ille l3arak in India. This indicates that tile
upper Meghna stocks migrate upstream to India Lo spawn tlhere.

12.1 MarILCetillg Structture
Powerful marketing internmediaries are controlling the fish market in the project area. Four to
five influential market intermediaries usually involved in the marketing of bulk quantity of
fisieries products. In general, the fisli markeL is strictured in levels as follows:
Pfimary Maidet
Agents (fissh btokers) which are commonly called as " Dalals/Nikari" approach the primary
producers (the fishermen or the farmers) and procure fishes on btihalf or the primary fish
traders (Mahlajans or Aratdar cumn Mahiajans). In lieu of their services the agents get
commission from Mahajans. PortiDns of the catchi/production are also sold locally in village
markets through fishermen themselves or retailers for local consumption. The Meginaghat
and its surrcounding primary fish markets also operate in the same way, In the irmmediatc
vicinity of the project arca about 7 or 8 suchi markets exists wihich Forms the primary market
strucure of the area.
,Secondary Afarkd
Fish collected througb different sources and places by the collectors (Mahajaxs) are brought
to the nearby thana (or large) mnarkets used as fish selling points. Meghuaghat is one of suclh
fish markets/selling points even in the whole country. At this point, fishes are sold to the next
intermediaries, the fish traders locally known as "Beparies". With the help of commission
agents (ArnLdars), tljey conLrol these sales points. It wu reporied that 4 or 5 fish traders
control 85% of thte total fish marketing volume in the Megliraghat point. Further
investigptions on the total volume suggest that about 80-100 metric tons (MT) fishes of
different species are traded in the Meghnaghat selling point.
Ifigher .Seconrd ayAarket
The lradens (Beparies) of lhe Meghnagbat area carry the fish to Dhaka, Chittagong and other
important market centers by road, rivcr or rail and sell fishes it to the distributors (Paikars)
through tile commission agents (Aratdars), At this point the divergence starts and the

products are chainelised through the distribution channels. A good quantity of Meghna river

Aquaculture development in tthe country has also catalyzed the growth of the fish, shrimp and

13.0  Fish, Distribuntion Market
Distributors sell their purchase to the retailers. Retailers, in turn, sell their products directly to
the consumer through fixed stalls in city/town markets or by vending on head or by rickshaw
vans. Some of the retailers take it back to the suburban areas or peripheral areas for selling it
to the local consumers.
Consignments of fish or fisheries products are handled by the concerned intermediaries at
different marketing poinits. As and when required, products are cleaned, iced, sorted,
preserved, stored, repacked and transported. Meghnaghat point is one of the major location of
Bangladesh's fish distribution system
Chittagong, Cox'6 Bazar, Barisal, Khulna, Bagerhat, Satkhira and Cbandpur are major
landing and marketing centres for bulk quantity of marine and brackishwater fish and shrimps
species. Bhairab Bazar, Kuliarchiar, Narsingdi, Bhugyakul, Munshiganj, Nilkomal are on the
other hand, myor leading and marketing centres for freshwater fish. Besides these, Lhere are
other landing/collection and marketing centres for fish caught from flood plain areas.
14.0 Fish rood
The availability of supplemenLary feed is one of the key inputs in fish culture for enhancing
fish production. The common supplementary feeds in Bangladesh are rice bran, wheat brmn
oil cake and some other agricultural wastes. As a resource constraints country, there is a
severm competition for these agricultural wastes for raising livestock and as fuel. Therefore,
the fish nutritionists aud aquaculOurists have been exploring the possibility of utilizing
alternative sources like soft plant leaves and aquatic vascular plants. Amongst several aquatic
plants, duckweed (Lenina sp.) whicih normally grows easily in backyard dilches, canals and
derelict ponds everywhere in Bangladesh is being considered as highly feasible provision. A
duckweed-1ed rish ponds appears to provide with a complete, balanced diet for those carps
that consunie it directly, while the faces of duckweed feeding species, are consumed directly
by detritus feeders, or indirectly through fertilization, plankton and other natural food
organisms, provide adequate food for reniaining bottom and column-feeding carp varieties.

16.0  Fishl Migration
Canals play t critical role in fish population dynamics in the Meghhna river floodplain. They
provide the important migration pathways for fish moving from rivers to floodplain during
early life stages and for reproductive purposes. Fish population stability in the floodplain
depends on fvnctioning canals. In the study area, most consumedspecies of fish were
observed to actively or passively migrate into the canals in the beginming of the monsoon
season. Major Carps (Catla catla, Labeo ro/ita, Labeo caclbasu Cirrhiiaus mrigala) begin
their longitudinal migration between March and May from their dry season habitats in beels
and the lower reaches of rivers to upstream spawning areas in the Meghna and Brahmaputra.
They spawvn fom May to August. Of all the rivers in Bangladesh, the Brmhmaputra has the
richest stock of major carps (Tsai and Ali 1986). During the day season, most speaes inhabit
the deeper waler of permanent river systems.
A schematic diagram of fish migration pattems is included as Figure 1.
17.0 Fisli Environment
The importance of fishes in the lives of the people is not surprising in the vast river systems
of the Megihna (the Brahmaputra, the Gumti and the M.eghna). The waters of this river
systems and many branches and tributaries of the river have been central to the lives of both
the fishers anid non fishers. In addition to the low lying area (all kinds of depressions,
wetlands, beefs and haours of the Meghna river flood plains) of the region is tbe fishing
hiabitats. Seasonal fishing durintg the rainy season usually increases due to the regular
flooding which is common for every year.

(he hatchleries have been established in the flood plain of the Meghna fiver, in the district of

20.0   Results of Fisi Survey and lnvestigatiou
A rield survey was conducted among the local people, fisliermen, markel people including
traders, traditional fishermen community and others to know the fishing prMctices, fishing
seasons, approxiniate quantity of catcih by species,,price per kg, fishing grounds u5ed by fish
species etc. During the process of field survey and investigation, in all 30 people were
interviewed and consulted, using a structured checklist (checklisL attached) in the surrounding
ofupper Mcghna river area.
Table 4 summarized the results of the survey and investigation made. It is evident from the
data that out of around 30 listed species, as yet only eight (8) species are cultured in ponds
and the rest are predominantly practiced as captured fislieries in the Meglina river. In the
upper Megina river system, except Rui, Catla, Carp, Catfish, Hilsa all species are in genena
available year round. Most reasonably Ifilsa bas the highest catch in thc catch season
followed by Catla and Carp. Fish prices are in general very high in the Meghna region as
reported by all respondents interviewed and consulted, which is not also unusual to other
parts or the country. Except Catfisih, l-lilsa, and Bata all oLlier fish species in the Meghna
river area uses both river anid flood plain as habitats.

AES Meghnaghat Ltd                                     Road Traffic Survey
Road Traffic Survey
1.0 Introduction
In Bangladesh the road communication network is not extensively developed. The road
width is narrow with respect to the traffic volume. The road system is connected by
bridges and culverts constructed even sometime within half a kilometer distance in most
of the highways. The incidence of accidents now on the highway is also higher than that
of any other time. The types and models of vehicles plying on the highway are variant
and old. All kinds of vehicle especially the old buses, trucks and tempos and auto
rickshaws discharge black smokes while plying on the road. Even that about 80% of the
vehicles running on the road systems are re-conditioned and sometimes the cars operated
on road are practically out of order emitting black smokes hazardous to public health and
thus polluting the environment. Most of the roads in our country are constructed with
Bitumen-concrete mixture which are susceptible to the tropical climate Bangladesh
experience almost all the year round.
2.0 Purpose of the Survey
With a view to counting the actual numbers of the vehicles plying along the Dhaka-
Chittagong Highway a road traffic survey was carried out. The survey work was also
designed to collect inforrnation during high-traffic time periods. The data is also
supplemented with road accident data collected from secondary sources.
3.0 Methodology
For the purpose of carrying out the survey, a team consisting of three surveyors was
deployed to the survey location. A survey assistant from the locality was engaged for the
purpose of assisting the team especially to continue the nighttime survey work. The
vehicles were counted immediately at the time of passing the station and recorded in data
record sheet. The vehicles were counted simultaneously for both directions.
4.0 Survey Period
The survey period for both motorized and non-motorized vehicles was from 23 July to 24
July and 26 July to 27 July 1999. The survey was conducted continuously over a 24-hour
period on each date.
5.0 Description of the Site
The site of the Meghnaghat Power Project lies at the left bank of the River Meghna that is
about 40 km away from Dhaka, the capital city of Bangladesh. The site is also situated at
the west side of the Dhaka-Chittagong highway in the mouza Char Ramzan Sonaullah
(Village Islampur) of Thana Sonargaon under Narayanganj district.
DPC                                                                 page-1



AES Meghnaghat Ltd                                     Road Traffic Survey
As a result of the construction of bridges over the Meghna and the Gumti rivers the
country's biggest seaport Chittagong and the tourist spot Cox's Bazar have been directly
connected with Dhaka. The recently completed Bangladesh's longest bridge over the
Jamuna River, have been also connected directly with Banglaband, the country's north-
western most land port in Tetulia Thana in the district of Panchagarh. Consequently, the
traffic volume over the highway is being increased rapidly.
6.0 Condition of the Highway
The devastating flood of the last year, 1998 ravaged the three-fourth area of the whole of
Bangladesh. The Dhaka-Chittagong highway was inundated at several points from
Kanchpur to the Meghnaghat. The 1998 flood, the highest catastrophe of the century,
breached the highway at many points. The swirling waters of the Meghna and the
Brahmaputra river-systems washed away the flanks of the highway in a stretch of several
kilometers from Kanchpur upto the Meghnaghat. The highway was seriously damaged
and many pockets, borrow pits and holes were created on the surface. The furies and
bores of the devastating flood eroded the slopes and shoulders of the road and made most
of the old bridges over the highway weak & unrestraint to allow the vehicles over the
road. They were unable to bear the heavy truckloads. The bridges needed to be replaced
for safe and smooth running of the vehicles.
The Government has taken proper initiatives to rehabilitate/develop the road
systems immediately after the recession of the floodwaters. The following types of
construction works are going on in full swing.
a) Bridge Construction
At least three medium-sized bridges over the highway upto the Meghnaghat are being
constructed rapidly. For these reasons many diversions and belly bridges have been
placed at several points of the road.
b) Widening the Road Width
Anticipating the future traffic volume over the highway, the road width is being widened
by filling earth or sand on either side of the road. The bricks, brick bats and concrete
remain heaved up for construction work at the roadside. The earth compaction, dressing
work, shoulders making and finishing work are being accelerated in the meantime. The
road carpeting work will be done just after full compaction & gaining sufficient stiffness.
c) Rise of Road Height
Considering the Highest Flood Level (HFL) of the flood occurred in 1998, the height of
the road is being elevated above the HFL of 1998 and the earth filling work is going on
accordingly. The sand and earth are being brought to the construction site by the
motorized boats and vessels for the construction purpose.
DPC                                                                  page-2



AES Meghnaghat Ltd                                    Road Traffic Survey
d) Selection of the Site for the Traffic Survey
The site for the road traffic survey was selected at the south tip of the Meghna Bridge.
This is situated at the Chayana Bazar in Gazaria Thana under Munshiganj district. The
vehicles ply on the road for almost 24 hours. Even the pedestrians move on the highway
during the late evening. All kinds of vehicles like Bus, Truck, Minibus, Auto-Rickshw,
Rickshaw, etc. were counted on both directions. The survey was performed for 24 hours.
7.0   Data Processing
The counted and recorded data were classified and formatted/tabulated categorically to
show the traffic profile through computer entry.
8.0   Findings
The vehicles plying on the road are very common in Bangladesh with some exception.
Traffic volume along Dhaka-Chittagong highway is steadily increasing and to help
alleviate the problem, the highway is being expanded from two lanes to four with an
anticipated completion period of 2003 year.
9.0   Road Accidents
A list of road accidents occurred on the Highway were collected from Sonargaon Police
Station for a period from January, 1994 to July, 1999.

AES Meghnaghat Ltd                                    River Traffic Survey
River Traffic Survey
1.0 Introduction
The AES Meghnaghat Limited had assigned DPC Group, Dhaka to carry out the traffic
survey. As the Meghnaghat river port is one of the major inland river port and trading
center, the importance of the area is also rapidly increasing day by day due to various
developmental efforts in the region. To asses this increased importance it is essential to
estimate the river traffic volume of the River Meghna to find out the trend of inland
business activities of the locality.
2.0 The Meghna River-
The Meghna river is one of the longest river of Bangladesh. It originates from the
Barrack River passing through Assam Province of India and finally enters into
Bangladesh near Zakiganj Thana of Sylhet district in the name of the Surma River. The
Barrack River has been bifurcated at the point Zakiganj in the name of I) The Surma and
2) The Kushiara. The united courses of these rivers in the downstream near Habiganj the
river system flows southward in the name of the Meghna. The Meghna meets the old
Brahmaputra near Bhairab passes through the present Meghnaghat and flows into the Bay
of Bengal again meeting with the Padma River at the downstream of Chandpur. Many
people (45% of the total population of Bangladesh) residing in the flood plain of the
Meghna live on fishing, in-land trading activities on the Meghna including a substantial
contribution to the agricultural production system of the entire river basin.
3.0 Purpose of the Survey
The survey was carried out to know the traffic volume transported on the river,
particularly at the survey location with a view to estimate the importance of the water
transport system operates in the region.
4.0 Time Period
The river traffic survey was carried out on 27 July and 29 July, 1999. The survey work
was performed for 16 hours in both the days.
5.0 Survey Team
A team consisting of three members was deployed to the traffic counting location in order
to carry out the survey work. One local assistant was hired for the night to support the
DPC team. The team members counted both stream (up stream and downstream) bound
vessels simultaneously.
DPC                                                                 page-i



AES Meghnaghat Ltd                                      River Traffic Survey
6.0 Selection of Site for the River Traffic Survey
Based on the maximum availability and accessibility of the vessels at the points over the
scheduled time period, the sites for river traffic survey were selected at some suitable
locations on either side of the Meghna River. The stations were also selected on the basis
of inforrnation of the river traffic volume from the local key informants. The river survey
was carried out at four stations like-I) Islampur 2) Super Board Mills point 3) Ishmanir
Char and 4) Bati Betagir Char.
7.0 Methodology
The survey activity was performed rotatorily by 4 teams (surveyors). The surveyors
counted the vessels for 16 hours from 06 AM to 10 PM continuously. The counting and
recording was performed for both upstream and downstream bound vessels
simultaneously.
8.0 Data Processing
The counted and recorded data was classified and formatted/tabulated categorically and
shown in the traffic profile with the help of computer data entry and processing.
DPC                                                                   page-2

APPENDIX 114:
Disease Vectors in Bangladesh
Malaria, black fever, cholera, and small pox have essentially been eradicated from Dhaka (Bigelow,
1995). Outside of Dhaka, however, parasitic and communicable diseases are more common. The parasitic
and communicable diseases that may be encountered in the vicinity of the MPSA are described below:
> Malaria is an infectious tropical disease caused by the protozoa Plasmodium and is primarily
transmitted to humans by the bite of the Anopheles mosquito, which are most active between
dusk and dawn. However, malaria can also be transmitted by blood transfusion, and by
contamninated needles and syringes. Protection from biting mosquitoes is the first line of
defence against malaria;
. Typhoid Fever is caused by the systemic bacteria Salmonella typhi, which infects the
intestinal tract and occasionally the bloodstream. It is usually transmitted by food or drink
that has been contaminated by feces or urine of an infected person;
H Hepatitis A, B, and C are viral infections of the liver. Hepatitis A is a contagious viral disease
which is most commonly spread from person to person through fecal contamination and then
hand-to-mouth contact, or through contaminated food and water. Hepatitis B and C are
contracted through the transfer of blood products or sexual activities;
D Dengue Fever is a severe, frequently fatal viral disease transmitted by urban Aedes
mosquitos. The principal vector mosquito is Aedes aegypti, a species found living in close
association with humans in most tropical urban areas. The disease is usually benign and self-
limiting after about 7 days. Dengue may also present as a severe and fatal hemorrhagic
disease, called dengue hemorrhagic fever (DHF). There is no specific treatment for dengue
infection;
. Schistosomiasis (also known as "bilharzia") is an infection by eggs of the Schistosoma
flatworm. The infection may be contracted when a persons skin comes in contact with
contaminated fresh water in which certain types of snails are living. Fresh water becomes
contamiinated by Schistosoma eggs when infected people urinate or defecate in the water;
- Cholera, an acute diarrhoeal illness caused by infection of the intestine with the bacterium
Vibrio cholerae, is a major problem in Bangladesh. A person may get cholera by drinking
water or eating food contaminated with the cholera bacterium or through contact with feces-
contaminated water or food. The cholera bacterium may also live in the environment in
brackish rivers and coastal waters. The infection is often mild or without symptoms, but
sormetimes it can be severe.
Vaccination, where available, and prudent behaviour can be a very effective mneans to avoid contracting
these common parasitic and infectious diseases.
